Accomplish an engine start (Check No. 2). Check for EEC fault indications and record on Fig. . Make sure all accessory loads are OFF. Make sure Cabin Bleed and Anti-icing Bleeds are selected OFF.
Advance thrust lever to the NORMAL TAKE-OFF detent and allow engine to stabilize for three minutes.

DO NOT EXCEED VALUES OF N2 AND T4.5 PREVIOUSLY DETERMINED. IF EITHER MAXIMUM VALUE IS EXCEEDED, REFER TO CHAPTER 72-00-00, FAULT ISOLATION FOR CORRECTIVE ACTION. FOLLOWING RECTIFICATION REPEAT CALIBRATION CHECK.Record the following parameters on Figure as obtained from the cockpit instruments:
N1
N2
ITT (T4.5)
OAT
FUEL FLOW
FUEL PRESS.
OIL PRESS.
OIL TEMP.
VIBRATION LEVEL Record fuel flow from cockpit instrumentation.

Readjust throttle, and record parameters listed above for each of the conditions defined in Figure ie: Normal Take-off (NTO), NTO-2%, NTO-4%, NTO-6%, NTO-10%, and Ground Idle. Allow a minimum of 1 to 2 minutes for engine to stabilize. When setting to engine conditions as required, move the thrust lever in one direction only. Reduced scatter is preferable for even spacing of calibration points on the plot.
Shut down engine on completion of calibration run (Ref. Check No. 3).
Make a copy of Figure and plot N2 Corr and T4.5 Corr against N1 Corr.
If it is not possible to plot the final N1 conditions, due to high or low ambient temperatures, use the four useable conditions only.
If excessive scatter is apparent on plotting the data, rerun the discrepant points.
Keep the graph of the calibration result together with the engine logbook for future reference.

procedure.title: Check No. 5 - Engine Performance
procedure.step: A performance check is to be carried out after completion of work on gas path components or as required by Major Component Repair/Replacement (Ref. Table ).
The procedure to be followed is the same as for Engine Calibration, except data is only required for normal take-off condition.

Plot N2 Corr and T4.5 Corr vs N1 Corr on the existing calibration curves obtained at ground run on initial installation. If the points obtained are within ± 0.5% N2 and ± 10°C T4.5, performance check is satisfactory.

figure.title: Engine Calibration and Performance Check Curve

procedure.title: Check No. 6 - Emergency Fuel Shut-off Cable Rigging
procedure.step: Completion of one or more of the following tasks requires complete installation and adjustment (rigging) of the fuel shut-off cable (Ref. 73-10-05): Replacement of Fuel Shut-off Valve (Ref. 73-10-05). Replacement of Fuel Start and Dump Valve (Ref. 73-10-05). Repair or replacement of combustion chamber liner and related parts (Ref. 72-40-01). Repair or replacement of HP turbine and related parts (Ref. 72-50-01). Repair or replacement of LP turbine and related parts (Ref. 72-50-02). Repair or replacement of exhaust case and related parts (Ref. 72-50-03).
Installation of an engine on an aircraft requires a dimensional check of the fuel shut-off valve tripper sleeve and fuel shut-off cable as described in Chapter 73-10-05.

procedure.title: Check No. 7 - Bleed Valve Operational Checks
procedure.step: Starting (P2.8) BOV Operational Check (Ref. Table ): Check the OAT and find the BOV closing point in Table . Start engine and allow to stabilize at idle. Select engine anti-ice OFF. Check that the BOV closes as follows: Slowly increase the engine speed until N2 goes through the closing point. If the TLA is moved too rapidly the BOV(s) can close at a different N2 speed and invalidate the test. Monitor T45 temperature. Look for a momentary drop in T45 of approximately 10°C at the closing point, followed by a normal continued increase in T45. If T45 does not drop, proceed as follows: Clean and inspect the P2.8 Bleed Valve (Ref. 75-30-01). Replace the starting BOV Solenoid (Ref. 75-30-02), if it has accumulated over 400 hours. Do a BOV close check (Ref. step ). Check that the BOV opens as follows: Slowly reduce the engine speed until N2 goes through the opening point. If the TLA is moved too rapidly the BOV(s) can open at a different N2 speed and invalidate the test. Monitor T45 temperature. Look for a momentary increase in T45 of approximately 10°C at the opening point, followed by a normal continued decrease in T45. If T45 does not increase, proceed as follows: Clean and inspect the P2.8 Bleed Valve (Ref. 75-30-01). Replace the starting BOV Solenoid (Ref. 75-30-02), if it has accumulated over 400 hours. Do a BOV open check (Ref. step ).

Handling (P2.5 and P2.8) BOV Operational Check (Ref. Table ): Check the OAT and find the BOV closing point in Table . Start engine and allow to stabilize at idle. Select engine anti-ice OFF. Check that the BOV closes as follows: Monitor T45 temperature and N2. Slowly increase the engine speed until N2 goes through the closing point. If the TLA is moved too rapidly the BOV(s) may close at a different N2 speed and invalidate the test. Look for a momentary decrease in N2 by approximately 2% and a momentary decrease in T45 by approximately 40°C, followed by a normal continued increase in N2 and T45. If the increase in T45 that comes after the BOV closes shows a higher than normal temperature when compared to the other engine and , continue as follows: Clean and inspect the P2.5 and P2.8 Bleed Valves (Ref. 75-30-01). Replace the handling BOV Solenoid (Ref. 75-30-02) if it has accumulated over 400 hours. Do a BOV close check (Ref. step ). Check that the BOV opens as follows: Slowly reduce the engine speed until N2 goes through the opening point. If the TLA is moved too rapidly the BOV(s) may open at a different N2 speed and invalidate the test. Look for a momentary increase in N2 by approximately 2% and a momentary increase in T45 by approximately 40°C, followed by a normal continued decrease in N2 and T45. If the decrease in T45 that comes after the BOV opens shows a higher than normal temperature when compared to the other engine and , proceed as follows: Clean and inspect the P2.5 and P2.8 Bleed Valves (Ref. 75-30-01). Replace the handling BOV Solenoid (Ref. 75-30-02), if it has accumulated over 400 hours. Do a BOV open check (Ref. step .

procedure.title: Check No. 8 - Leak Check
procedure.step: Do the engine ground run checks pre-start, engine start and engine shutdown (Ref. Para. , and ).
Start the engine, run for two minutes or until oil pressure and oil temperature are stabilized.
For AGB seals replacement, run the engine at max. power for two minutes minimum.
Shut down the engine.
Do a visual check for fuel/oil leaks. If there are leaks, correct as necessary and do the leak test again.

procedure.title: Cabin Bleed Ports Blanking Procedure (Ref. Fig. )

key.def: LP Bleed Pad Cover Gasket (Ref. IPC)
HP Bleed Pad Cover Gasket (Ref. AMM)

procedure.caution: THIS PROCEDURE IS USED STRICTLY FOR MAINTENANCE PURPOSES AND IS TO BE USED WHEN PERFORMING ENGINE COMPRESSOR WASH AND/OR DURING INVESTIGATION OF PERFORMANCE DETERIORATION.
procedure.step: Make sure aircraft bleed system is shut-off.
Disconnect the P2.5 and P3 engine cabin bleed ports, on the aircraft side of the engine.
Install a slave LP P2.5 cabin bleed cover (1) and new gasket (2). Install six bolts (4) and torque to 36 to 40 lb.in (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Install a slave P3 cabin bleed cover (5) (PWC43436) and new gasket (6). Install five bolts (8) and torque (Ref. AMM).
Perform engine compressor wash (Ref. 71-00-00, CLEANING) and/or engine performance run, refer to Para.
Remove the slave P2.5 cabin bleed cover (1) and gasket (2) previously installed.
Remove the slave P3 cabin bleed cover (5) (PWC43436) and gasket (6) previously installed.
Install aircraft cabin bleed ports connection on the aircraft side of the engine (Ref. AMM).

n-para.title: Motoring Runs
n-para.caution: OBSERVE STARTER DUTY CYCLE. FAILURE TO COMPLY MAY RESULT IN DAMAGE TO EQUIPMENT (REF. AMM).
n-para.note: Post multiple motoring runs (more than four), which may cause excess oil to accumulate in air passages, perform a normal engine start. Select bleed “ON”. Run engine for a minimum of five minutes at ground idle, then increase to 82% N1 and allow engine to stabilize for a minimum of 10 minutes. Finally decrease to ground idle and run for a further five minutes for cool down prior to shutdown. If smoke in the cabin is noticed, inspect the cabin bleed P2.5 port. If oil is found in the cabin bleed P2.5 port, clean the entire ECS systems, duct and repeat the ground run as identified above.

procedure.title: Dry Motoring Run
procedure.step: The following procedure is used to clear the engine at any time during ground operation when it is deemed necessary to purge the engine of internally trapped fuel and vapors. Air passing through the engine serves to remove fuel or vapor from the combustor area, turbines and engine exhaust nozzle. TLA - CUT-OFF or IDLE with CUT OFF switch selected OFF. Ignition Switches - OFF. Engine Master Switch - ON. Engine Starter Switch - ON. Maintain starter operation for the desired duration. Normally 15 seconds. Observe starter limits (refer to applicable Starter Manufacturers Manual). Engine Starter Switch - OFF. Engine Master Switch - OFF. Observe starter cool-down period (refer to applicable Starter Manufacturers Manual prior to attempting further starting operations).

procedure.title: Wet Motoring Run
procedure.caution: THIS PROCEDURE IS USED STRICTLY FOR MAINTENANCE PURPOSES AND IS NOT PART OF NORMAL START PROCEDURES. AFTER A WET MOTORING RUN, A DRY MOTORING MUST BE ACCOMPLISHED BEFORE ANY START IS ATTEMPTED.
procedure.step: Accomplish prestart Check No. 1.
Ignition Switches - OFF.
Engine Starter Switch - ON.
TLA - IDLE detent. Maintain starter operation for desired duration. Observe starter limits (refer to applicable Starter Manufacturers Manual).
TLA - CUT-OFF or CUT-OFF switch to OFF.
Engine Starter Switch - OFF.
Fuel Boost Pump Switch - OFF.
Fuel System Shut-off Switch - FUEL OFF.
Engine Master Switch - OFF.
Allow starter to cool for specified period, then accomplish a dry motoring run.

procedure.title: Emergency - Ground Fire
procedure.step: TLA - CUT-OFF or IDLE with CUT OFF switch selected OFF.
Engine Master Switch - ON.
Fuel Boost Pump Switch - OFF.
Fuel System Shut-off Switch - OFF.
Engine Starter Switch - ON.
Maintain starter operation for the desired duration. Observe starter limits. (Refer to the applicable Aircraft Flight Manual).
Engine Starter Switch - OFF.
Engine Master Switch - OFF.
Allow the starter to cool before any further starting operation is attempted.

procedure.title: Engine Oil Pressure Adjustment (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.caution: DO NOT ADJUST OIL PRESSURE TO COMPENSATE FOR UNRESOLVED OIL SYSTEM PROBLEMS (REF. 72-00-00, FAULT ISOLATION). THIS COULD CAUSE MOP TO BE OUT OF SPECIFIED LIMITS AND CAUSE DAMAGE TO OIL SYSTEM COMPONENTS.
procedure.step: Shut down engine.
Remove two nuts (1) and remove cover (3) using puller (PWC43172). Remove and discard preformed packing (4).

Adjust sleeve (5) using a 7/8 inch open-end wrench, clockwise to increase pressure or counterclockwise to decrease pressure. One eighth turn (one flat) of the sleeve will change oil pressure approximately 3 psi.
Install new preformed packing (4) on sleeve (5) and install valve cover (3) on housing with nuts (1). Tighten and torque 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).
Start engine, stabilize at N2=92.8% (25000 RPM or maximum available, whichever is less) for five minutes and check oil pressure (Ref. Fig. ). Repeat procedure as required.

procedure.title: Engine Oil Pressure Adjustment (Alternate Method) (Ref. Figs. and )
procedure.warning: WEAR EAR DEFENDERS IF ADJUSTMENTS ARE BEING DONE WITH THE ENGINE RUNNING AT GROUND IDLE.
procedure.caution: DO NOT ADJUST OIL PRESSURE TO COMPENSATE FOR UNRESOLVED OIL SYSTEM PROBLEMS (REF. 72-00-00, FAULT ISOLATION). THIS COULD CAUSE MOP TO BE OUT OF SPECIFIED LIMITS AND CAUSE DAMAGE TO OIL SYSTEM COMPONENTS.
procedure.step: If necessary, adjust oil pressure as follows: Shutdown the engine. Remove nuts (1), bolts (2). Remove cover (3) with puller (PWC43172). Remove and discard preformed packing (4). Install new preformed packing (4) on cover (6). Install pressure adjustment (PWC60457) (3, Fig. ) and secure with nuts (1, Fig. ) and bolts (2). Tighten and torque bolts 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm). Adjust the oil pressure by turning the sleeve (5) clockwise to increase pressure or counter-clockwise to decrease pressure. One eight turn (one flat) of the sleeve will change oil pressure approximately 3 psi. Start the engine. Run the engine at target speed N2=92.8% (25000 rpm or maximum allowable, whichever is less) for five minutes and/or until the oil temperature stabilizes, then check the oil pressure (Ref. Fig. ). Repeat procedure as required. Remove nuts (1) and bolts (2). Remove pressure adjustment (PWC60457) (3, Fig. ) without changing the settings. Remove and discard preformed packing (4, Fig. ). Install new preformed packing (4) on cover (6). Install valve cover (3), secure with nuts (1) and bolts (2). Torque bolts 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).

procedure.title: VIGV Actuator Rigging
procedure.step: Refer to Chapter 75-30-04.

n-para.title: In-situ Fan Trim Balancing - TEC Model 4040 Viper Analyzer

subpara.title: General
subpara.para: Current engine balancing procedures, carried out during engine build, includes a requirement to trim balance the complete LP compressor assembly during engine test. This is achieved by the installation of counterweights to the specific position in the fan hub assembly. Similarly, for field replacement of the fan assembly, trim balancing of the fan assembly may be necessary if a high vibration indication is noted.

The operator must be familiar with the TEC Model 4040 Viper Analyzer, P/N 10-100-4040 before performing these operations. Do a transient vibration survey and fan trim balance operation with the following procedures and the Viper Operator's Manual.
Refer to FAULT ISOLATION 1 - OPERATING section of this manual to determine when engine in-situ trim balance should be done.

Required equipment, including the optional TEC Model 4040 Viper Notebook Cable - P/N 10-320-0157, found in the Fixtures, Equipment and Supplier Tools List at the front of this section have been approved for use in determining position and mass of trim balance weight. Other equipment may be approved on a case by case basis.

When using the TEC Model 4040 Viper Analyzer two different installation will be required:
Initial and Final Vibration Survey (Ref. Fig. )
Fan Trim Balancing (Ref. Fig. )

procedure.title: Installation of Vibration Sensor (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Gain access to top area of the LP compressor case/intermediate case (Flange B) and locate the two adjacent nuts at 12 o’clock position.
Remove two nuts (5) and washers (3) from Flange B location.
Install sensor (1) with mounting bracket (PWC43442) (2) with two washers (3) and two nuts (5).
Torque nuts 62 to 72 lbf.in (7.1 - 8.1 Nm).

KEEP VELOCITY CABLE AWAY FROM HOT BLEED AIR AND OIL LINES.Install high temperature cable P/N 10-320-0008 connector to vibration sensor P/N 69-100-0016. Torque connector 50 to 60 lbf.in. (5.7 - 6.7 Nm). Connect the other end of the cable to converter box P/N 10-100-1500.
Connect the vibration sensor cable P/N 10-320-0131 to the other receptacle of the converter box and connect the other end of the cable to the VELOCITY receptacle of the Aces Analyzer.

procedure.title: Installation of Optical Tachometer Probe (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Remove P1/T1 probe from it is mounting point in the inlet cowl and secure to the cowling area.
Install optical tachometer probe P/N 10-100-1773 or P/N 10-100-1300 with bracket P/N 22-430-0058 or P/N 10-100-0196 respectively, on the P1/T1 probe mounting point.

FASTEN CABLE TO AIRFRAME TO AVOID ENGINE INGESTION AND HOT AIR AND OIL LINES.Connect tachometer probe cable P/N 10-320-0126 to the optical probe and the other end to the receptacle marked ‘PHOTO’ on the speed unit P/N 10-100-0485.

procedure.title: Initial and Final Vibration Survey Installation (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: Vibration Survey Installation with Cable 10-320-0413 - TEC Model 4040 Viper Analyzer
Fan Trim Balancing Installation with Cable 10-320-0413 - TEC Model 4040 Viper Analyzer

procedure.step: Install the vibration sensor (Ref. Para. ).
Install the charge converter box 10-100-0574 with cables 10-320-0431 and 10-320-0008.
Locate the maintenance plate containing the left and right engine maintenance receptacles (Ref. AMM).
Install the G200/IAI interface cable 10-320-0413 and connect to the maintenance connector for the engine under test.
Connect the N1 and N2 cables of the G200/IAI interface cable to the TACH 1 and TACH 2 receptacles, respectively, of the TEC Model 4040 Viper Analyzer, P/N 10-100-4040.
Connect the vibration cable P/N 10-320-0431 to the CHANNEL A receptacle of the TEC Model 4040 Viper Analyzer, P/N 10-100-4040.

procedure.title: Installation of Reflective Tape on Inlet Cone (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: Installation of Reflective Tape on Nose Cone

procedure.note: Installation of reflective tape is required only for fan trim balancing and It is not required for vibration survey.
procedure.step: MATERIAL OF FAN ASSEMBLY IS TITANIUM. HANDLE WITH EXTREME CARE USING CLEAN, LINT-FREE GLOVES.Locate the fan blade marked in line with the ‘V’ mark on the inlet cone. Mark a line on the blade platform with an approved silver pencil (PWC05-018).

CLEANED AREA MUST BE IN LINE WITH THE ‘V’ MARK AND DIRECTLY IN PASSING VIEW OF THE OPTICAL PROBE AS THE FAN ASSEMBLY ROTATES.Clean the area of the inlet cone where the tape is to be attached, with acetone (PWC11-012).

POSITION THE REFLECTIVE TAPE SO THE LEADING EDGE OF THE TAPE IS RELATIVE TO THE OPTICAL PROBE, TO MAKE SURE THAT THE ARRANGEMENT TRIGGERS THE TACHOMETER LED.Install a two inch piece of reflective tape (PWC05-238) one inch wide, or two one-half inch wide pieces on the cleaned area fan inlet cone.
Apply a light coat of locking and retaining compound (PWC09-002) around the edges of the tape, and between the two pieces.
Supply power to the analyzer and check that the tachometer triggers when the No. 1 blade is at the 12 o’clock position.

procedure.title: Vibration Survey (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.caution: DO NOT EXCEED ANY ENGINE OPERATING LIMIT WHEN TRIM BALANCING (REF. Chapter 05-10-00, OPERATING LIMITS AND LEADING PARTICULARS). IF ANY N1 SETTING WILL CAUSE THE ENGINE TO EXCEED AN OPERATING LIMIT, OMIT THAT SETTING.
procedure.step: Make sure that the Transient Vibration Survey option is installed in the Viper Analyzer. Detailed instructions are available at the TEC ACES Systems website.

Install the P&WC Transient Vibration Survey setup file in the TEC Model 4040 Viper Analyzer. Switch the power on and load the procedure into the ACES Analyzer. Make sure that the battery charge indication is more than 80%.

Determine engine maximum N1% RPM for local pressure altitude and ambient temperature from the Aircraft Flight Manual. Obtain aircraft and engine information before start of the test. i.e. aircraft registration number, aircraft hours, engine serial number, hours and cycles.

Verify and install if required application software 3.05Q and PWC OW setup version 2.72 or greater in the Viper Analyzer. To install this software use notebook computer 10-320-0157, USB cable 10-320-0483, and Avtrend software 10-700-0103. Detailed instructions are available at the TEC ACES Systems. website: www.acessystems.com/manuals.htm

MAKE SURE THE INFORMATION ON THE VIPER ANALYZER SCREEN IS CORRECT BEFORE PRESSING ENTER.At the "Main" menu, select the Transient Vibration Survey option with the cursor up/down arrow keys and press ENTER.
At the Transient "Vibration Survey" menu, select Start Job with the up/down arrow keys and press ENTER.
At the "Set-up List" menu, select PW306A OW with the up/down arrow keys and press ENTER. The screen will display "Loading....Please Wait".

At the "Job Identification" menu, type in the name of the Customer and Aircraft Serial number with the keypad and press the cursor down key. You can press the F1 “Names” key to select the name from a list if it has previously been used in this analyzer and press ENTER.
Enter the A/C (Aircraft) Registration number with the keypad and press the down arrow key.
Enter the A/C (Aircraft) Total time in hours with the keypad and press ENTER.
At the "Engine Information" menu, select "POSITION 1" for all tests.
Skip over the first section identified as propeller by pressing the cursor down key until the Engine section is reached.

Enter the engine S/N with the keypad or press the F1 "Serial Nos" key to select it from a list if it has previously been used in the analyzer. Press the down arrow key to move the cursor into the "Type" field, then with the keypad enter the text 306A. Press the down arrow key to move the cursor to the "TSO" field and then with the keypad, enter the engine hours since overhaul. Press the down arrow key to move the cursor to the "TSN" field and then with the keypad, enter the engine hours since new. Then press ENTER. There will be a 5-8 second pause while the analyzer initializes the data acquisition application. The screen will display "Perform FOD check, start the engine, and establish normal operating conditions".

Start the engine, let engine stabilize and engine oil temperature reach a minimum of 125°F (51°C). If required, run the engine at a higher idle speed to warm the engine oil, then return the power lever to idle.
When the engine is warmed up and you are ready to begin the survey, press ENTER.
There will be a 10 second delay while the analyzer prepares the Database manager and recovers database memory. When the overall vibration display starts, the analyzer will be recording data.

The Viper screen will display the overall vibration data on the screen, which consists of the following table.
Overall Vibration Data
CurrentMaximumUnits
Plane 1n.nnn.nnIPS
N1nnnnn.nnnnnnn.nnIPS
N2nnnnn.nnnnnnn.nnIPS

Accelerate engine from idle to target N1 speed identified in item (1), sweep time approximately 120-180 seconds (between 2 and 3 minutes). When target N1 is achieved, press ENTER to stop data acquisition. Record Max N1, N2 and ITT values. If N1 target is exceeded by more than 1.5% notify PWC field representative.
The Viper analyzer will display the message “Store the Data?”. Press the F1 key to answer Yes and save the data, or F5 to answer No if the run is to be deleted.
Decelerate the engine to idle.
Press F5 to continue.
Select the "Manage Job" menu with the upper/lower cursor keys and press ENTER.

Select "Review" with the upper/lower cursor keys and press ENTER. The screen will display the surveys that are available. Locate the correct survey with the upper/lower cursor keys and press ENTER. The screen will display the jobs that are available.

At the "Select Item To Review" menu, select View EN1 vs N1 Vibration with the upper/lower cursor keys and press ENTER. The screen will display the fan vibration plot (Ref. Fig. ). The plot indicates the peak level at the corresponding N1 speed.

Use the Right and Left arrow keys as necessary to locate the highest amplitude peak on the plot. The X (speed) and Y (amplitude) values are displayed in the upper right corner of the analyzer screen. Record the peak amplitude (Y) and RPM (X) value (e.g.: Peak = 0.13@5574.8).
Shut down the engine.
View all the plots from the menu. Transfer the analyzer data to the AvTrend software to print the plots.
Return to "Main" menu by pressing the BACKUP key.

procedure.title: Fan Trim Balancing Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Remove the inlet cone (Ref. 72-30-01).
Record the location of the counterweights on the front balancing rim in the Fan Trim Balancing Data Worksheet (Ref. Fig. ).
Install the inlet cone (Ref. 72-30-01).
Install the optical probe (Ref. Para. ).

Disconnect the N1 speed probe connector from the TEC Model 4040 Viper Analyzer and connect the tacho cable 10-320-0126 connector to the appropriate receptacle of the TEC Model 4040 Viper Analyzer for the N1 speed signal (Ref. Fig. ).
Install reflecting tape on the nose cone (Ref. Para. ).
Power on the Viper analyzer.
At the Main menu, select "Fan/Turbine Balance" with the upper/lower cursor keys and press ENTER.
Select "Start Job" with the upper/lower cursor keys and press ENTER.
At the "Set-up List", select PW306A OW Fan with the upper/lower cursor keys and press ENTER.
At the "Customer Information" menu, type in Customer Name, Aircraft Registration Number and Aircraft Total Time then press ENTER.
At the "Engine Information" menu, select "POSITION 1", then use the upper/lower curser keys to move to "ENGINE".
At the "Engine S/N" field, input "CCXXXX" and press DOWN ARROW KEY.
Input the engine type, time since overhaul (TSO) and time since new (TSN) with the keypad keys and press ENTER.

At the Label Detail Weight Holes menu, input the location of the detail balance weights. Use the up/down cursor keys to select the hole numbers then change the selected hole(s) to an "X" with the right cursor keys. When done, press ENTER.

At the Fan/Turbine Balance Speeds menu, enter the peak vibration speed from the vibration survey and press ENTER. Start the engine. Let the engine stabilize and oil temperature reach 125°F (51°C) minimum. Press ENTER. The VIPER Analyzer will prompt Fan/Turbine Balance Setup as a reminder to verify unit connections. Press ENTER to continue.
The VIPER Analyzer will display CURRENT RPM VALUE. Press ENTER.

DO NOT EXCEED ENGINE OPERATING LIMITS (REF. Chapter 05-10-00, OPERATING LIMITS AND LEADING PARTICULARS). MAINTENANCE MANUAL ENGINE OPERATING LIMITS SUPERSEDE ANY INSTRUCTIONS IN THE VIPER ANALYZER PROCEDURE.The VIPER Analyzer will display "Set eng #1 RPM to: XXXX", the peak vibration N1 speed minus 500. Bring the engine to this speed and press ENTER. At the next display, allow 10 to 15 seconds for the phase and amplitude to stabilize, then press ENTER to accept the measuring point. Repeat the procedure for the following N1 rpm settings.
SPEED 1 = RPM = (PEAK -500 RPM)
SPEED 2 = RPM = (PEAK -250 RPM)
SPEED 3 = RPM = (PEAK)
SPEED 4 = RPM = (PEAK +250 RPM)
SPEED 5 = RPM = (PEAK +500 RPM)
Return the engine to idle speed.
At the "Review Prior Run Data" menu, review data taken and press ENTER.
Shut down the engine and wait as necessary for the optimization of weights to be completed. Press F5 to continue.
Record the position of the counterweight and hole defined by the VIPER Analyzer.

procedure.title: Trial Weight Trim Balance Run
procedure.step: Review the trim balance mass and location solution defined by Viper analyzer in the two left columns labeled "Hole Suggested". Trim balance counterweight rivet hole locations are counted counterclockwise from the inlet cone index 'V' mark.

Install trial counterweight as follows: Remove inlet cone (Ref. 72-30-01). Record the class and location of the existing counterweights on the fan front balancing rim. This information is required if the solution counterweight location given by the analyzer is occupied by an existing counterweight, and a split weight option is required. The trim balance counterweight mass and position defined by the Viper analyzer is called the solution. Install class of counterweight closest to trial solution defined by analyzer at indicated fan balance location (Ref. Para. - Rivet and Counterweight). Do not install a trial weight heavier than required. Classes are listed in the Table below:
Class Ref. Weight Including Rivet (grams)
CL12.18
CL22.68
CL33.16
CL43.63
CL54.21
CL65.36
At the FAN INSTALLED WEIGHTS menu, press ENTER only if the trial counterweight is installed in the positions defined by the analyzer. If the trim counterweight is installed in a hole other than the defined hole, change the class and location on the Viper analyzer with the cursor keys. Record this information and press ENTER to continue. Install the inlet cone (Ref. 72-30-01).

Perform a trial counterweight run as follows: Start the engine. Let the engine stabilize and oil temperature reach 51°C (125°F) minimum. Repeat the fan balance run (Procedure ) and check the new vibration level. The Viper analyzer will provide the solution counterweight and angle. The analyzer calculates final or successive solutions based on previous trial trim weight having been removed. Return the engine to idle speed. Shut down the engine.
If vibration level is within acceptable limits, end the balancing procedure.
If vibration level is not acceptable, record the new counterweight size and location calculated by analyzer.

Remove first trial weight and install solution counterweight (Ref. Para. - Rivet and Counterweight): The analyzer calculates final or successive solutions based on previous trial counterweight having been removed. Unbalance is corrected by using a maximum of four fan trim counterweights. Existing fan trim counterweights may be replaced, as required. The weights used for detail balancing must not be replaced. Maximum of four trim counterweights and four detail counterweights can be added to the front balancing rim.
When engine vibration is within acceptable limits, record the counterweight(s) mass and position(s), with respect to fan hub V-mark, in the engine log book.
Remove the test equipment and return the engine to normal operating condition.

procedure.title: Removal of Rivet and Counterweight - 25058 (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Remove the inlet cone (Ref. 72-30-01).
Find the counterweight (6) and rivet (5) to be removed from balancing result.

DO NOT DAMAGE FAN BALANCING ASSEMBLY WHEN REMOVING RIVETS.Remove rivet (5) and counterweight (6) with suitable chisel (PWC66645) and punch (PWC60614) or (PWC38297-101 and PWC38297-102). Remove the flared end of the rivet with the chisel.
Check the hub (2) areas for metal particles and clean as necessary with alcohol (PWC11-014) and dry.

procedure.title: Installation of Rivet and Counterweight - 25058 (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Find the location of the counterweight (6) and rivet (5) in the balance rim (4) as specified from the balancing result.

FOR 25058 HUB WITH FRONT RETAINING RING, ALL RIVETS (MANUFACTURED HEADS) TO BE POSITIONED ON THE INSIDE DIAMETER OF THE HUB.Install and flare the rivets (5) without the counterweights (6) with riveter (PWC43238) and rivet set (PWC43239) and (PWC43240).
Install and flare the rivets (5) with the counterweights (6) with riveter (PWC43238) and rivet set (PWC60085) and (PWC43240).

procedure.title: Removal of Rivet and Counterweight - 25058 (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: Always remove and install the rivet and counterweight with the split of the retaining ring and rivet location at 6 o'clock position.
procedure.step: Remove the inlet cone (Ref. 72-30-01).

REMOVAL OF THE INLET CONE ALLOWS THE 22 BLADES TO MOVE FORWARD. MAKE SURE BLADES DO NOT DISENGAGE FROM THE FAN HUB WHEN REMOVING THE CONE ASSEMBLY. INSTALL THE RETAINING RING.After removing the inlet cone install the split retaining ring (PWC62019) (8) and secure by tightening holding screw. Always position the split of the retaining ring at the 6 o'clock position. Blade at 6 o'clock position in line with the split cannot slide forward and disengage by itself. At other positions blade could slide forward more so at the 12 o'clock position because the blade slot on the hub slopes downward.
Install the fan hub protector (4) (PWC62002) on the hub (2) and secure with the inlet cone bolt (3). Torque handtight only.

Close the gap between the bigger outer diameter of the protector (PWC62002) and the hub using a duct tape. This will prevent the ground metal powder from going into and damaging the hub inner diameter.

Find the rivet (7) and counterweight (5) to be removed. Loosen the split retaining ring (8) holding screw and hold the ring in place with one hand while turning the fan hub assembly with the other until the rivet/weight is at 6 o'clock position in line with the split of the ring.
Tighten the split retaining ring (8) holding screw.

Install the fan wedge tool (PWC66581) in between the fan blade tip and the fan case. This will prevent the fan assembly from rotating during the removal and installation of the rivet and counterweight.

USE EXTREME CARE NOT TO DAMAGE HUB AREAS AND THE FAN BALANCING ASSEMBLY DURING THE GRINDING OF THE RIVETS.Carefully grind the flared side of the rivet (7) using rivet cutter/grinder (PWC62005) - the flared side is on the inside hub diameter where the weight is installed).
The rivet (7) should come out easily. If the rivet does not come off, use pusher (PWC62004) to remove the rivet.
Remove all ground metal powder from the hub.
For removing another rivet/weight repeat steps to .
Remove the inlet cone bolt (3) and the fan hub protector (PWC62002).
Check the inside hub areas for metal particles and clean as necessary.

procedure.title: Installation of Rivet and Counterweight - 25058 (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: Always remove and install the rivet and counterweight with the split of the retaining ring and rivet location at 6 o'clock position.
procedure.step: Clean the hub (2) with alcohol (PWC11-014) and dry.
Make sure the split retaining ring (PWC62019) (8) is installed.

Find the location rivet (7) and counterweight (5) to be install as specified in the balancing result. Loosen the split retaining ring holding screw and hold the ring in place with one hand while turning the fan hub assembly (2) until the rivet/weight is at 6 o'clock position in line with the split of the ring.
Tighten the split retaining ring holding screw.

USE EXTREME CARE NOT TO DAMAGE HUB AREAS AND THE FAN BALANCING ASSEMBLY DURING THE INSTALLING OF THE RIVETS.Position the counterweight from the inside diameter of the hub rim at the location specified in the balancing results.
ALL RIVET HEADS MUST BE POSITIONED ON THE OUTSIDE DIAMETER OF THE HUB BALANCING RIM.Secure counterweight with rivet. Flare rivet using riveter (PWC62003).
For installing other rivet (7) and counterweight (5), repeat steps to .
Remove the fan wedge tool (PWC66581).
Carefully remove the split retaining ring (PWC62019) (8). Make sure blades do not slide forward and disengage from the hub.
Install inlet cone (Ref. 72-30-01).

general.para: Engine cleaning is basically confined to compressor desalination or performance recovery washes. However, an external wash is recommended whenever the engine is contaminated with salt. Refer to Chapter 05-20-00 for wash schedule.

To perform a compressor wash, the engine is motored using the starter and wash fluids are sprayed through the fan at a high flow (10 gal/min, 37.8 liters/min) using a suitable spray wand with a nozzle angled to ensure cleaning fluid enters the engine core.

Motoring washes are carried out at an N2 of 8 to 25% and the water or cleaning mixture, which is pressurized at 60 psi (414 kPa) is sprayed into the compressor inlet via the high flow wash wand. Washing while motoring the engine ensures that the cleaning mixture remains in liquid form.
To perform a turbine wash the engine is dry motored and wash fluid is sprayed through a nozzle installed in one of the igniters mount openings.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.
Refer to INTRODUCTION for alternate products, suppliers and suppliers addresses.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

procedure.title: Procedure
procedure.step: DO NOT USE GASOLINE OR SIMILAR FLUIDS OR SOLVENTS FOR EXTERNAL ENGINE CLEANING. DO NOT CLEAN AN ENGINE THAT IS OPERATING OR IS STILL HOT FOLLOWING OPERATION. ALLOW THE ENGINE TO COOL FOR A MINIMUM PERIOD OF 40 MINUTES AFTER SHUTDOWN TO AVOID THE PRECIPITATION OF SALTS OR OTHER SOLIDS IN THE EVENT OF INADVERTENT USE OF HARD WATER.Fresh water external cleaning is recommended when engine is contaminated with salt, volcanic dust or corrosive chemicals such as those found in industrial smog. Demineralized/distilled water is not necessary. The engine must never be left in a contaminated condition overnight, or longer.

If water wash is ineffective, a petroleum solvent (PWC11-027) /water emulsion may be used to remove oil, grime, or other materials/fluids (e.g. Hydraulic fluids). Thoroughly rinse with water to remove all traces of cleaning fluid. Completely dry the engine using clean, dry compressed air. External cleaning is very effective in tracing possible origin of external oil leakage.

procedure.title: General
procedure.step: Washing removes salt, dirt and other baked-on deposits that accumulate in the gas path and cause engine performance deterioration.

A compressor/turbine desalination wash uses water or water/methanol (PWC11-010) (Ref. Table or Fig. ) to remove salt and light deposits. The addition of cleaning agents is not recommended. Figure introduces an alternate method to determine the methanol requirement when mixing a desalination/rinse solution for use at temperatures below 0°C (32°F).
A rinse wash uses the same solution (according to temperature) as the desalination wash (Ref. Table ) and is used after a performance recovery wash to clean the gas path.
A performance recovery wash uses cleaning agents (Ref. Tables , , and ) in the wash solution to remove deposits that cannot be dissolved by a desalination wash.
The formula of the P&WC developed performance recovery solution WCT is shown in Table .
Depending upon the operating environment, the nature and frequency of washing are recommended to be in accordance with Chapter 05-20-00.

figure.title: Desalination/Rinse Solution - Determining Methanol Requirement at Temperatures Below 32°F (0°C)

procedure.title: Preparation of Equipment (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Set up engine wash rig (PWC32677-300) as shown on schematic (Ref. Fig.).
Check that the air or nitrogen pressure supply connected to the wash rig is adjusted to 50 psig.

Verify the availability and condition of the wash nozzle assembly (PWC61152) or the Wash Wand. The Wash Wand is a locally designed and fabricated spray nozzle or wand used to inject wash fluids. Fan Blade wedges (PWC66581) are used to immobilize the fan. The Wash Wand must be designed and fabricated to deliver the recommended amount of fluid (19 liters or 5 US gallons), at the recommended pressure (50 psi or 345 Kpa), in the recommended time (20 to 30 seconds) to the core of the engine. The Wash Wand is a hand held tool and should be designed to direct the fluid stream into the core of the engine while keeping operating personnel at a safe distance from any rotating parts or splash back and should not present any risk of coming into contact with rotating parts or of parts liberating and being ingested by the engine.

procedure.title: Preparation of Cleaning Solutions
procedure.step: Prepare a 5 US Gal. or (10 US Gal. in case of performance recovery) of desalination/rinse solution based on the Outside Air temparature (OAT) of the day in accordance to Table . Use demineralized/distilled water or drinking water quality specified below.

Get a supply of demineralized/distilled water which obeys the criteria that follows: Appearance: Free of suspended solids. Total solids: 10 ppm (mg/1) maximum. Specific conductance: 11 Microohms/cm maximum. Silica content: 3 ppm (mg/1) maximum. Ph: 5.0 + 7.5 inclusive. Intake filter must not be coarser than 10-microns.

Get a supply of drinking quality water complying with the following criteria: Appearance: free of suspended solids. Total solids: 175 ppm (mg/1) maximum. Ph: 6.0 to 8.0 inclusive. Chlorides: 15 ppm (mg/1) maximum. Sulphates: 10 ppm (mg/1) maximum.

Depending on the prevailing outside air temperature (OAT), prepare a 5 US Gal. of performance recovery solution as per Tables , , and using one of the following cleaning agents:
Desalination/Performance Recovery Solutions

°F °C% by Vol. % by Vol. % by Vol. % by Vol.

-13 to +36 -25 to +225 15 20 40
Below -13 Below -2525 15 40 20

B & B 3100 25% by Vol = 1250 ml in 5 liters (1.33 US gal.)
Fuel 15% by Vol = 750 ml
Methanol 20% by Vol = 1000 ml
Water 40% by Vol = 2000 ml
Total 100% by Vol = 5000 ml or 5 liters (1.33 US gal.)
ADD 150 ml OF WITCONATE EMULSIFYING AGENT (PWC05-005) AND MIX SOLUTION THOROUGHLY BEFORE USE TO PREVENT FUEL SEPARATION.
Approved solutions for Table are:
CLIX (PWC11-001)

Magnus 1214 (PWC11-001B)

ADD 150 ML OF WITCONATE EMULSIFYING AGENT (PWC05-005) AND MIX SOLUTION THOROUGHLY BEFORE USE TO PREVENT FUEL SEPARATION.
Approved Recovery Solutions for Table are:
Turco 4217 (PWC11-001F) (concentrate)
Ardrox 624 (PWC11-001H) (concentrate)
The above table results in 5 liters of power recovery solution. Multiply the 5 liters by approximately 4 to obtain 5 U.S. gallons.

Approved Biodegradable Solutions for Table are:
Ardrox 6345 (PWC11-003)
R-MC-G21 (PWC11-003A)
Ardrox 6367 (PWC11-003B) previously identified as Turboclean 2
Ardrox 6368 (PWC11-003C), previously identified as Turboclean 2 RTU, is a Ready To Use solution of 6367 mixed with water as recommended in Table for ambient temperatures above 36°F (2°C). Do not further dilute solution by adding water.
ZOK27 (PWC11-003D)
B & B TC100 (PWC11-003E)
Ardrox 6373 (PWC11-066) identified as Turboclean 2 RTU-W, is a Ready To Use - Winterized solution of 6367 mixed with water and methanol for ambient temperatures below -13°F ( -25 °C). Do not further dilute solution by adding water and/or methanol.

procedure.title: Engine Preparation (Ref. Figs. and )

figure.title: Preparation Of Engine For Compressor Wash

procedure.step: Remove cap assembly (2) from Pt air tube assembly (1).
Remove cap assembly (4) from P3 air tube assembly (3).
Cover two P1/T1 probes in the engine inlet case with suitable waterproof protectors to prevent water from entering the probes.
Disconnect and cap the P2.5 and P3 engine cabin bleed ports, on the aircraft side of the engine (Ref. 71-00-00, POWERPLANT - ADJUSTMENT/TEST).
Make sure throttle is in “CUT-OFF” position.
Make sure ignition system is in the OFF position.
Make sure aircraft bleed system is shut-off.
Set the engine anti-ice switch to “ON” position to prevent the compressor wash fluid from entering the valve piston.

Install compressor wash nozzle assembly (PWC61152) (6, Fig. ) into the engine inlet as follows:
LET A HOT ENGINE COOL FOR 30 MINUTES MINIMUM BEFORE DOING A COMPRESSOR WASH.Remove one P1/TI probe from the intake case mounting holes and cover the other probe with suitable waterproof protectors to avoid the ingestion of water in the probes. Push the compressor wash nozzle (6) until the three pads (3) touch into the inlet cone. Extend locking rod (1) through the hole vacated by the removal of the P1/T1 probe. Make sure the flat face of each of the four spray nozzles is tangent to the fan hub and target spray into the core of the engine.
DO NOT TIGHTEN THE SUPPORT RODS OF SPRAY NOZZLE TOO MUCH OR DAMAGE TO THE INLET OR FAN CASE MAY OCCUR.Extend the three threaded support rods (4) while keeping the support pads (3) in contact with the inlet cone. Tighten the rods with your hand. Extend and secure the fan lock rod (2) to touch one of the fan blade leading edge and hold the fan assembly from rotating during the motoring cycle.
MAKE SURE THE COMPRESSOR WASH NOZZLE ASSEMBLY (PWC61152) (6) IS SECURELY INSTALLED IN THE INLET CASE.Connect the engine wash rig (PWC32677-300) to the compressor wash nozzle assembly (PWC61152) (6).

Set up for washing operations using alternate tooling, the Wash Wand (described in Subpara. ) and the fan blade wedges (PWC66581) as follows:
CARE IN INSTALLING THE WEDGES SHOULD BE TAKEN TO AVOID DAMAGE TO THE ABRADABLE LINER.Position the four fan blade wedges (PWC66581) securely between the fan blade tips and the fan case to prevent the fan's normal rotation. Cover both P1/T1 probes with suitable waterproof protectors to avoid the ingestion of water in the probes. Connect the wash rig hose to the Wash Wand. Hold the Wash Wand to direct the fluid stream into the core of the engine.

procedure.title: Fan Washing
procedure.warning: BEFORE WASHING FAN, MAKE SURE STARTER SWITCH AND IGNITION SYSTEM ARE IN THE OFF POSITION AND TLA IS IN CUT OFF POSITION.
WHEN WASHING THE FAN BY HAND WEAR CLEAN COTTON GLOVES AND USE CAUTION BECAUSE THE LEADING EDGE OF FAN BLADES MIGHT BE SHARP.
procedure.step: Fan blade washing is best accomplished by hand using a sponge or soft clean cloth. Each blade must be washed individually on both pressure and suction side.

procedure.title: Compressor Washing (Desalination or Performance Recovery)
procedure.step: BEFORE MOTORING ENGINE, MAKE SURE ENGINE INTAKE IS CLEAR OF ALL LOOSE OBJECTS WHICH MAY BE INGESTED AND CAUSE ENGINE DAMAGE AND SUBSEQUENT FAILURE. OBSERVE STARTER MANUFACTURER'S LIMITS DURING MOTORING (REF. STARTER MANUFACTURER'S MANUAL).Install compressor wash nozzle assembly (PWC61152) and connect to the engine wash rig (PWC32677-300). Check installation per Subpara.
Check the air or nitrogen pressure supply connected to the wash rig is adjusted to 50 psig.

LET STARTER COOL BETWEEN RUNS (REF. STARTER MANUFACTURER'S MANUAL). MAKE SURE ITT/T45 IS NOT MORE THAN 65°C (150°F) BEFORE DOING A COMPRESSOR WASH.Do a 30 second dry motoring run. When N2 reaches 5% during acceleration, start injecting wash fluid. Stop wash fluid injection when N2 drops below 5%. If the wash rig is correctly adjusted, 5 US Gal. of wash fluid will be used for each motoring run. This is not required when a desalination wash is done.
Allow cleaning solution to soak for 30 minutes.

Accomplish two 30 seconds dry motoring run, one after the other, and start injecting rinse solution when N2 reaches 5%. Stop wash fluid injection when N2 drops below 5%. If the wash rig is correctly adjusted, 5 US Gal. of wash fluid will be used for each motoring run. Only one motoring run is required for desalination wash.
Disconnect wash rig (PWC32677-300) and remove compressor wash nozzle assembly (PWC61152).

procedure.title: Post Compressor Washing (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: LET STARTER COOL BETWEEN RUNS (REF. STARTER MANUFACTURER'S MANUAL).Do a 30 seconds dry motoring run (Ref. Adjustment/Test).
Install cap (4) on Pt air tube (3). Torque cap 90 to 100 lb.in. (10.0-11.0 Nm) and lockwire (PWC05-089).
Install cap (2) on P3 tube (1). Torque cap 270 to 300 lb.in. (30.0-34.0 Nm) and lockwire (PWC05-089).
Install P1/T1 probe and remove protective covers from P1/T1 sensors in fan case.
Remove all bleed port caps. Allow sufficient time for wash solution to drain.
Reconnect P2.5 and P3 cabin bleed ports.
MAKE SURE ALL COWLS ARE CLOSED.Do an engine start and run for 3 minutes at GROUND IDLE with CABIN BLEED OFF (Ref. Adjustment/Test).
Shutdown engine.

procedure.title: Turbine Washing
procedure.step: Remove one igniter plug and install turbine wash nozzle (PWC60708).
Connect engine wash rig (PWC32677-300) to the spray nozzle and adjust air or nitrogen to 50 psig pressure (414 kPa).

ALLOW ENGINE TO COOL FOR A PERIOD OF 30 MINUTES PRIOR TO CARRYING OUT A TURBINE WASH. BEFORE MOTORING ENGINE, ENSURE ENGINE INTAKE IS CLEAR OF ALL LOOSE OBJECTS WHICH MAY BE INGESTED AND CAUSE ENGINE DAMAGE AND SUBSEQUENT FAILURE. OBSERVE STARTER MANUFACTURER'S LIMITS DURING MOTORING (REF. STARTER MANUFACTURER'S MANUAL). Do two 30 seconds dry motoring runs, one after the other, while injecting five gallons of wash fluid (Ref. Table ) at a prescribed rate of 10 gallons per minute.
Remove turbine wash nozzle (PWC60708) and install igniter plug (Ref. 74-10-01).
Do a 30 seconds dry motoring run.
Perform 5 min. engine ground run at ground idle.

n-para.title: Engine (Ref. Figs. through )
n-para.para: The PW306A Engine is a two-spool, turbofan engine, featuring a full-length annular bypass duct. A concentric shaft system supports the high and low pressure rotors. The inner shaft supports the low pressure (LP) compressor (fan) and is driven by a three-stage turbine at the rear. The outer shaft is mechanically independent of the LP shaft and supports the four axial stages and one centrifugal stage of the high pressure (HP) compressor, and is driven by a two-stage turbine supported at the rear.

Air enters the engine through the fan case, is accelerated rearwards by the fan and is split into bypass and core flow streams through concentric dividing ducts. The bypass air passes through a single stage of stators and a faired bypass duct before exiting with the core flow through a common mixing nozzle.

The core airflow passes through variable inlet guide vanes and first-stage variable stator vanes, which allow optimum airflow into the HP compressor. Both sets of vanes are hydraulically actuated by fuel pressure from the hydro-mechanical unit, as commanded by the electronic engine control. From the HP compressor, core airflow is passed through 24 diffuser tubes, which convert velocity to static pressure. The diffused air then passes to the annulus surrounding the combustion chamber liner.
The combustion chamber liner consists of an annular straight-through assembly, with multi-holed patterns for air mixing and dilution with the combustion gases.

The air enters the combustion chamber liner and mixes with fuel. Fuel is injected into the combustion chamber by 24 air blast nozzles supplied by a single-tube manifold. Two of the nozzles are a hybrid-type, having an additional fuel supply line of lower pressure, to provide a separate primary fuel flow for ease of starting. During starting, the mixture is ignited by two spark igniters which protrude into the combustion chamber liner.

The resultant gases expand from the combustion chamber liner and pass through the first-stage HP turbine stator to the first-stage HP turbine. The first-stage HP vanes and rotor blades are cooled by air flowing through internally cast passages. The still expanding gases pass rearward to the cooled second-stage HP vanes and turbine, then to the three-stage LP turbine and associated stator vanes, then to atmosphere through the exhaust duct, subsequently mixing with the bypass flow.
PW306A Engine - Three-quarter View (Right Side)
PW306A Engine - Three-quarter View (Left Side)
PW306A Engine - Bottom View

All engine driven accessories (Ref. Table ), with the exception of the N1 LP rotor speed sensor, are on the accessory gearbox secured to the bottom of the intermediate case.The accessories are driven by a tower driveshaft geared to the HP rotor shaft (N2), passing downward through the intermediate casing to mesh with a bevel gear in the accessory gearbox. The N2 speed sensors located on the right side of the accessory gearbox are of an electromagnetic pulse type. A spur gear on the alternator gearshaft passes over the probes, creating an impulse which is transmitted to the EEC. The N1 speed sensors are mounted in the aft end of the engine, in the exhaust case. The operation of the N1 probes is the same as the N2 probes, and transmits signals to the EEC.
The engine oil tank is integral with the intermediate case and is located between the core and bypass flow passages.

procedure.title: Use of Approved Fuels
procedure.step: The fuels specified in Table are recommended by P&WC. Airworthiness authorities normally require operators to follow these recommendations unless alternative fuels have been agreed between the operator and P&WC and approval by the operators airworthiness authority.
The fuels recommended have been substantiated by P&WC specifications and are Transport Canada approved.

The fuel properties specified in Table are the minimum requirements that are accepted for use. As these properties only meet minimum engine requirements, the list is not intended for use as a purchase specification for procurement of fuel for P&WC commercial engines. Rather, it is intended to allow operators to include minimum approved fuel requirements for P&WC engines in conjunction with other functional requirements when formulating their own procurement specification or judging the acceptability of fuels manufactured to other national specifications that exist throughout the world.
Technical requirement tests shall be performed, in accordance with the latest issue of the listed American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) test methods.

row.entry: 37 (0.84 Kg per l) to 57 (0.75 Kg per l)
Min. 20 mm. plus 3% by volume max.
Max. No. lb. at 212°F (100°C), for 2 hrs

entry.note: Mercaptan Sulfur determination may be omitted provided Doctor Test in accordance with ASTM D4952 is conducted and results are negative.
Only FAME meeting the requirements of ASTM D6751 is acceptable.

procedure.title: High Temperature Stability
procedure.step: The Jet Fuel Thermal Oxidation Tester (JFTOT), ASTM D3241, will be used to test thermal stability. Maximum filter pressure change must be 1.0 inch Hg (25.4 mm Hg) and tube deposit must be less than Code 3 at the following conditions as defined in ASTM D3241: Fuel Pressure: 500 psi (3447.4 kPa). Fuel flow rate: 2.85 US gal/hr (3 ml/min.). Test time: 150 minutes.

procedure.title: Quality
procedure.step: The results from the 500°F (260°C) control temperature test (Ref. Subpara. ), must be reported by the refiner on all fuel analysis reports.

Fuel shall consist solely of hydrocarbon compounds except as otherwise specified herein. It shall be clear and free of undissolved water, sediment, and suspended matter, and shall be suitable for use in aircraft turbine engines.
The odor of the fuel shall not be nauseating or irritating. No substances of known dangerous toxicity under usual conditions of handling and use shall be used.
Fuel that contain dissolved metals is not usable.

procedure.title: Additives
procedure.step: One or a combination of the following oxidation inhibitors may be added to the basic fuel in total concentration not more than 24 mg/l (0.025 g/l) to prevent formation of gum. 2, 4-dimethyl-6-tertiary-butyl phenol. 2, 6-ditertiary-butyl-4-methyl phenol. 2, 6-ditertiary-butyl phenol. 75% min. 2,6-ditertiary-butyl phenol, plus 25% max. mixed tertiary-butyl phenol and tritertiary-butyl phenol. 72% min. 2,4-dimethyl - 6 tertiary butyl phenol, 28% max. monomethyl and dimethyl tertiary butyl phenol. 55% min. 2,4-dimethyl-6-tertiary-butyl phenol, plus 15% min. 2,6-ditertiary-burtyl-4-methyl phenol, 30 % max. mixed methyl and dimethyl tertiary-butyl phenol.

The following additives in addition to the oxidation inhibitors listed above are acceptable for use in engine fuel subject to the limitations stated. Anti-corrosion and lubricity additives in the following tables of this sub-section are described as being primary corrosion inhibitors and secondarily as lubricity improvers, to meet a U.S. Military Specification. In certain cases it is necessary to adjust concentration of such additives to obtain necessary lubricity improvement. Anticorrosion additives and fuel lubricity improver additives The lubricating properties of jet fuels are important for easy movement of the rubbing surfaces such as engine controls, servo valves, pump bearings, gear and piston type pumps. The lubricating properties of fuels can be improved by adding an approved corrosion inhibitor/lubricity improver. Corrosion inhibitor/lubricity improver additives approved for use are those shown on the Qualified Product List QPL 25017 of products qualified under Performance Specification MIL PRG 25017, Inhibitor, Corrosion/Lubricity Improver, Fuel Soluble, within the concentration limits specified. Thermal stability additives (Ref. Table ): JFA-5 is a thermal stability additive, approved for use in engine fuel, at the option of refiner, to make sure that the adequate high temperature stability at time of use. The remaining additives in Table have been shown to improve jet fuel thermal stability, and in some applications to significantly reduce fuel nozzle coking and to improve hot section cleanliness. These additives consist of an antioxidant, a metal deactivator, and a dispersant. They are same to each other, except that turboline FS100 is diluted. Table specifies an approved metal deactivator.
THESE FUEL SYSTEM ANTI-ICING ADDITIVES CONTAIN ETHYLENE GLYCOL MONOETHYL ETHER WHICH IS HIGHLY TOXIC. THESE PRODUCTS MUST BE HANDLED WITH EXTREME CARE. AVOID ALL DIRECT CONTACT WITH SKIN OR CLOTHING. ANY CLOTHING WHICH IS ACCIDENTALLY CONTAMINATED BY SPLASHING SHOULD BE PROMPTLY REMOVED AND THE SKIN WASHED WITH SOAP AND WATER. PREVENT CONTACT WITH EYES AND AVOID INHALATION OF VAPOURS. IF CONTACT IS MADE WITH EYES THEY SHOULD BE FLUSHED WITH WATER FOR 15 MINUTES. CONSULT WITH A PHYSICIAN AS RAPIDLY AS POSSIBLE AFTER ALL CONTACT CASES.Any anti-icing additive which is directly equivalent to those listed in Table is approved. Table specifies approved anti-static additives. Anti-microbial Organisms Additive (Ref. Table ). Airline Operation The following biocide additive may be used on a limited basis. Limited basis is defined as intermittent or non-continuous use in a single application to sterilize aircraft systems suspected or found to be contaminated by microbial organisms, such as fungi, bacteria and yeasts. For those operators, where the need for biocide use is indicated (blocked LP filters), P&WC recommends, as a guide, a dosage interval of once a month. This interval can then be adjusted, either greater or lesser, as the operator's own experience dictates. Executive Aircraft Operation The additive may be used continuously in executive aircraft where utilization is less than 1200 hours per year.

entry.note: Approved for use in engine fuel at the option of the refiner to ensure adequate high temperature stability at time of use.

The use of this additive must be limited to engines being operated by departments and agencies of the U.S. Department of Defense and must be used accordance to the provisions of MIL-PRF-83133. This additive has been shown to improve jet fuel thermal stability, in some applications to significantly reduce fuel nozzle coking and to improve hot section cleanliness. This additive consists of an antioxidant, a metal deactivator and a dispersant.

Ethylene Glycol EthylEther (Ethyl Cellosolve,“Fluid I”) as definedin GOST 8313

entry.note: If these fuels are to be used for more than 1000 hours, intermittently, or continuously, a borescope inspection of the hot section, and flow and visual inspection of the fuel nozzles must be done between 500 and 1000 hours of accumulated running time.To enable continued use of this fuel in excess of 1000 hours, the results of the inspections must be acceptable to P&WC.Borescope inspection requirements are available from P&WC.

procedure.title: General
procedure.note: P&WC does not recommend the casual mixing of different brands or types of oil. If oil mixing is necessary, refer to the related text below, Chapter 72-00-00, Engine - Servicing and Chapter 05-20-00, SCHEDULED MAINTENANCE CHECKS.
procedure.step: Refer to 05-20-00, SCHEDULED MAINTENANCE CHECKS for oil drain interval and 72-00-00, SERVICING for oil system servicing.

Major factors affecting oil deterioration over time are engine mechanical condition, climatic, atmospheric and environmental conditions, dust and sand ingestion during take-off/landing modes and engine utilization.

Oil System Servicing On expiry of approved oil drain period, drain complete oil system (Ref. Engine - Servicing) and refill (Ref. Engine - Servicing). When switching to another approved brand, drain (Ref. Engine - Servicing) and flush complete oil system (Ref. Engine - Servicing) and refill (Ref. Engine - Servicing). If oils of non-approved brands, or of different viscosities become mixed, drain (Ref. Engine - Servicing) and flush complete oil system (Ref. Engine - Servicing) and refill with an approved oil Engine - Servicing. If it is necessary to replenish oil consumption losses when oil of the same brand (as tank contents) is unavailable, then the following requirements apply: for contingency purposes, oil replenishment with any other approved oil brand listed is acceptable provided: The total quantity of added oil does not exceed 2 U.S. quarts/2.4 Imp. quarts (1.88 liters), in any 600 hour period. If it is required to add more than 2 U.S. quarts/2.4 Imp. quarts (1.88 liters) of dissimilar oil brands, the instructions in step apply. If an operator wishes to monitor oil quality, it is recommended that a program be established in collaboration with the operator's oil supplier/manufacturer.

procedure.title: Approved Oils
procedure.step: 5 Centistoke Oils The oils listed (Ref. Table ), comply with specification PWA 521, Type II Oil (5Cs). These oils are fully approved for use in PW300 engines.

WHEN CHANGING FROM AN EXISTING LUBRICANT FORMULATION TO A “THIRD GENERATION” LUBRICANT FORMULATION (SEE TABLE ), P&WC STRONGLY RECOMMENDS THAT SUCH A CHANGE SHOULD ONLY BE MADE WHEN AN ENGINE IS NEW OR FRESHLY OVERHAULED.Third Generation Oils The term “Third Generation” is one that oil companies use to describe turbine oils which they claim to have superior thermal and oxidative stability when compared to typical Type II, 5 Centistoke oils. To make sure that there is no confusion regarding the term “Third Generation”, P&WC consider approved “Third Generation” lubricants, only those listed in Table .

Other Oils No other oils are approved for use in PW300 engines. Should the use of an oil not listed be desired, the intended user should contact Pratt & Whitney Canada, Product Support Department for consultation.

procedure.title: Procedure
procedure.caution: SWITCH OFF EEC ELECTRICAL POWER AND SWITCH ON MAINTENANCE TEST DISCRETE (REF. A.M.M.) BEFORE REMOVING OR INSTALLING ANY ELECTRICAL CONNECTOR
procedure.note: Cleaning procedures must be done on each of the wiring harness connectors every time the connector is disturbed (Ref. 70-00-00 Cleaning).
procedure.step: All EEC fault isolation and corrective action procedures are to be done with the aircraft on the ground only.
All resistance values contained within the corrective action procedures are defined to cover an ambient temperature range of -55°C to +80°C.

The resistance of an electrical circuit varies directly as a function of temperature. If a high resistance value is measured for a cold component on a cold day, but is acceptable according to the Fault Isolation Table, it is possible that when the engine is hot, the component resistance will be high enough to cause a fault.
Inspect pin and socket ends for corrosion, contamination or damage when connectors are removed.
All recycling of EEC 28 VDC aircraft power is required with engine(s) not running.
Clean electrical connectors using trichloroethane.

Do all chromel and alumel thermocouple harness checks as follows: Positive test lead to positive lead lug. Negative test lead to negative lead lug. Record resistance value (ie 9.8 ohms). Negative test lead to positive lead lug. Positive test lead to negative lead lug. Record resistance value (ie 23.0 ohms). Use average resistance value. ie. Overall resistance value = 23.0 + 9.82 = 16.4 ohms.
All EEC fault isolation and corrective action procedures are based on treating each fault as a single fault occurrence.
An EEC intermittent fault is a fault which occurs more than once for every two flight legs.
For flight legs with more than one fault occurrence, troubleshoot faults with numerically prefixed MFD fault codes first.
If multiple fault codes occur, check for loose or dirty electrical connectors and rectify as required. Check if fault codes have cleared before proceeding with EEC removal.

Complete the following information sheet and ship with each EEC returned (Ref. Fig. ).
EEC Return Sheet

procedure.title: Procedure
procedure.step: Every EEC fault which produces a cockpit indication can be annunciated via the EEC ARINC 429-11 data bus.
A single EEC fault will produce 1 MFD code.

procedure.title: Description
procedure.step: The EICAS provides an indication of the severity of a fault, based on the ability of an EEC channel to provide required system functions. The four levels are listed in Table .

row.entry: All system functions are available.(EDU may contain fault codes to facilitate preventative maintenance and troubleshooting)

Loss of aircraft power input to EEC. Loss of engine Pamb or PT pressure inputs. Loss of ability to shut-off fuel flow from software.Loss of engine synchronization capability due to any number of faults affecting sync operation.Loss of ATTCS cockpit indication, armed or achieved driver fault.Cannot guarantee igniter operation from software.

Loss of surge protection/recovery due to P3 fault. Loss of T45 or BOV solenoid control.Loss of one of the two sources of N1 or N2 speed input. Loss of ARINC. Loss of ADC input. Loss of ATTCS uptrim function due to any number of failures associated with ATTCS operation.
Any number of faults that inhibits the channel from providing thrust in relation to the TLA position or the capability to shut down.

procedure.title: Description
procedure.step: The prefix or first number or letter of each MFD code designation represents a specific LRU. The EEC is designated by LRU codes 1 through 9. Engine interfaces are designated by LRU codes A through N and W. Airframe interfaces are designated by LRU codes P through T and V.
LRU system includes all components which comprise the system, ie: the T45 system includes EEC, main engine harness, rear core harness, junction box and probe harness.
Table lists major code LRU categories.

general.para: This section contains the servicing procedures applicable to the engine. The procedures are sub-divided to cover four main topics: Oil System Servicing, Preparation for Service or Storage, Preservation/Depreservation and Removal/Installation from/in Maintenance Stand.
Oil system servicing involves oil level checks, replenishing, draining, flushing and refilling.

Preparation of the engine for service or storage involves removal or installation of the engine from its shipping container. Preservation/depreservation covers protection of the engine and the engine oil and fuel systems.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are identified in procedural text.
Refer to INTRODUCTION for alternate products, suppliers and suppliers addresses.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

entry.note: Ref. INTRODUCTION for more details.
The cable equipment that is included in the DPHM kit may be purchased separately through all tooling suppliers.

fixtures-and-equipment.para: The fixtures, equipment and supplier tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

n-para.title: Oil System Servicing
n-para.caution: DURING ALL OIL SYSTEM SERVICING, MAKE SURE EQUIPMENT AND CONTAINERS USED ARE ABSOLUTELY CLEAN. TAKE CARE TO PREVENT INGRESS OF ANY MATTER WHICH COULD CAUSE CONTAMINATION.
n-para.note: P&WC does not recommend the casual mixing of different brands or types of oil. If oil mixing is necessary, refer to Chapter 72-00-00, Description and Operation and Chapter 05-20-00, SCHEDULED MAINTENANCE CHECKS.

subpara.title: General
subpara.para: For lubricating oil specifications, refer to Chapter 72-00-00, Description and Operation.

Recommendations for oil change intervals are based on the performance of specific brands and types of oil, specific engine models and operating criteria. General oil change intervals may be extended periodically and will be reflected by revisions to Chapter 05-20-00, SCHEDULED MAINTENANCE CHECKS.

Permission for extension of oil drain intervals may be granted to operators through monitoring programs conducted by most major oil companies which have been approved by Pratt & Whitney Canada. Chapter 72-00-00, Description and Operation will be revised accordingly to include newly approved oils.

In cases where oils approved by P&WC are not available and other oils have to be substituted, an operator must obtain prior approval or recommendations for use of such oil from:
Pratt & Whitney Canada
1000 Marie-Victorin Blvd.
Longueuil
Quebec
Canada
J4G 1A1
Customer Support

procedure.title: Replacement of Oil with a Different Approved Brand
procedure.step: If replacing an oil listed in Table 12 (Ref. Chapter 72-00-00, Description and Operation, Table 12, Approved Lubricating Oils - PWA521, Type II (5 Centistokes) with another oil also listed in Table 12, continue as follows: Add new oil as required (top off). Original oil does not need to be drained and engine does not need to be flushed.

If replacing an oil listed in Table 12, with an oil listed in Table 13 (Ref. Chapter 72-00-00, Description and Operation, Table 13, Approved Lubricating Oils - PWA521, Type II (5 Centistokes) “THIRD GENERATION”), or replacing an oil listed in Table 13, with an oil listed in Table 12, continue as follows: Replace oil filter and add new oil as required (top off). Original oil does not need to be drained and engine does not need to be flushed. Do a visual check of the oil filter for carbon deposits at the following intervals:
At the next aircraft line check or 60 Flight Hours (FH) max.
At 200 FH max. after the replacement with the new brand.
At 400 FH max. after the replacement with the new brand.
If large quantities of carbon deposits are found (i.e. loose carbon deposits cover most of the oil filter surface and the inside cavity of the filter), stop the replacement process and continue as follows: Replace the oil filter, drain and flush the oil system (Ref. Para. Oil System Drainage). Fill with the original brand of oil and continue oil filter inspection at the above intervals. If carbon deposits are still found in large quantities, contact P&WC for further action. If the oil filter condition is normal, return to the standard oil filter maintenance interval.

If oils of different brands or viscosities are accidentally combined, continue as follows: If the combined oils are listed in Table 11 (not "Third Generation"), no further action is required. For any other combination of approved oils listed in Table 11 or Table 12, continue as follows: Do a visual check of the oil filter. Do another visual check of the oil filter at the next line check or max. 60 FH. If large quantities of carbon deposits are found (i.e. loose carbon deposits cover most of the oil filter surface and the inside cavity of the filter), continue as follows: Replace the oil filter element. Drain, flush and refill the oil system with the original oil (Ref. Para. and Oil System Drainage and Oil System Filling). Do a visual check of the oil filter at the next line check or max 60 FH. Contact P&WC if large quantities of carbon deposits are still found. Alternatively, return to the standard oil filter maintenance interval.
It is recommended that operators wishing to monitor oil quality, should establish a program in collaboration with their oil supplier/manufacturer.

procedure.title: Blue Oil Dye
procedure.step: This dye (PWC05-372) may be added to any P&WC approved lubricating oil on a one time basis when filling the system. The dye improves sight glass visibility and aids in the detection of oil leaks.

Use 0.122 - 0.171 milliliters per liter, or 0.462 - 0.647 milliliters per U.S. gallon of oil. The maximum concentration must not exceed 0.171 milliliters per liter, or 0.647 milliliters per U.S. gallon.
The dye is blue in color, however, when mixed with some oils which are yellow in color, the result may be green colored oil.

row.entry: Octel Oil Blue B Liquid Dye
Octel Starreon LLC8375 South WillowStreet5th FloorLittleton, ColoradoUSA 80124TEL: (303) 792-5554FAX: (303) 792-5280web: http://www.octel-starreon.com

procedure.title: Oil Analysis
procedure.step: Before obtaining an oil sample to analyze, start the engine and run until oil temperature is 70°C (158°F) minimum. Shutdown the engine.

If the Total Acid Number (TAN) is above 2.0, or water content is more than 800 parts per million, either by weight or by volume, continue as follows: Drain and discard oil from the oil tank (Ref. Para. Oil System Drainage). Refill the oil tank with fresh oil (Ref. Para. Oil System Filling). The value of TAN in unused oil conforming to specification varies, depending on brand and manufacturer. As oil deteriorates, the color becomes black and a strong harsh odor is given off. This is not a reason to change the oil, but the oil should be analyzed. Use a Titra-Lube TAN Test Kit (P/N TI-TAN) to analyze the oil. The kit can be obtained from the following address or contact a local distributor for availability of the kit:
Dexsil Chemical Corp.
1 Hamden Park Drive
Hamden
CT
06517
USA
1-800-4-DEXSIL
203-288-3509
203-248-6523

procedure.title: Oil Level Check
procedure.caution: DO NOT ADD OIL ABOVE “MAX” ON THE SIGHT-GLASS, BECAUSE A LARGE QUANTITY OF OIL VAPOR CAN BE LOST DURING ENGINE RUNNING, AND FALSE “OIL LEVEL LOW L-R” EICAS MESSAGES CAN BE DISPLAYED. IF THE OIL LEVEL IS ABOVE “MAX”, DRAIN SOME OIL BEFORE STARTING THE ENGINE.
procedure.note: P&WC does not recommend the casual mixing of different brands or types of oil. If oil mixing is necessary, refer to Chapter 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - DESCRIPTION AND OPERATION and Chapter 05-20-00, SCHEDULED MAINTENANCE CHECKS.

If possible, check the oil level after 10 minutes and within 20 minutes of engine shutdown, do the hot check procedure (Ref. Step , below). This will decrease the possibility of overfilling, due to oil expansion at operating temperature or oil transfer to the AGB during periods of inactivity, and will also give more accurate oil consumption data. If the oil level check is not possible within 20 minutes, do the cold check procedure (Ref. Step , below). If no oil level is visible, do the no oil visible procedure (Ref. Step , below).
If external oil leakage or high oil consumption is suspected, troubleshoot and repair (Ref. 72-00-00, FAULT ISOLATION -1) before adding oil.

Due to installation pitch and roll, and internal clearances, each engine will "find its own level" and will consume less oil if it is maintained at or below that level. Note that an oil level between “MIN” and “MAX” is serviceable for continued operation to the next scheduled oil level check.
procedure.step: Hot Check: Do the oil level check after 10 minutes and within 20 minutes after engine shutdown, as follows: Check oil tank contents directly from sight glass oil level indicator. If the oil level is above “MIN” no action is required. If the oil level is below “MIN” and excessive oil consumption is suspected, refer to Chapter 72-00-00, FAULT ISOLATION -1. Otherwise add oil to a level between “MIN” and “MAX”. To add oil, do as follows: Unlock and remove the filler cap from the filler neck. Add the necessary quantity of approved oil to the oil tank. Install the filler cap in the filler neck. Make sure the cap is correctly installed and locked safely. If necessary, clean spilled oil from the engine.

Cold Check: Do the oil level check after more than 20 minutes after engine shutdown, as follows: If the oil level is above “MIN” no action is required. Optionally, add oil up to one half inch below “MAX” to allow for expansion at operating temperature. If the oil level is below “MIN” but visible on the sight glass, do an engine motoring cycle or a run cycle as shown: If oil is not visible on the sight glass, proceed with the following step . Motoring Cycle: - Perform a 15 to 20 second dry motoring cycle to return the oil that could have transferred into the AGB from the oil tank. Observe starter limits (Ref. Aircraft Flight Manual). Check the oil level in the sight-glass and proceed as follows: If the oil level is above “MIN” no action is required. Optionally, add oil up to one half inch below “MAX” to allow for expansion at operating temperature. If the oil level is still below “MIN” and excessive oil consumption is suspected refer to Chapter 72-00-00, FAULT ISOLATION -1. Otherwise add oil to a level between “MIN” and one half inch below “MAX” to allow for expansion at operating temperature. Run Cycle: - Alternatively, start the engine (Ref. Aircraft Flight Manual) and run at idle or above until the oil temperature reaches the nominal operating temperature. If operation above idle is required to reach the nominal oil temperature, reduce power to idle for a minimum of two minutes before shutting the engine down to stabilize the engine temperature. Check the oil level, refer to hot check procedure above.

No Oil Visible: If oil level is not visible in the sight glass oil level indicator and/or the aircraft has not been used for an extended period, proceed as follows: Check for external leakage and repair as necessary. Fill oil tank to the “MIN” level mark on the sight glass and motor the engine for 30 seconds. This will return oil that has drained into the AGB back to the oil tank. Check the oil level after 10 minutes (this is to let the oil stable in the oil tank). If the oil level is above “MIN” no action is required. Optionally, add oil up to one half inch below “MAX” to allow for expansion at operating temperature. If the oil level is above “MAX”, drain some oil before starting the engine. If the oil level is below the “MIN” mark, further investigation is required. Contact your local Field Service Representative.

procedure.title: Oil System Drainage (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: Recommendations for oil change intervals are based on the performance of specific brands and types of oil, specific engine models and operating criteria. General oil change intervals may be extended periodically and will be reflected by revisions to Chapter 05-20-00, SCHEDULED MAINTENANCE CHECKS.

Permission for extension of oil drain intervals may be granted to operators through monitoring programs conducted by most major oil companies which have been approved by Pratt & Whitney Canada. Chapter 72-00-00, DESCRIPTION AND OPERATION will be revised accordingly to include newly approved oils.
procedure.step: Place suitable containers or drip pan under engine.
Remove oil filler cap.
Remove nuts (11) and washers (12).
Remove cover (13), located on pressure oil pump body, with puller (PWC43172).
Remove and discard preformed packing (10).

On 25088 engines, proceed as follows:
DO NOT REMOVE PLUG (14) TO DRAIN THE OIL FROM THE AGB, AS THIS COULD DAMAGE THE AGB HOUSING. Drain the oil from the AGB by removing the chip detector valve housing (4) from adapter (7), using puller (PWC37728). Remove and discard preformed packing (6). Make sure all oil is removed from the bottom of the AGB housing by using a suitable siphon device.
On 25088 engines, proceed as follows: Remove bolt (19) and washer (18). Remove the AGB drain cover (17) with puller (PWC66103). Remove and discard preformed packing (16).

procedure.title: Oil System Filling (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Lubricate new preformed packing (10) with engine oil (PWC03-001), install on cover (13) and insert cover into oil pump housing .
Install washers (12) and nuts (11). Torque nuts 23 to 26 lb.in. (2.6-2.9 Nm), two places.

On 25088 engines, proceed as follows: Lubricate and install new preformed packing (6) on chip detector valve housing (4) and install assembly in adapter (7). Tighten and torque housing 200 to 225 lb.in. (22.6-25.4 Nm) and lockwire (PWC05-089).

On 25088 engines, proceed as follows: Lubricate preformed packing (16) with engine oil (PWC03-001) and install it on cover (17). Install cover (17) with washer (18) and bolt (19). Torque bolt 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm) and install lockwire (PWC05-089).
Remove oil filter cover and withdraw element (Ref. Chapter 79-20-01).
Replace oil filter element if necessary (Ref. Chapter 79-20-01).
Fill cover with specified clean oil, fit new preformed packings and install cover on engine.
Refill oil tank with specified clean oil.
Record the type and brand of oil used in the engine logbook.
Start engine (Ref. Chapter 71-00-00 POWER PLANT - ADJUSTMENT/TEST) and run at stabilized IDLE for fifteen minutes.

procedure.title: Oil System Flushing
