procedure.title: Low Utilization Inspection
procedure.note: The category 1 and 6 Service Bulletins must be considered for incorporation when access permits it.
Do not disassemble sub-assemblies unless indicated in the workscope.
procedure.step: The Low Utilization Inspection (LUI) must be performed as per the following instructions: Do an engine internal wash (Ref. 71-00-00, POWER PLANT - CLEANING). Do a power assurance test (Ref. 71-00-00, POWER PLANT - ADJUSTMENT/TEST). Inspect oil filter content (Ref. 79-20-01, OIL FILTER AND HOUSING - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Inspect LP compressor (Ref. 72-30-01, LP COMPRESSOR - INSPECTION) inlet cone, fan blades, fan case, inner and outer vane ring. Remove compressor inlet cone and fan assembly (Ref. 72-30-01, LP COMPRESSOR - REMOVAL/INSTALLATION). Remove compressor inlet vane (Ref. 72-30-01, LP COMPRESSOR - REMOVAL/INSTALLATION). Check intermediate case for corrosion (Ref. 72-30-01, LP COMPRESSOR - INSPECTION). Inspect variable inlet guide vane (Ref. 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - INSPECTION). Inspect first-stage HP compressor blades (Ref. 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - INSPECTION). Inspect fourth-stage HP compressor blades (Ref. 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - INSPECTION). Inspect and clean compressor bleed valve (Ref. 75-30-01, COMPRESSOR BLEED VALVES - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Check variable inlet guide vane (VIGV) rigging (Ref. 75-30-04, VIGV ACTUATOR - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Inspect combustion chamber liner (Ref. 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - INSPECTION). Inspect first, second stage HP turbine blades and vanes (Ref. 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - INSPECTION). Inspect third, fifth stage LP turbine blades and vanes (Ref. 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - INSPECTION). Inspect fuel nozzle (Ref. 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - INSPECTION). Check the continuity resistance of T4.5 system (Ref. 77-20-01, T4.5 THERMOCOUPLES - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Check security of connections inside T4.5 terminal box (Ref. 77-20-01, T4.5 THERMOCOUPLES - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Check for fuel and oil leak externally and at drains. Remove and check chip detector for debris (Ref. 72-00-00, ENGINE, GENERAL - INSPECTION) and (Ref. 79-30-01, CHIP DETECTOR - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Inspect chip detector (Ref. 79-30-01, CHIP DETECTOR - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Inspect oil filter content for foreign matter and damage (Ref. 79-20-01, OIL FILTER AND HOUSING - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Inspect fuel filter (Ref. 73-10-03, FUEL FILTER AND FUEL WASTE EJECTOR - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Clean all wiring harness connectors (Ref. 70-00-00, STANDARD PRACTICES - CLEANING). Check for security of all wiring harness, clamps and brackets, and for evidence of wear, chaffing, cracks and corrosion (Ref. 77-20-01, T4.5 THERMOCOUPLES - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Check for security of tube connections, clamps and brackets, and for evidence of wear, chaffing, cracks and corrosion (Ref. 70-00-00, STANDARD PRACTICES - CLEANING).

n-para.title: LP Rotor Balancing Assembly and Compressor Inlet Cone Assembly (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: LP Rotor Balancing Assembly and Compressor Inlet Cone Assembly

n-para.para: The LP rotor balancing assembly and compressor inlet cone assembly are mounted on the front end of the low compressor shaft and are housed by the fan case.

The titanium fan hub mounts 22 titanium fan blades in slots in the disk. A retaining ring, attached to the front balance rim, retains the blades axially at the front. The blades are retained axially at the rear by two collar segments surrounded by a one-piece ring. The one-piece ring is secured by a retaining ring which is attached to the rear balance rim. The assembly is balanced in two planes by the addition of counterweights riveted to the inner diameter of the front and rear balance rims. The balanced assembly is secured to the low compressor shaft by a cupwasher, fan retaining nut, keywasher and retaining ring.

The aluminum compressor inlet cone mounts on the front of the fan hub with a bayonet style arrangement. A central tie-bolt, mounted in the front of the compressor shaft and retained by a nut, engages the front of the nose cone which in turn is secured to the tie-rod with a drive key and bolt. The hollow tie-bolt provides the passage for hot P2.8 air to continuously anti-ice the nose cone. Balancing is achieved by material removal from a flange located inside the cone.

n-para.title: Fan Case and Stator Assemblies (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The fan case consists of a hardwall nitronic stainless steel shell, with integral front and rear flanges. The rear flange is bolted to the intermediate case, while the front flange provides the means of attachment for the air intake cowling. A shrouded abradable liner of epoxy/glass microballoon composition surrounds the fan on the case inside diameter, and a honeycomb/perforate sheet provides noise suppression behind the fan, also on the case inside diameter.
The fan stator assemblies, which consists of concentric inner and outer stator assemblies, divide and direct the airflow from the fan.

The inner stator (core) assembly has a single row of 48 stainless steel guide vanes which direct the airflow through the intermediate case to the high pressure compressor. Each inner vane incorporates anti-icing air channels which direct hot P2.8 air from the outer support shroud cavity along the inside of the leading and trailing edges of the vane. The anti-icing air exits from the vanes into the cavity behind the fan disk, where it is vented into the core airflow. The inner vanes are brazed to their outer shroud, while a silicone rubber potting compound secures the roots of the vanes to the inner shroud. The inner stator assembly locates on the intermediate case with a bayonet fixing on the outer shroud, and is secured to the case at the inner shroud with six bolts.

The outer stator (bypass) assembly has a single row of 66 aluminum guide vanes, which direct airflow to the bypass duct. The vanes are secured to an inner and outer shroud ring with a silicone rubber potting compound, to form a one-piece assembly. The two assemblies entrap a steel sleeve which forms a plenum for P2.8 air for anti-icing of the inner stator vanes.

n-para.title: LP Compressor Shaft, No. 1 Bearing and Intershaft Seal Housing (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: LP Shaft, No. 1 Bearing and Intershaft Seal Housing

n-para.para: The LP compressor shaft is a one-piece steel shaft, supported by the No. 1 ball thrust bearing at the front and No. 4 roller bearing at the rear. The balanced shaft assembly contains an internal counterweight, riveted in place midway along the shaft. Slots on the front end of the shaft mate with lugs on the nose cone extension, while a spline mounts the fan balancing assembly. A spline towards the rear end of the shaft mounts the LP turbine assembly, while a thread mounts the N1 speed sensor toothed wheel. Air seals mounted on both ends of the shaft prevent oil leakage from the No. 1 and 4 bearing compartments. Holes in the shaft allow passage of P3 air for pressurizing of the seals.

The No. 1 bearing compartment consists of a one piece housing assembly. The cone shaped one piece housing fastens to the front of the intermediate case with 18 bolts and supports the No. 1 bearing cover and housing assembly at its inner flange with 12 bolts. The bearing cover houses a carbon seal and the stationary runner of the labyrinth air seal at the front of the No. 1 bearing and joins with the housing assembly which supports the No. 1 bearing inner race.

The intershaft seal housing bridges the gap between the LP and HP compressor shafts and supports two carbon seals; one at the rear of the No. 1 bearing compartment and one at the front of the No. 2 bearing compartment. The housing connects to the intermediate case and directs pressure oil from the case to the No. 1 and 2 bearing compartments and P2.8 pressurizing air to the carbon seals and intershaft space.

n-para.title: Intermediate Case Assembly (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The intermediate case assembly consists of a machined magnesium casting which provides passage for core and bypass airflow through concentric annular passages. The case is the main structural member of the engine carcass; it supports the low pressure compressor case at flange B, the bypass duct at flange C and at its inner rear flange, the gas generator case. The accessory gearbox is suspended from the bottom of the intermediate case. Primary (core) airflow passes through the inner passage to the high pressure compressor rotor while secondary (bypass) airflow passes through the outer passage to the bypass duct. The annular passage walls are joined by six radial struts in the outer passage and airfoil guide struts in the inner passage. The outer and inner struts are located on common radial axes and are all hollow.
The outer wall of the primary passage and the inner wall of the bypass passage are joined at the front and rear to form the annular engine oil tank.
The oil filler and sight-glass are located on the port side of the engine installation.

The bore at the rear of the intermediate casing supports the No. 2 oil-damped ball bearing and the variable inlet guide vane shroud hub, while the front face of the bore supports the No. 1 bearing housing assembly by means of a frangible support.

Four mount pads on the outer wall are in line with the four struts located 35 degrees above and below the horizontal centerline. Passageways and bosses provide for oil and air transfer and various accessories.

n-para.title: Gas Generator Case/Diffuser Assembly (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The gas generator case is a titanium weldment consisting of an open girder section welded to front and rear flanges and a titanium diffuser off-take section. A sealing face for the impeller housing is embodied at the diffuser inlet while the center section forms the support for the conical No. 3 bearing housing. Internal passageways in the diffuser section direct P2.8 pressurizing air, pressure and scavenge oil to and from the No. 3 bearing compartment.

The front flange is bolted to the intermediate case and the rear flange supports the combustion chamber outer case. Open girder construction allows access to the variable inlet guide vane geometry, compressor bleed valves, anti-icing solenoid valve and starting bleed valve.

The conical No. 3 bearing housing supports the No. 3 roller bearing outer race. The diffuser center section supports the oil nozzle assembly and front and rear carbon seals. Bearing covers mounted on the front and rear of the center section provide thermal protection for the bearing cavity and act as air seals. The rear of the bearing housing also provides a mounting face for the tangential on-board injection nozzle.

n-para.title: HP Compressor Rotor Balancing Assembly (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The HP compressor rotor balancing assembly consists of the four-stage axial and one-stage centrifugal HP compressor rotor and the two-stage HP turbine rotor balancing assembly.

The HP compressor rotor consists of four axial stages and a single-stage centrifugal impeller. The first-stage rotor is a one-piece titanium forging, consisting of a shaft, disk and 23 blades (integrally bladed rotor) and is bolted to the front of the compressor assembly with 12 nuts and bolts. The second, third and fourth-stage rotors are also titanium forged blisks, electron-beam welded together to form a one-piece (drum) assembly, thus providing rigidity for tight blade tip clearances. The welded rotor stages have 31, 34 and 39 blades respectively. The 32 vane centrifugal impeller is produced from a titanium forging and is connected to the HP turbine shaft with 15 nuts and bolts to comprise a balanced set. The impeller/shaft set is fastened to the rear of the HP compressor axial stages (drum) with 15 nuts and bolts.

The No. 2 bearing is oil film damped to minimize engine vibration and supports the front end of the compressor rotor balancing assembly in the intermediate case. A carbon seal runner is mounted behind the bearing, while the accessory gearbox bevel drive gear abutts against the front side of the bearing. A keyed lock-ring and nut secures the drive gear on the compressor shaft.

The HP turbine shaft is a hollow steel forging, machined to accommodate the No. 3 bearing front rotor air seal, the oil slinger, the No. 3 roller bearing inner race and the No. 3 bearing rear rotor air seal. The rear rotor air seal also serves as a “pressure balance piston”, by transmitting a forward load to the No. 2 ball bearing, from pressurized air behind the No. 3 bearing compartment. Splines on the rear end of the shaft mate with the two-stage HP turbine rotor balancing assembly, while six holes on the conical end of the shaft allow P2.8 pressurizing air from the No. 3 bearing compartment to vent into the intershaft space.

n-para.title: HP Compressor Case (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The HP compressor case installation consists of two titanium casings, (front and rear), variable inlet guide vanes (VIGV) and first-stage variable stators with associated unison-ring linkage, and the second, third, and fourth-stage stator assemblies.

The front case mates with 14 studs on the intermediate case and bolts to the HP compressor rear case with 12 bolts. A row of 29 and 42 bushed holes accommodate the outer spindles of the VIGV and the first-stage variable stators, respectively. An abradable silicone/microballoon glass coating on the front case ID surrounds the first and second-stage rotor path to allow tight blade tip clearance.

An actuator linkage for the variable vanes is mounted on the front case and consists of two unison rings (one per stage) and 71 connector links (one per vane), which connect to the outer spindles. The VIGV inner spindles are supported by a two-piece inner shroud ring which is mounted on the intermediate case with six studs. Pressure oil for the No. 2 bearing and its rear carbon seal is supplied through a passage at the 10 o'clock position on the ring, while a slot in the bottom of the ring allows scavenge oil to pass into a hollow strut in the intermediate case, where gravity drains into the accessory gearbox. The inside diameter (ID) at the rear of the shroud ring assembly acts as the stationary runner for the No. 2 bearing labyrinth air seal. The first-stage compressor stator inner shroud ring assembly is held together with six bolts and forms the stationary runner for the inter-stage air seal between the first and second-stage HP compressor rotors.

The rear case consists of a flanged front and rear section, welded to an intermediate support-ring. The support-ring mounts the fourth-stage stator with three bolts and forms the front of a plenum for P2.8 bleed air. The rear flange supports the impeller shroud housing with six bolts and forms the rear of the plenum. The second and third-stage compressor stators comprise a two-piece cast stainless steel assembly, having 56 and 48 vanes, respectively. Anti-rotation lugs on the outer platform locate in slots at both ends on the inside of the rear case. Slots, located around the circumference of the outer shroud, allow P2.5 air from the third-stage of the HP compressor to vent to the compressor bleed valves. An abradable coating on the inner shrouds of the stator vanes and around the third and fourth-stage rotor paths provides interstage air sealing.

Ten bosses on the rear case provide for compressor bleed as follows:
two for P2.5 compressor bleed valves.
two for P2.8 compressor bleed valves.
two for cabin bleed air tubes.
one for P2.8 anti-ice solenoid valve.
two for airframe supplied rudder bias system.
one for P2.8 bearing air seal pressurization.

general.para: Lubricate preformed packings, threads and mating surfaces with engine oil unless otherwise stated.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.
Refer to INTRODUCTION for alternate products, suppliers and suppliers addresses.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

procedure.title: Removal - 25058 and 25058 (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: Fan Assembly and Compressor Inlet Cone - Removal

procedure.step: INLET CONE IS A BALANCED COMPONENT, HANDLE WITH CARE.Put an index mark on the inlet cone and fan blade in line with the V-mark on the inlet cone using an approved marker (PWC05-018).

Unstake
nose cone keywasher (2) A13RW03-03 1 using socket (PWC43260).

Remove
compressor inlet cone bolt (1) A13RB20-01 1 using socket (PWC43260), remove and discard inlet cone keywasher (2).

Remove
nose cone drive key (3) A13RK01-01 1 .

25058 Engine Only: Turn and remove
compressor inlet cone (4) A13RC15-01 1 .

FOR 25058 ENGINE, REMOVAL OF THE INLET CONE ALLOWS THE 22 BLADES TO MOVE FORWARD. MAKE SURE BLADES DO NOT DISENGAGE FROM THE FAN HUB WHEN THE CONE IS REMOVED. INSTALL THE BLADE RETAINER (PWC61996) TO SECURE ALL THE BLADES ON THE HUB.25058 Engine Only: Turn and remove compressor inlet cone (4). Install the blade retainer (PWC61996) on the fan hub.

procedure.title: Installation - 25058 (Ref. Fig. and )
procedure.step: MATERIAL OF FAN ASSEMBLY IS TITANIUM. HANDLE WITH EXTREME CARE USING CLEAN GLOVES. SCRATCHES, NICKS OR ABRASIONS MUST NOT OCCUR.Turn the fan until the V-mark on the blade retaining ring is at top center. Put a mark on the number one fan blade in line with the V-mark, using an approved marker (PWC05-018).

INLET CONE IS A BALANCED COMPONENT, HANDLE WITH CARE.Install
inlet cone (4) A13RC15-01 1 over
low compressor tie-rod (6) A13RT10-01 1 with V-mark at top.
MAKE SURE THAT THE INLET CONE IS ALL THE WAY ON.Push the inlet cone all the way on. Turn inlet cone until slot in cone aligns with the slots in the tie rod end.
Install puller (PWC30128-03) into end of tie rod (6) and pull tie rod forward until fully engaged.

Install
drive key (3) A13RK01-01 1 in inlet cone (4). Turn inlet cone if necessary until drive key can be inserted.

Install
keywasher (2) A13RW03-03 1 and
compressor inlet cone bolt (1) A13RB20-01 1 .

Centralize keywasher using (PWC62180). Loctite (PWC08-014) may be applied sparingly to make sure the keywasher tab (2) remains braced against the drive key slot in a counterclockwise position during the torquing of the nose cone bolt (1).
Torque bolt (1) using socket (PWC43260) (Fits and Clearances, REF. NO. 1701).
Stake nose cone keywasher (2) into two opposing slots of inlet cone bolt with crimper (PWC60926) or (PWC62073).
Check for fit and clearance of the keywasher. Fits and Clearances, REF. NO. 1420 is 0.095 inch Axial in two places (Ref. Fig View A).

procedure.title: Installation - 25058 (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Apply a light coat of anti-seize compound (PWC06-004) to the compressor inlet cone on the surface shown (Ref. Fig. ).
Remove the retaining ring (PWC61996).

Install the compressor inlet (nose) cone and rotate until the slot in the nose cone and the slot in the tie rod are aligned and the V-mark on the nose cone is aligned with the top center of the fan assembly. Put a mark on the number one fan blade in line with the V-mark, using an approved marker (PWC05-018).

INLET CONE IS A BALANCED COMPONENT, HANDLE WITH CARE.Install inlet
cone (1) A13RC15-01 1 over low compressor
tie-rod (5) A13RT10-01 1 with V-mark at top.
MAKE SURE THAT THE INLET CONE IS ALL THE WAY ON.Push the inlet cone all the way on. Turn inlet cone until slot in cone align with the slots in the tie rod end.
Install puller (PWC30128-03) into end of tie rod (5) and pull tie rod forward until fully engaged.

Install
drive key (4) A13RK01-01 1 in inlet cone (1). Turn inlet cone if necessary until drive key can be inserted.

Loctite (PWC08-014) may be applied sparingly to make sure the
keywasher (3) A13RW03-03 1 tab remains braced against the drive key (4) slot in a counterclockwise position during the torquing of the nose cone bolt.
Install keywasher (3) and compressor inlet cone bolt (1). Torque bolt using socket (PWC43260) (Ref. 72-30-01, Fits and Clearances, Table 402, REF. NO. 1701).
Stake nose cone keywasher (3) into two opposing slots of inlet cone bolt with crimper (PWC62073) or (PWC60926).
Check for fit and clearance for the keywasher. Fits and Clearances, REF. NO. 1420 is 0.095 inch Axial (2 Places).

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Push
tie-rod (6) A13RT10-01 1 rearward until lugs disengage from
tie-rod retaining nut (7) A13RN05-02 1 using puller (PWC30128-03).
Remove tie-rod retaining nut (7).

Remove tie-rod (6) using puller (PWC30128-03). Remove and discard
preformed packing (8) A13RP03-01 1 .

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Find and mark the master slot of low compressor shaft,
tie rod retaining nut (7) A13RN05-02 1 and master lug of
low compressor tie-rod (6) A13RT10-01 1 using an approved marker (PWC05-018). Master slot and lug are wider than the others.

MAKE SURE TIE ROD IS FULLY SEATED.Lubricate and install one new
preformed packings (8) A13RP03-01 1 onto
low compressor tie-rod (6) A13RT10-01 1 using (PWC03-001). Align master lug of tie-rod with master slot of low compressor shaft and insert tie rod.

Install
tie rod retaining nut (7) A13RN05-02 1 onto low compressor shaft until contact is made with lugs of tie-rod (6).
Unscrew tie rod retaining nut (7) until the master slot aligns with master lug of low compressor tie rod (6). Pull tie rod forward until lugs of tie-rod engage slots of retaining nut.

procedure.title: Blade Replacement - 25058 (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: A maximum of 3 damaged blades can be replaced in the fan balancing assembly by redistributing some of the 22 blades (including the new replacement blades) based on the redistribution printout of a computer program which can be obtained from PWC Help Desk.
procedure.step: REMOVAL OF THE INLET CONE ALLOWS THE 22 BLADES TO MOVE FORWARD. MAKE SURE BLADES DO NOT DISENGAGE FROM THE FAN HUB WHEN THE CONE IS REMOVED. INSTALL THE BLADE RETAINER (PWC61996) TO SECURE ALL THE BLADES ON THE HUB PRIOR TO REMOVAL FOR BLADE REPLACEMENT/REDISTRIBUTION.Remove the compressor inlet cone (Ref. Para. 5A, Compressor Inlet Cone).
Install blade retainer (PWC61996).

Mark the fan blades with an approved marker (PWC05-018) with reference to the 'V' mark on the hub. The No. 1 blade is the closest counterclockwise of the 'V' reference. Mark all 22 blades in counterclockwise direction (leading edge view).

Record on the Fan Blade Distribution Chart, the moment weight and serial number of all 22 blades in the existing assembly, including the blades to be replaced. The blade moment weight is marked on the front of the blade platform.
Send the blade information recorded in step including the Serial No. and Moment Weight of the new blades to be installed to PWC Help Desk. Also send the fan blade inspection results of all blades.
PWC Help Desk will provide the new optimum circumferential positions of the fan blades.

Based on the printout results, mark all 22 blades including the replacement blade/s of the fan assembly in counterclockwise direction (leading edge view) with an approved marker (PWC05-018) starting with No. 1 blade. The nearest slot counterclockwise (leading edge view) from the 'V' mark is the slot position of No. 1 blade. The remaining blades are numbered in counterclockwise direction (leading edge view) up to No. 22.
Remove the blade retainer (PWC61996) from the fan assembly and replace with a slotted blade retainer (PWC62019) for individual removal/installation of the blade.

MAKE SURE BLADES DO NOT DISENGAGE FROM THE FAN HUB WHEN INSTALLING THE BLADES.Take note of the alignment mark 'V' on the hub. Remove the damaged blades and reposition the blades including the replacement blades in accordance with printout results of redistribution from PWC Help Desk. Use the slotted blade retainer (PWC62019) to individually remove/install the blade.
Remove the retainer and install compressor inlet cone (Ref. Para. 5, Compressor Inlet Cone - Installation - 25058).
Restore engine to standard operating condition. Ground run the engine and check for vibration (Ref. 71-00-00, Adjustment and Test).

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
MATERIAL OF FAN ASSEMBLY IS TITANIUM. HANDLE WITH EXTREME CARE USING CLEAN GLOVES. SCRATCHES, NICKS OR ABRASIONS MUST NOT OCCUR.Remove
retaining ring (9) A13RR20-01 1 and
keywasher (10) A13RW03-02 1 .

Unstake
cupwasher (12) A13RW03-01 1 using unstaking tool (PWC60773).
Install adapter (14) (PWC43262) into end of low compressor shaft (Ref. Sht. 2).
Install socket (15) (PWC43261) over adapter (14) and onto fan retaining nut (11).
Insert drive bar (16) (PWC43515-11) into end of adapter.
Install wrench (17) (PWC41050) over drive bar and locate on drive spline of socket.
Install adapter (18) (PWC40781) on rear of drive bar and locating holes on rear face of wrench. Attach using two socket head screws (19) .

Loosen
fan retaining nut (11) A13RN05-01 1 .
Remove previously installed special tooling, fan retaining nut (11) and cupwasher (12). Discard cupwasher.
Attached lifting fixture (PWC60449) to a suitable hoist and install on fan assembly (5).
Insert pad (20) (PWC43248) into end of low compressor shaft.

Install puller (21) (PWC43264) on
fan assembly (5) A13RS08A01 Ref .
Screw adapter (22) (PWC71392) on cylinder (23) (PWC89837).
Install cylinder assembly on puller (21). Make sure that locking features engage.
Connect cylinder hose to hydraulic pump (24) (PWC37807).
Slowly operate hydraulic pump and remove fan assembly (5) from low compressor shaft.
Remove previously installed puller and related tooling.
Place fan assembly in a suitable container and remove lifting fixture.

Remove
adjusting spacer (13) A13RR33-05 1 from low compressor shaft. Measure and record spacer thickness as Dim. S.

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
MATERIAL OF FAN BALANCING ASSEMBLY IS TITANIUM. HANDLE WITH EXTREME CARE WITH CLEAN GLOVES. SCRATCHES, NICKS OR ABRASIONS MUST NOT OCCUR. THE USE OF DRY ICE IS NOT PERMITTED ON THE LP SHAFT. FOR 25052 ENGINES, MAKE SURE THE BLADE RETENTION TOOL (PWC61996) IS INSTALLED PRIOR TO LIFTING THE FAN ASSEMBLY.Lift
fan assembly (12) A13RH06A01 1 using method 1 or method 2 as follows: Fan Lifting Method 1. Put puller (PWC61801) (4) on bench and remove sleeve (5). Install split body segments (6) on fan hub (12). Attach with sleeve (5). Put lifting adapter (PWC61404) (3) on bench. Remove ball lock pin (8) and swing lock (7) away from lifting adapter.
MAKE SURE FIXTURE DOES NOT DAMAGE FAN.Engage lifter assembly (3) in the groove in puller (4). Swing lock (7) into place engaging in puller groove. Attach with ball lock pin (8). Install lifter(PWC61793) (2) in lifting adapter (3). Attach with ball lock pin (1). Fan Lifting Method 2. Install fan lifter (13) onto front face of fan assembly bore.
Install fan case protector (17) onto the inner diameter of the fan case at the 12 o'clock position.
Attach fan lifter to a suitable overhead crane.
Lift fan assembly until the fan hub is at the same height as, and aligned with, low compressor shaft.

PUT ON PROTECTIVE GLOVES WHEN HANDLING HOT PARTS TO PREVENT PERSONAL INJURY.Heat fan bore using method 1 or method 2 as follows: Method 1: Connect the heater to the TOOL output connection on the controller (PWC67176) or alternate (PWC60136). Install heater (14) (PWC61005) into rotor bore. Turn the main power switch to ON. Check the process controller pre-set is 490° to 500°F (254° - 260°C). Set timer to 8 minutes. Initiate heating by pressing the HEATER START button. Start the timer by using the START/RESET switch. The indicated temperature is equivalent to approximately 300° to 310°F at the front and rear spigot. Alternate Method 2: Install heat shield (16) (PWC63068) onto the rear face of the fan hub bore. Install heat gun (15) (PWC90000) into heat shield (16). Set heat gun dial to 10. Heat fan bore for ten minutes.

MAKE SURE THAT FAN BORE IS CORRECTLY ALIGNED WITH THE LP SHAFT MASTER SPLINE WHEN INSTALLING FAN ASSEMBLY.Install fan
spacer (10) A13RR33-05 1 onto LP
shaft (9) A13RS08-03
. Remove heating tooling and install fan assembly immediately.
Remove fan case protector (PWC62593)
Install drift (20) (PWC60399), adapter (21) (PWC40263), hydraulic cylinder (19) (PWC89837), hydraulic pump (18) (PWC37807) and cooling ring (PWC64330) or air cooling tool (PWC89835).
Apply 700 - 1000 psi to seat LP shaft components.
Connect air supply to cooling ring or air cooling tool.
Maintain pressure until assembly reaches room temperature.
Remove tooling.

procedure.title: Torque Fan Nut
procedure.step: READ MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEET PRIOR TO USING CONSUMABLE MATERIAL.25335: If the replacement fan retaining nut (11) is new proceed to step . If not, apply one coat of anti-galling compound (PWC06-032) to the threads and thrust face of the retaining nut using a brush or swab before installation. Anti-galling compound must be completely removed and then re-applied to nut thread and thrust face area following each complete torque cycle (Ref. Fits and Clearances, REF. NO. 1702).
25335: Apply anti-seize compound (PWC06-004) to the nut thread and thrust face and to shaft thread. Remove excessive compound wherever possible (Ref. Fits and Clearances, REF. NO. 1702).
USE A SLAVE WASHER, IN PLACE OF CUPWASHER DURING INITIAL STEPS OF FAN RETAINING NUT TORQUING PROCEDURE.Install slave washer (PWC60903) on low compressor shaft.
Install adapter (3) (PWC43262) into end of low compressor shaft.
Install socket (4) (PWC43261) over adapter (3) and onto fan retaining nut (11).
Insert drive bar (PWC43515-11) into end of adapter.
Install wrench (5) (PWC41050) over drive bar and locate on drive spline of socket.
Install adapter (6) (PWC40781) on rear of drive bar and rear face of wrench. Attach using two socket head screws (19).
Torque fan retaining nut (11) (Ref. Fits and Clearances, REF. NO. 1702).
Remove previously installed special tooling.
Measure the fan blade leading edge (LE) tip clearances (Ref. Para. ).
Install keywasher (10) and retaining ring (11).
Stake cupwasher (12), at four locations, using staking tool (9) (PWC60668).
Install tie-rod (Ref. Para. ).
Install compressor inlet cone (Ref. Para. ).
Refer to Chapter 71-00-00, for checks following installation of fan assembly.

procedure.title: Fan Clearances (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Load low compressor shaft rearwards.
With each blade loaded to the rear and outward, check leading edge LE tip clearance at a common point on the fan case. Find and mark longest fan blade using an approved marker(PWC05-018).

MEASUREMENT SHOULD BE TAKEN AT PORTION OF FAN CASE THAT IS NOT WORN.With longest blade loaded to the rear and outward, measure and record leading edge tip clearances at four locations around the fan case (Ref. Fig. ). Calculate the average clearance and record it as Dim. b. Make sure clearances are within limits specified (Fits and Clearances, REF. NO. 1256).

If fan blade tip clearance is within limits measure the gap between the rear fan blade retaining ring and the compressor inlet vane assembly. There must be a minimum gap of 0.070 inch (1.78 mm) (Ref. View B). If fan blade tip clearance is within limits go to Para. , step . If fan blade tip clearance is not within limits go to next step.

Adjustment of fan tip clearance, if required, is achieved by varying the thickness of the fan spacer as follows: Remove fan balancing assembly (5) and adjusting spacer (Ref. Para. ). Prepare another fan spacer (Ref. Para. ).
Repeat Para. and Para. , step to .
If fan clearance is now within limits go to Para. , step . If fan clearance is still not within limits go to step .

procedure.title: Fan Spacer Grinding (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Calculate and record the thickness of the fan spacer necessary to bring the fan blade tip clearance within limits using the following formula. a = S ± (C × 0.01) where:
a = Necessary thickness of fan spacer.
S = Thickness of the existing fan spacer.
± = Change in fan blade tip clearance. Use + sign to increase tip clearance. Use - sign to decrease tip clearance.
C = Necessary change of fan blade tip clearance in 0.001 of an inch.
0.01 =Calculation factor. A change in fan blade tip clearance of 0.001 inch requires a 0.01 inch change in spacer thickness.
Adjust fan tip clearance by grinding a new or existing adjusting spacer to Dim. a ± 0.0005 inch (0.013 mm) (Ref. Fig. ).
Faces of spacer must be parallel within 0.0002 inch (0.005 mm), flat within 0.0002 inch (0.005 mm) and have a surface finish of 63 micro-inches or better.
Break sharp edges 0.003 to 0.015 inch (0.08-0.38 mm).
Spray wash spacer (14) using petroleum solvent (PWC11-027).
Check for residual magnetism using a standard field gauge. Negate any residual magnetism.

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: Note location and orientation of all items removed from flange.
procedure.step: Remove EEC (Ref. 73-20-02).

Remove
nut (20) F13EN05-03 1 ,
washer (19) F13EW03-01 3 ,
bolt (18) F13EB20-01 1 and
support tube (17) F50ES65A02 1 .

Remove
nuts (4) A13EN05-01 3 , shipping bracket and
EDU rear support bracket (16) F13EB40A36 1 (Ref. View B).

At location M, two places, remove nuts (4),
washers (3) A13NW03-01 6 and
fire detector brackets (15) F50EB40A08 2 .

At location R, remove nut (4), washer (3),
bolt (14) A13NB20-01 1 and
tube support bracket (13) F50LB40A05 2 .
At location N, remove nut (4) and tube support bracket (13).

Remove nut (4), washer (3),
bolt (12) A13NB20-06 1 and
support (11) F50ES65A02 1 (Ref. Section S-S).

At location T, remove nuts (4), washers (3),
bolts (10) A13NB20-02 3 and
engine lift bracket (9) F13NB40-01 2 .
At location L, two places, remove nuts (4) and washers (3).

At location P, remove
nut (8) A13EN05-01 3 ,
washers (7) A13NW03-01 6 and
bolt (6) A13NB20-04 3 .

At location J, four places, remove nuts (4), washers (3) and
bolts (5) A13NB20-01 5 .

At location K, three places, remove nuts (4), washers (3) and
bolts (2) A13NB20-04 3 .
Install three jacking screws (PWC32396-100) into jacking inserts in fan case Flange B.
Support the weight of the fan case and tighten the jacking screws in a star pattern until the fan case releases from the intermediate case.

Remove
fan case (1) A13NC05A01 1 .

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Apply a thin coat of grease (PWC09-003) to the mating flange of the
fan case (1) A13NC05A01 1 . Align bolt holes and install fan case assembly.

Location K. Install 3
bolts (2) A13NB20-04 3 , 6
washers (3) A13NW03-01 6 and 3
nuts (4) A13EN05-01 3 . Torque 62 to 72 lb. in. (7.0 to 8.1 Nm) dry.

Location J. Install 4
bolts (5) A13NB20-01 5 , 8 washers (3) and 4 nuts (4). Torque 62 to 72 lb. in. (7.0 to 8.1 Nm) dry.

Location P. Install slave
bolt (6) A13NB20-04 3 , 2
washers (7) A13NW03-01 6 and
nut (8) A13EN05-01 3 . Torque 62 to 72 lb. in. (7.0 to 8.1 Nm) dry.
Location L. Install 2 washers (3) and 2 nuts (4). Torque 62 to 72 lb. in. (7.0 to 8.1 Nm) dry.

Location T. Install 2
engine lift bracket (9) F13NB40-01 2 with 3
bolts (10) A13NB20-02 3 , 3 washers (3) and 3 nuts (4). Torque 62 to 72 lb. in. (7.0 to 8.1 Nm) dry.

Location S. Install
support (11) F50ES65A02 1 with
bolt (12) A13NB20-06 1 , washer (3) and nut (4). Torque fingertight.

Location N. Install
tube support bracket (13) F50LB40A05 2 with nut (4). Torque 62 to 72 lb. in. (7.0 to 8.1 Nm) dry.

Location R. Install tube support bracket (13) with
bolt (14) A13NB20-01 1 , washer (3) and nut (4). Torque 62 to 72 lb. in. (7.0 to 8.1 Nm) dry.

Location M. Install 2
fire detector brackets (15) F50EB40A08 2 with 2 washers (3) and 2 nuts (4). Torque 62 to 72 lb. in. (7.0 to 8.1 Nm) dry.

Install
EDU rear support bracket (16) F13EB40A36 1 and shipping bracket with 2 nuts (4). Install shipping bracket facing rearward installed on top or bracket facing forward. Torque 62 to 72 lb. in. (7.0 to 8.1 Nm) dry.

Install
support tube (17) F50ES65A02 1 with
bolt (18) F13EB20-01 1 ,
washer (19) F13EW03-01 3 and
nut (20) F13EN05-03 1 . Torque 36 to 40 lb. in. (4.1 to 4.5 Nm). Torque nut and bolt at other end of support tube 62 to 72 lb. in. (7.0 to 8.1 Nm) dry.
Install EEC (Ref. 73-20-02).

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
DO NOT USE A HAMMER TO ROTATE VANE.Remove
bolts (1) A14NB20-07 6 ,
keywashers (2) A14NW03-08 6 from compressor inlet vane.
Install fixture (PWC61783) to the compressor inlet vane and remove the vane assembly from the intermediate case by turning the assembly using the fixture.

Remove
bolts (4) A14NB20-16 6 ,
washers (5) A14NW03-09 6 and
fan exit vane ring (6) A13NV02A01 1 from
intermediate case (7) A14NC05A01 1 .

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Align 3 lugs on
fan exit vane ring (6) A13NV02A01 1 into 3 slots of
intermediate case (7) A14NC05A01 1 , make sure drain hole is at BDC.

Attach vane ring (6) to intermediate case (7) with 6
bolts (1) A14NB20-07 6 and 6
washers (5) A14NW03-09 6 . Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb. in. (4.1 to 4.5 Nm).

DO NOT USE A HAMMER TO ROTATE VANE.Apply a thin coat of silicone grease (PWC09-003) on mating surfaces for ease of installation. Install fixture (PWC61783) by rotating into position aligning bolt holes. Make sure fixture (PWC61783) is locked and secured correctly into position (pins fit rotation holes).

Secure vane ring (6) to intermediate case (7) with 6
bolts (4) A14NB20-16 6 and 6
keywashers (2) A14NW03-08 6 . Torque bolts 65 to 85 lb. in. (7.4 to 9.7 Nm) and lock tabwashers.

n-para.title: LP Shaft and No. 1 Bearing Housing

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: Removal/Installation of LP Shaft and No. 1 Bearing Housing

key.def: LP Shaft and No. 1 Bearing Housing

procedure.step: Disconnect N1 speed probe wiring harness from N1/T4.5 terminal box (Ref. 77-20-01).
Disconnect No. 4 bearing pressure and scavenge oil tubes from exhaust case (Ref. 79-20-03 and 79-20-04).
Disconnect emergency fuel shut-off cable (Ref. 73-10-05).
Disconnect and remove T4.5 “IN” wiring harness connections from N1/T4.5 terminal box (Ref. 77-20-01).
Remove exhaust case(Ref. 72-50-03).
Remove LP turbine module (Ref. 72-50-02).
Install protector (PWC43250) on rear end of LP shaft.
Remove compressor inlet cone (Ref. Para. ).
Remove low compressor tie rod (Ref. Para. ).
MATERIAL OF FAN ASSEMBLY IS TITANIUM. HANDLE WITH EXTREME CARE USING CLEAN GLOVES. SCRATCHES, NICKS OR ABRASIONS MUST NOT OCCUR.Remove fan balancing assembly (Ref. Para. ).

Install sleeve spacer (3) (PWC60758) and secure with
fan retaining nut (2) A13RN05-01 1 , handtight.

Remove 12
nuts (6) A14NN05-01 12 and
bolts (4 ) A14NB20-14 12 from
No. 1 bearing housing (5) A14NH05-04 1 .
Install three jacking screws (PWC32396-100) in the No. 1 bearing housing jacking inserts.

DO NOT DAMAGE CARBON SEALS IN INTERSHAFT SEAL HOUSING.Carefully withdraw
LP shaft and No. 1 bearing housing (1) A13RS08-03
together by evenly turning jacking screws and pulling LP shaft and housing assembly from engine.
Secure two halves of No. 1 bearing housing together using two slave nuts and bolts.

Discard
preformed packing (8) A14NP03-09 1 .

Remove
transfer tube (11) A13LT17-01 1 (Ref. Sht. 2) and discard
preformed packings (10) A13LP03-01 2 .

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install protector (PWC43250) on the rear of
LP shaft (1) A13RS08-03
.

Lubricate and install new
preformed packing (8) A14NP03-09 1 on
No. 1 bearing housing (5) A14NH05-04 1 .

Lubricate and install two new
preformed packings (10) A13LP03-01 2 on oil
transfer tube (11) A13LT17-01 1 .

Push transfer tube (11) into
No. 1 bearing oil nozzle assembly (12) A14LN04-05
.
Remove slave nuts and bolts from No. 1 bearing housing.

DO NOT DAMAGE CARBON SEALS IN INTERSHAFT SEAL HOUSING.Make sure oil transfer tube (11) is aligned with No. 1 bearing oil nozzle (12) and
oil transfer tube housing (9) A14NH05-05 1 and insert LP shaft assembly and bearing housing assembly into engine.

Secure No. 1 bearing housing assembly (5) to No. 1 bearing support with 12
bolts (4 ) A14NB20-14 12 and
nuts (6) A14NN05-01 12 . Torque 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm.) using a star tightening pattern.

Remove
fan retaining nut (2) A13RN05-01 1 ) and sleeve spacer (3).
Install fan balancing assembly (Ref. Para. ).
Install compressor inlet cone (Ref. Para. ).
Install low compressor tie rod (Ref. Para. ).
Remove protector (PWC43250) from rear end of LP shaft.
Install LP turbine module (Ref. 72-50-02).
Install exhaust case (Ref. 72-50-03).

subpara.title: General
subpara.para: The following pages provide the fits and clearances, torques, spring pressures, special assembly, and backlash checks.
All tables have metric equivalents given in parentheses either beside or below the imperial measurements.
For all tables, the indicated REF. NO. can be found on the Figure following the last table.

subpara.title: Dimensional Checks
subpara.para: The DIMENSIONS FOR REF. column indicates minimum and maximum manufacturing dimensions of two mating parts. These dimensions are provided for information only.
The LIMITS column indicates the desired minimum and maximum fits and clearances between new parts, and also the allowable limit to which these parts may wear before replacement is necessary.
The letter T indicates a tight fit; L or no letter, a loose fit.
BY SELECTION means parts must be matched by selection to provide a required fit.
FIT TO means a fitting operation may be required at assembly to obtain the required fit.
An asterisk (*) indicates part(s) should be replaced if any looseness is evident.
Unless otherwise stated, all fits are diametrical. Spline fits are calculated from chordal dimensions.

subpara.title: Torque Limits
subpara.para: Unless otherwise stated, apply thread lubricant to all parts that are to be torque-loaded.
Use engine lubricating oil or equivalent, unless otherwise specified.

Where torque limits for castle nuts are provided in the MINIMUM column only, these nuts should be tightened to the designated torque and then further tightened, if necessary, to properly align the locking slots and holes.

Where MINIMUM and MAXIMUM values are given, the alignment of the locking slot must be obtained without loosening the nut and without exceeding the maximum limit. If this is not possible, back-off the nut half a turn, then retighten. If alignment cannot be accomplished, select another nut.
Torque requirements for interference fit applications, such as studs, may be obtained with or without lubrication, unless otherwise specified.

row.entry: (LE Radial Tip Clc For New Abradable Material)

entry.note: Axial, 2 places

procedure.title: Nut - Retaining, Fan Hub (25335)
procedure.caution: ANTI-GALLING COMPOUND MUST BE COMPLETELY REMOVED THEN RE-APPLIED TO NUT THREAD AND THRUST FACE AREA FOLLOWING EACH COMPLETE TORQUE CYCLE (STEPS 1 THRU 8). THE SLAVE SPACER MUST HAVE SIMILAR FLATNESS, PARALLELISM AND SURFACE FINISH AS THE CUPWASHER.
procedure.step: Install slave spacer in place of cupwasher. Tighten nut 1200 to 1920 lb.in. (135.6 to 216.9 Nm).
Turn nut thru angle of 42 to 45 degrees.
Loosen nut to 0.0 lb.in. (0.0 Nm).
Remove slave spacer. Install a new cupwasher and match mark using silver pencil (PWC05-018) to detect movement during torquing.
Tighten nut 1140 to 1860 lb.in. (128.8 to 210.15 Nm).
Establish common reference points between nut and mating part using a silver pencil (PWC05-018).
Turn nut thru angle of 40 to 43 degrees.
Loosen nut to 0.0 lb.in. (0.0 Nm) and repeat step .
If nut reference point is in line with mating part reference point or beyond it within 4 degrees Max, apply final angle of turn per step .
If nut reference points are not within limits, repeat steps , and in order, until reference points are within limits then apply final angle of turn per step .
Turn nut thru angle of 40 to 43 degrees.

ANTI-GALLING COMPOUND MUST BE COMPLETELY REMOVED THEN RE-APPLIED TO THE NUT THREADS AND THRUST FACE AREAS FOLLOWING EACH COMPLETE TORQUE CYCLE (STEPS 1 THRU 8).Trial fit key washer. If Key washer can not be installed vary the torquing procedure within limits until key washer can be installed as follows :
Loosen nut 0 lb.in. (0 Nm).
Tighten nut 1140 to 1860 lb.in. (128.8 to 210.15 Nm).
Turn nut thru angle of 40 to 43 degrees.

procedure.title: Nut - Retaining, Fan Hub (25335)
procedure.warning: READ MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEET PRIOR TO USING CONSUMABLE MATERIAL.
procedure.caution: SLAVE SPACER TO HAVE SIMILAR FLATNESS, PARALLELISM AND SURFACE FINISH AS CUPWASHER.
DO NOT EXCEED MAX. TORQUE OF 12000 LB.IN. (1356 NM).
procedure.step: Apply anti-seize compound (PWC06-004) to the nut threads and thrust face including area "AT" and to the LP shaft threads. Remove excess compound wherever possible.

Seat fan assembly - Done as part of fan assembly installation (Ref: Para. ): Method 1: Apply a seating force of 700 to 1000 psi. Keep the pressure up until the fan reaches room temperature, and then reduce pressure to zero. Method 2: Install the nut and torque 1900 to 2800 lb.ft (2576.0 to 3796.3 Nm). Keep the seating torque until the fan reaches room temperature, then loosen nut to 0.0 lb.ft (0.0 Nm).
Install slave spacer in place of cupwasher and torque the nut 1200 to 1920 lb.in (135.6 to 216.9 Nm).
Turn nut thru angle of 42 to 45 degrees.
Loosen nut to 0.0 lb.in. (0.0 Nm).
Remove slave spacer, install actual cupwasher and match mark with silver pencil (PWC05-018) to find rotation during torquing.
Torque nut to 1140 to 1860 lb.in. (128.8 to 210.15 Nm).
Establish same reference points between nut and its mating parts.
Turn nut thru angle of 40 to 43 degrees.
Loosen nut to 0.0 lb.in. (0.0 Nm) and repeat step .
If the nut reference points is in line with the mating part reference point or beyond it within 4 degree maximum, apply final angle of turn of 40 to 43 degrees.
If the reference points are not within limits, repeat steps , and in order, until reference points are within limits then apply final angle of turn per step .

entry.note: NOT APPLICABLE

procedure.title: Nose Cone Assembly
procedure.step: Assemble tie rod onto shaft so that tangs are loaded rearward into shaft shoulder.
Turn tie rod retaining nut on shaft until it touches tie rod, and turn back to the next locking position.
Using puller (PWC30128-03) load tie rod forward so that tangs lock tie rod retaining nut.
Assemble cone assembly onto fan hub bayonet.
Rotate cone assembly until drive keywashers can be inserted.
Tighten bolt per REF. NO. 1701 to a locking position using socket (PWC43260).
Lock bolt by bending tabs of keywasher into two opposing slots of inlet cone bolt using a suitable drift.

entry.note: NOT APPLICABLE

figure.title: Fan Balancing Assembly - Fits and Clearances

general.para: This section provides instructions and limits, required to perform visual inspection of the Compressor Inlet Cone, Fan Blades, Fan Case and Inlet Vane Rings.
Within the following text, where the term nicks or dents is used, unless otherwise specified, blend repair limits are applicable provided at least 70 percent of original surface remains undamaged.
Parts found unsuitable for further engine running should be replaced. Rejected parts should be returned to Pratt & Whitney Canada for complete inspection and possible repair/refurbishment.

procedure.chgdesc: The inspection procedure for compressor inlet cone has been revised to add fretting limits on the fan blade retaining face.
procedure.title: Inspection (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Check for foreign object damage and erosion.
Check for evidence of cracks. No cracks permitted.
Check for dents. A maximum of two dents permitted, provided depth is not greater than 0.100 inch and span is not greater than 1.0 inch. Dents directly adjoining each other are not acceptable.

Nicks on surface is serviceable if it is in the limits that follows:
0.025 in. (0.63 mm) deep maximum.
0.010 in. (0.25 mm) wide maximum.
No raised material.
Local erosion, minor surface pitting and corrosion 0.010 in. (0.25 mm) deep maximum is serviceable.
25058: Fretting on the fan blade retaining face (Face A) is permitted up to 0.015 in. (0.38 mm) deep maximum if there is no fretting on the blade platform mating face (Face B).

procedure.title: Damage Limits (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: SEND ENGINE TO AN APPROVED OVERHAUL FACILITY FOR INSPECTION IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE OVERHAUL MANUAL, IF FOREIGN OBJECT DAMAGE IS SUSPECTED.A fan with blade damage beyond the blend repair limits (Ref. Table ) must be removed from service and sent to an approved overhaul facility for repair. If an aircraft must be flown to a facility equipped for fan removal, record the extent of the blade damage and submit this information to Pratt & Whitney Canada Inc. A review of the information may permit P&WC to recommend limited engine operation for purposes of obtaining flight permission from the operator's regulatory authority.
Inspect the blade LE for erosion. Blend the LE to restore original radius as shown (Ref. Fig. , Detail K), if the LE flat exceeds 0.020 inch.

Inspect LE for bends or deformation. Bends or deformation is acceptable providing the displacement of material does not exceed 0.020 inch perpendicular to the LE span and the length of the bend is less than 0.060 inch along the LE span and the bend is smooth and continuous (Ref. Fig. , View B).
Inspect blade for tears (Ref. Fig. ) and cracks. Tears and cracks are not acceptable.
Inspect blade for nicks (Ref. Fig. ) and dents (Ref. Fig. ). For disposition refer to (Ref. Fig. and Table ).

table.title: Nicks/Dents Fan Blade Inspection and Repair Limits

row.entry: Ref. Fig. for cut back.Ref. Notes 1 and 3.
Total for area B, C & D 2.000 inch.
Ref. Fig. for blending.Ref. Notes 2 and 3.
Total for area B, C & D 2.000 inch.
Ref. Fig. for blending.Ref. Notes 2 and 3.
Total for area B, C & D 2.000 inch.
Ref. Fig. for blending.Ref. Notes 2 and 3.
Total for area E & F 1.000 inch.
Ref. Fig. for blending.Ref. Notes 2 and 3.
Total for area E & F 1.000 inch.
Ref. Fig. for blending.Ref. Notes 2 and 3.

entry.note: a) Only two blades per set to be repaired to the maximum cut back limit.b) Smaller cut back repair can be applied up to eight (8) consecutive blades. The total cut back area must not exceed the equivalant of one cut back performed to maximum limit.c) Total area of cut back repair for a set must not exceed the equivalant of two cut backs performed to the maximum limit.

a) Only six (6) blades per set can be repaired to the maximum limit.b) The cumulative total of all blend repairs performed on a set must not exceed the equivalant of six (6) blades repaired to the maximum limit.c) The total blend repair length for one blade over areas B, C and D must not exceed 2.000 inches.d) The total blend repair length for one blade over areas E and F must not exceed 1.000 inch.
Scattered round bottom dents are acceptable without repair.

procedure.step: Blade tip inspection (area I). Perform this inspection if the blade is removed from the engine. Blend surface damage in form of burrs, rubs or wear to a maximum depth of 0.005 inch.

figure.title: Fan Blades - Example of a Dent
Fan Blades - Example of a Nick
Fan Blades - Example of a Tear

procedure.title: Inspection (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: THE FAN CASE ASSEMBLY IS A COMPOSITE MATERIAL COMPONENT WITHIN A FORGED STAINLESS STEEL CASE. DO NOT DROP OR IMPACT IN ANY WAY. WHEN TRANSPORTING OR STORING, USE A SUITABLE CONTAINER AND MAKE SURE CASE IS COVERED WITH A SUITABLE PROTECTIVE PACKING (e.g. BUBBLE PACK).Visually check fan case without the aid of magnification. Magnification up to 4X may be used as an aid to evaluate observed damage. Definitions of damage and acceptable limits to composite areas of fan case are as specified in Tables and .

Stainless Steel Case: Check for raised metal and sharp edges. Stone to remove. Nicks, burrs, scratches and scores are acceptable up to 0.005 inch deep and not acceptable beyond 0.010 inch deep. Damage from 0.005 to 0.008 inch deep may be blended to a maximum depth of 0.010 inch. Elongation and damage of flange holes is acceptable to a maximum of 0.020 inch radially and 0.010 inch axially. Stone to remove raised metal and sharp edges. No cracks are permitted.
Visually check abradable lining (Area f) for foreign inclusions, holes, or cracks (Ref. Table ).

Perforated Liner (Area h) for (Ref. Table ): The perforated area of the liner segment is aluminum alloy (AMS 4348) Check for ingress of foreign debris (e.g. oil, rubber, dirt). Clean as necessary. Check for nicks, scratches, dents, cracks and holes in perforated areas.
Dimensionally check abradable lining for wear (Fits and Clearances, REF. NO. 1256).

row.entry: Particle included in a component which is foreign to material composition.
Missing material which results in cavity or void.
Refer to Fig. for acceptable limits. Maximum of 0.750 inch diameter to bottom of tray and up to maximum of 14 holes. Holes must be repaired (Ref. Repair). Tray must not be damaged.
Cracks having a width more than 0.025 inch must be repaired (Ref. Repair).
Debonding of abradable material from fan case.

A maximum of 3 areas of delamination can be repaired if the total length of each delaminated area is less than 10 inches, width is less than 2 inches and the 3 areas are separated by a minimum of 3 inches (Refer to repair).
Small piece broken off edge or surface.
A maximum of 20 on seams of perforate is acceptable if chips are separated by a minimum of 2 inches and a maximum depth of damage does not exceed 1/16 inch. Remove any loose material and blend edges.
Maximum of 4 cracks allowed on the seams of the perforate panels. Maximum crack is 1.00 inch long and separated by 6 inches minimum.
Perforate separated, crack extends through thickness
Refer to Fig.: Maximum of 2 cracks in the perforate if crack does not exceed 1.50 inch long and cracks are separated by a minimum of 6 inches. Cracks must be repaired (Ref. Repair).
A surface depression having rounded edges, corners or bottom. Caused by impact of a foreign object.

Scattered dents not exceeding three square inches each, up to 0.250 in. (6.35 mm) deep are acceptable. Maximum total of 15 square inches surface area for each perforate (Ref. Fig. ). All dents must be repaired (Ref. LP COMPRESSOR - REPAIR).Dents (not associated with cracks) 0.100 in. (2.54 mm) deep maximum to the full length and the full circumference of the area are serviceable without repair.
Cracks acceptable to maximum length of 0.250 inch. Refer to Fig. .
Narrow shallow marks caused by movement of sharp object on surface.
Maximum of 10 to a maximum depth of 0.010 inch and a maximum length of 3 inches.
Small piece of perforate broken off.
Maximum of 4 holes, up to 0.50 inch in diameter, allowed on the perforate panels if holes are separated by a minimum of 6 inches. Holes must be repaired (Ref. Repair).

procedure.title: Fan Exit Vane Ring (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Vanes: Visually check for cracks. Cracks are acceptable up to a maximum of 0.100 inch long on the leading edge and 0.025 inch long on the trailing edge and may be removed by blending. Vanes with cracks over these limits , vane assembly must be replaced. Check for raised metal and sharp edges. Stone to remove. Check for nicks and dents on leading and trailing edges. Blend to remove to a maximum depth of 0.125 inch on leading edges and 0.030 inch on trailing edges. Leading and trailing edges must be polished after blending. Check airfoil surfaces for damages. Nicks, dents, scratches or pitting on airfoil surfaces is acceptable to a maximum depth of 0.025 inch if damage does not occur directly opposite on concave and convex surfaces of airfoil.

Inner and Outer Shrouds: Check for raised metal and sharp edges. Stone to remove. Check for local surface damage. Damage is acceptable to 0.005 inch deep and not acceptable beyond 0.008 inch deep. Damage from 0.005 to 0.008 inch deep may be blended to a maximum depth of 0.010 inch.

All other surfaces: Check for raised metal and sharp edges. Stone to remove. Check for local surface damage. Damage is acceptable to 0.005 inch deep and not acceptable beyond 0.008 inch deep. Damage from 0.005 to 0.008 inch deep may be blended to a maximum depth of 0.010 inch.

procedure.title: Compressor Inlet Vane Assembly (Ref. Fig. and Table )
procedure.step: Refer to definitions of damage and acceptable limits as specified in Table .

Visual checks: Check for cracks. No cracks are permitted in the vanes or outer shroud braze fillet. Check for raised metal and sharp edges. Stone to remove. Check for nicks on leading and trailing edges. Blend to remove raised material. Leading and trailing edges must be polished after blending. Check for bends on the leading and trailing edges. Dents on airfoil surface (area B) are serviceable if: No bulging/deformation found on airfoil T/E surface (concave side) (Ref. NOTE: 2, Table ). Dents does not damage the inner shroud potting material. No cracks found on round bottom of the dents.

row.entry: Up to 0.040 inch (1.01 mm) deep and 0.500 inch (12.7 mm)long with no kinks
Acceptable if not associated with a bulge at the same locationon the opposite surface
Up to 0.200 inch (5.08 mm) deepis acceptable

entry.note: Blends must maintain outer braze fillet radius and must not damage inner shroud potting material.
The stator vane internal passageways are required for anti-icing and must not be blocked.

procedure.title: Inspection (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Examine the part for surface damage, corrosion and deterioration of the protective coating. Refer the Table below for acceptable limits.
Acceptable Limits for Corrosion/Damage/Erosion
AreaVisual Inspection Limits
All other SurfacesLocal surface damage 0.005 in. (0.12 mm) deep maximum is serviceable, remove only raised material.
Intermediate Case CastSurfacesRepair local surface damage 0.005 to 0.030 in. (0.13 - 0.76 mm) deep.Isolated corrosion pitting 0.010 in. (0.25 mm) deep maximum is serviceable.Group of corrosion pitting 0.005 in. (0.12 mm) deep maximum is serviceable. Repair group of corrosion pitting 0.005 to 0.015 in. (0.13 - 0.38 mm) deep. Repair group of corrosion pitting with epoxy 0.015 to 0.025 in. (0.39 - 0.63 mm) deep.
Engine Mounting-padsFaces Area CRepair isolated corrosion pitting with epoxy 0.050 in. (1.27 mm) deep maximum. Repair group of corrosion pitting with epoxy 0.015 in. (1.27 mm) deep maximum. NOTE: Corrosion on the mounting-pads must be minimum 0.050 in. (1.27 mm) away from the first coil end of the insert and minimum 0.100 in (2.54 mm) away from center bore and pad edge.
Engine Mounting-pad Spigot-bore Area DRepair local surface damage or corrosion pitting up to 0.010 in. (0.25 mm) deep.
Accessory Mount-pads and External Boss FacesIsolated corrosion pitting 0.005 in. (0.12 mm) deep maximum is serviceable. Repair isolated corrosion pitting 0.030 in. (0.76 mm) deep maximum with epoxy. Repair group of corrosion pitting 0.015 in. (0.38 mm) deep maximum with epoxy.
Side StrutsErosion or FOD 0.040 in. (1.01 mm) deep maximum is serviceable, remove only raised material and sharp edges. Repair erosion or FOD 0.040 to 0.070 in. (1.02 - 1.77 mm) deep with epoxy.
Top and Bottom Dead Centre StrutsErosion or FOD 0.020 in. (0.50 mm) deep maximum is serviceable, remove only raised material and sharp edges. Repair erosion or FOD 0.020 to 0.045 in. (0.51 - 1.14 mm) deep with epoxy.

general.para: This section provides instructions for repairing LP Compressor components.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.
Refer to CONSUMABLE MATERIALS for alternate products, suppliers and suppliers addresses.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

procedure.title: Blend Repairs
procedure.step: MATERIAL OF FAN BLADES IS TITANIUM. AN ACCUMULATION OF TITANIUM DUST IS A FIRE HAZARD. CLEAN UP TITANIUM DUST ON COMPLETION OF REPAIR, DO NOT ALLOW DUST TO ACCUMULATE ON CLOTHING. REFER TO CHAPTER 70-00-00, INSPECTION AND REPAIR FOR INFORMATION ABOUT BLENDING ROTATING COMPONENTS.Fan blades may be repaired if damage is not in excess of limits (Ref. Inspection).
Mask surfaces adjoining damaged areas using pressure sensitive tape (PWC05-069).

Blend out in a lengthwise direction nicks, scratches, pits and sharp edges using small hand files and stones. Finish blend using fine stones to ensure surface finish is restored to that of surrounding surface. Maintain a smooth transition to adjoining areas.
Blade LE and TE radii shall be restored by blending convex surface, and minimizing blending on the concave surface.
Repaired area depth shall be 1/3 deeper than the depth of the damage to ensure complete damage removal.
Where possible local repair of airfoil surface (area H) shall extend over an area five (5) times the depth of the damage.
The blade airfoil, LE and TE shall be repaired sufficiently to remove damage. Material removal shall be minimized to reduce the effect on fan balancing and engine performance.
Remove pressure sensitive tape and clean off any residual adhesive using alcohol (PWC11-014).

procedure.title: Lubrication (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: Engines must be serviceable in all respects for this limited instruction to be valid. Engines not in serviceable condition for continued operation must be repaired per the specific Maintenance Manual, Overhaul Manual or Engine Manual instructions.
Do this task during an unscheduled maintenance task due to suspected vibration.
procedure.step: Remove nose cone and install fan blade retaining ring (PWC62019). Turn the retaining ring and make sure that the gap to remove the blade is at the 12 o' clock position.
Install fan wedges (PWC66581) to prevent fan rotation during application of lubricant.
Remove fan blade from TDC position.
Apply antiseize compound (PWC06-004) on contact surfaces of fan blade roots.

LIGHTLY APPLY THE ANTISEIZE COMPOUND (PWC06-004) AND REMOVE THE EXCESS. THE ANTISEIZE COMPOUND HAS POTENTIAL TO BE INGESTED INTO ENGINE CORE.Install the fan blade and adjust retaining ring (PWC62019) to the next blade. Remove fan wedges (PWC66581) and turn the LP rotor balancing assembly to move the next blade to TDC position.
Repeat Steps thru until all the blade are coated.
Install fan nose cone (Ref. 72-30-01, LP COMPRESSOR - REMOVAL/INSTALLATION).
Do a engine ground run check (Ref. 71-00-00, ADJUSTMENT/TEST).

procedure.title: Repair of Cracks or Holes in Abradable Lining
procedure.step: Clean affected area f (Ref. Inspection) of contaminants or debris by scraping or sanding. Do not flush affected area with solvents as this tends to draw oil/grease into repair area. Abradable material is pale blue in color. Contaminant (black residue) removal is obvious when original color is obtained.
Blow off affected area with clean, oil free compressed air or nitrogen.

Mix EC-3524 B/A (PWC05-184) per following parts by weight (pbw) requirements. Weigh each material to the nearest gram of the specified amount. Mix enough to fill the repair area(s).
Base (Blue):100 pbw
Accelerator (White):94 pbw
Mix in a plastic or metal container using a plastic spatula, and to a uniform pale blue color.

Spread potting compound into repair area using a straight edge spatula. Make sure material completely bonds to the repair surface by working the material into the repair area until it darkens and moistens the existing surrounding material. Adequate bond will not occur if the potting compound is not worked into the repair area until it darkens and moistens the existing cured material surrounding the repaired area.
Make sure potting material is flush with adjacent surfaces, to maintain gas path profile.
Allow the repaired material to cure at room temperature 21°C (70°F) for 16 hours or cure at 66°C (150°F) for 2 hours.
Sand finish excess material using 400 grit to return to original gas path profile.

procedure.title: Line Maintenance Repair of Delamination of Abradable Lining
procedure.step: DO NOT DRILL INTO STAINLESS STEEL SHELL OF FAN CASE.Drill several holes 1/8 inch in diameter, 1 inch apart, through delaminated section. The holes must be not less than 1/2 inch from the leading edge of the abradable lining.
Inject silicone rubber compound (PWC09-017) into holes.
Apply light pressure to abradable to evenly spread compound under abradable.
Remove any excess material from surface of abradable.
Make sure holes are completely filled with silicone rubber compound.
Cure to manufacturer's instructions.

procedure.title: Heavy Maintenance Repair of Delamination of Abradable Lining
procedure.step: Remove delaminated piece of abradable material.
Repair abradable in accordance with repair procedure "Repair of Cracks or Holes in Abradable Lining" (using potting compound PWC05-184).

procedure.title: Repair of Cracks or Holes in Perforate Liner
procedure.step: Flush clean affected area with isopropyl alcohol (PWC11-014) or acetone (PWC11-012) or ardrox leeder 1064K (PWC11-023+) or desoclean 45 (PWC11-025+) or envirosolv 655 (PWC11-005+). Air dry for 30 minutes minimum at room temperature.

THE EA934NA MIXTURE MUST BE USED WITHIN 40 MINUTES AFTER MIXING.Mix EA934 NA (PWC08-016) per the following parts by weight (pbw) requirements. Weigh each material to the nearest gram of the specified amount. Mix enough to fill the repair area(s). Mix in a plastic container or metal container using a plastic spatula.
Part A:100 pbw
Part B:33 pbw
DO NOT BLOCK DRAIN CHANNEL AT BOTTOM DEAD CENTER OF CASE WHEN FILLING CRACKS AND DENTS IN PERFORATE.Fill a syringe with a suitable quantity of EA934NA mixture and inject repair area.
Inject the damaged area and the adjacent cells surrounding the damaged area.
Wipe excess mixture from perforated liner surface.
Allow 5-7 days at room temperature for full cure or 2-3 hours at 66°C (150°F) temperature using hot air gun.
Sand finish repaired area to ensure smooth and burr free surface using 400 grit sand paper.
Touch up any sanded perforate in Area h (Ref. Inspection) using anodize solution (PWC05-064).

procedure.title: Repair of Corrosion or Pitting on Mount Pads and External Surfaces (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Seal the oil passages, air holes and area around corroded surface.
Clean the corroded area. Refer inspection for acceptable limits.
Apply chromate solution (PWC11-019) or chrome pickle solution (PWC05-161) to the bare metal surfaces of intermediate case (Ref. 70-00-00, STANDARD PRACTICES - REPAIR).
Restore protective coating on painted surfaces (Ref. 70-00-00, STANDARD PRACTICES - REPAIR).

procedure.title: Restoration of Intermediate Case Struts Leading Edges damaged by Impact, Erosion or Corrosion with Material Loss (Pitting)
procedure.step: Place a suitable blank or debris collector to prevent ingress of debris into the compressor or any other openings.
Manual blend repair the corrosion or impact damage and treat reworked surface (Ref. 70-00-00, STANDARD PRACTICES - REPAIR). Refer inspection for acceptable limits.
Apply epoxy (PWC08-016A) or (PWC08-018A) to fill the impact damaged, eroded or corroded area. (Ref. 70-00-00, STANDARD PRACTICES - REPAIR).
Remove blank on completion and vacuum or wipe area to remove any remaining debris.

general.para: This section provides instructions and limits for inspection/check of the gas generator case assembly.
It is recommended that a magnifying glass of at least 10X power be used when visually inspecting for damage.
Within the following text, where the term nicks or dents is used, unless otherwise specified, blend repair limits are applicable provided at least 70 percent of original surface remains undamaged.
Parts found unsuitable for further engine running should be replaced. Rejected parts should be returned to Pratt & Whitney Canada for complete inspection and possible repair/refurbishment.

procedure.title: Check Diffuser Ducts (Fishtails)
procedure.step: Visually check for: Cracks, holes and weld integrity. No cracks permitted, replace any damaged ducts. Nicks or dents. Maximum of 10 acceptable to a depth of 0.003 inch (0.08 mm) provided nicks and/or dents separated by a minimum of 0.250 inch (6.4 mm) (two occurrences separated by a minimum of 0.100 inch (2.5 mm) is acceptable) and damage is removed by blending to a maximum depth of 0.005 inch (0.13 mm).

Check torque of duct retaining bolts. Torque as necessary 32 to 36 lb.in. (3.6-4.0 Nm). If torque value is not achieved, replace Helicoil insert with oversize inserts as necessary (Ref. 70-00-00, STANDARD PRACTICES).

procedure.title: Check Diffuser Heat Shield
procedure.step:
Visually check: Nicks, burrs and raised metal. Stone to remove raised metal or sharp edges. Local wear or damage is acceptable to a maximum depth of 0.005 inch provided wear or damage occurs circumferentially.
MAKE SURE DRILL DOES NOT DAMAGE DIFFUSER CASE.Cracks. Vee out crack(s) using a suitable abrasive wheel. Stop drill where practical using a 1/16 inch drill.
Shield assembly with damage in excess of above limits must be replaced.

procedure.title: Check Diffuser Case
procedure.step: Visually check for cracks. No cracks permitted.

n-para.title: Combustion Chamber Outer Case (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The combustion chamber outer case consists of a nickel-alloy weldment with the front flange bolted to the gas generator case (Flange H). The rear flange is bolted to the low pressure turbine case (Flange E) and supports the high pressure turbine stator support.

Bosses on the conical section at the 4 and 5 o'clock positions provide for the insertion of spark igniters, while 24 equally spaced bosses slightly forward of the igniters provide for fuel nozzle adapters. Fuel nozzle bosses at the 4 and 5 o'clock positions provide for two hybrid-type fuel nozzles. Bosses at the 3 and 9 o'clock positions toward the front end of the case provide an offtake for P3 cabin bleed air.
A drain hole towards the front of the conical section at the 6 o'clock position allows residual fuel to drain overboard through the drain valve.

n-para.title: Combustion Chamber Liner (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The combustion chamber liner is a straight-through annular type, consisting of a nickel-alloy weldment and is contained by the combustion chamber outer case. Twenty-four fuel nozzle sleeves are equally spaced around the domed end, along with two spark igniter suspension collars located at the 4 and 5 o'clock positions.

A series of perforations allow air to enter the liner in a manner designated to provide the best fuel/air ratios for engine starting and sustained combustion with minimum exhaust smoke. Direction of airflow, uniform wall cooling and extended durability is provided by cooling rings, while a conical heatshield, secured in place with 3 bolts to the gas generator case, provides extra thermal protection for the No. 3 bearing area.
The combustion chamber liner is supported at the domed end by the fuel nozzles and by means of a flexible support bolted to the HP turbine stator.

general.para: The following section describes the removal and installation of the combustion chamber outer case, combustion chamber liner and the first-stage HP turbine vane assembly. These procedures can only be done during Heavy Maintenance.
Lubricate preformed packings, threads and mating surfaces with engine oil unless otherwise stated.
Install protective caps and plugs on disconnected tubes, component openings and electrical connectors after disassembly.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.
Refer to INTRODUCTION for alternate products, suppliers and suppliers addresses.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

Insert one

MAKE SURE ALL THE NOZZLES ARE ALIGNED CORRECTLY. MAKE SURE ALL FUEL NOZZLE GASKETS ARE CORRECTLY INSTALLED IN LINER BEFORE TORQUING OF FUEL NOZZLE NUTS.Torque bolts (8 and 10) 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm) at 48 places.

Do a leak check of the fuel manifold and nozzles (Ref. Adjustment/Test).
