procedure.title: Application of Sealant (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: Inner Bypass Duct Fairings - Application of Sealant

procedure.step: Remove any remaining original sealant from the fairing assemblies (3) with a suitable non-metallic scraper.
Clean area a adjacent to the gap with isopropyl alcohol (PWC11-014).
Apply sealant (PWC09-019) at area a to fill the gap all around the fairing assemblies (3).
If necessary, moisten finger with water and gently smooth out the sealant.

procedure.title: Visual Check
procedure.step:
Inspect upper and lower outer by-pass duct upper and lower for: Cracks: No cracks are permitted. Nicks or dents: Acceptable, with blending to a maximum depth of 0.010 inch (0.25 mm). Loose or damaged rivets: Replace as necessary. Anchor nut security and rundown torque: Replace if loose or rundown torque is not within limits specified (Ref. 70-00-00, STANDARD PRACTICES). Inspect the rear engine mount as follows (Ref. Fig. ): Measure the clearance between the face of the bonded inner member and link as shown in Fig. . The inner member should protrude above the link a minimum of 0.030 inch (0.76 mm) to a maximum of 0.108 inch (2.7 mm). If the dimensions are outside the limits, send the part back for refurbishment.
Inspection of the Rear Engine Mount

Inspect inner by-pass duct fairings for: Cracks up to a maximum length of 1.500 in. (38.10 mm) may be stop drilled more than once. Converging cracks or cracks with the potential for material loss are not acceptable. Cracks starting at a free edge are acceptable up to a maximum length of 1.500 in. (38.10 mm) if they are stop drilled with a 0.125 in. (3.18 mm) dia. drill. Cracks starting in a nut plate are acceptable up to a maximum length of 1.500 in. (38.10 mm) if they are stop drilled with a 0.125 in. (3.18 mm) dia. drill. Cracks starting at a bolt hole location are acceptable up to a maximum length of 1.500 in. (38.10 mm) if they are stop drilled with a 0.125 in. (3.18 mm) dia. drill. Nicks or dents are acceptable, with blending to a maximum depth of 0.005 inch (0.13 mm). Replace loose or damaged rivets or fasteners as necessary.

Inspect BOV cover and remaining inner by-pass ducts for: Cracks up to a maximum length of 2.000 in. (50.80 mm) may be stop drilled more than once. Converging cracks or cracks with the potential for material loss are not acceptable. Cracks starting at a free edge are acceptable up to a maximum length of 2.000 in. (50.80 mm) if they are stop drilled with a 0.125 in. (3.18 mm) dia. drill. Cracks starting in a nut plate are acceptable up to a maximum length of 2.000 in. (50.80 mm) if they are stop drilled with a 0.125 in. (3.18 mm) dia. drill. Cracks starting from the air scoops are acceptable up to a maximum length of 2.000 in. (50.80 mm) if they are stop drilled with a 0.125 in. (3.18 mm) dia. drill. Cracks starting at a bolt hole location are acceptable up to a maximum length of 2.000 in. (50.80 mm) if they are stop drilled with a 0.125 in. (3.18 mm) dia. drill. Nicks or dents are acceptable, with blending to a maximum depth of 0.005 inch (0.13 mm). Replace loose or damaged rivets or fasteners as necessary.
Inspect Nut plates: Damaged anchor nuts are acceptable provided one of the nuts is secure and meets rundown torque requirements (Ref. 70-00-00, STANDARD PRACTICES).

Inspect rear outer by-pass duct: It is acceptable to operate engines with some or all of this filler missing. Rear outer by-pass duct rubberized coating bubbling in localized area is acceptable. Open areas where the base material is exposed must be repaired to protect underlying layers from contaminants. Local surface damage of 0.005 in. (0.12 mm) deep maximum on internal surfaces is serviceable. Remove only raised material. It is acceptable to operate engines with some or all filler material missing on rear mount flange inner surface. Local surface damage of 0.005 in. (0.12 mm) deep maximum on mating surface is serviceable. Remove only raised material. Local surface damage of 0.005 in. (0.12 mm) deep maximum on flange bolt holes is serviceable. Remove only raised material.

n-para.title: Repair of Rear Outer Bypass Duct

procedure.title: Repair of Delamination between Inner/Outer Rubber Layer and Fabric
procedure.note: It is acceptable to operate the engine with the outer rear bypass duct rubberized coating bubbling in localized areas; however, open areas where the base material is exposed should be repaired to protect underlying layers from contaminants.
procedure.step: Cut the outer layers to obtain access to delaminated area.
Mix a two-part mix of high temperature sealant (PWC09-025) (Ref. Sealant Manufacturer's Instructions).
Inject sealant mixture (PWC09-025) into the delaminated areas. Spread into full area beneath delaminated layer.
Make sure space between layers is completely filled with sealant.
Apply light pressure to the layers with a suitable teflon or nylon scraper to evenly spread compound and remove the entrapped air.
Apply sealant mixture (PWC09-025) over the cut areas of the outer layers to seal the repair.
Remove any excess material from outer layer surface.
Cure the repair areas for 40 minutes or in accordance with sealant manufacturer's curing instructions.

procedure.title: Repair of Filler Material on Rear Mount Flange Inner Surface (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: Rear Outer Bypass Duct - Application of Sealant

procedure.step: Remove any loose material.
Thoroughly clean area with wire brush to remove any residual sealant and prepare for bonding.
Fill area b with sealant (PWC09-001A) (Ref. Standard Practices Manual).
Visually check condition of sealant and touch up holes as necessary.

module.pageblock-title: FUEL AND CONTROL - DESCRIPTION AND OPERATION

n-para.title: Engine Control System - General (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: PW306A engine thrust is controlled by a dual channel full authority digital electronic control (FADEC) which regulates low rotor (fan) speed N1 in response to a pilot-operated Thrust Lever (TL). Main control system components are the Thrust Lever (TL), Electronic Engine Control (EEC) and the Hydromechanical Fuel Control Unit (HFCU or HMU).

The Thrust Lever (TL) is the pilot-demanded set point for the control system. Thrust Lever Angle (TLA) is converted to an electrical signal by a Rotary Variable Differential Transformer (RVDT) position transducer and sent to the EEC as its set point.

The EEC is the electronic “brain” of the control system. The EEC performs thrust management, compressor surge control, high and low pressure compressor rotor overspeed protection (N2 and N1 O/S PROT).
Provision is made for installation of an airframe-supplied fuel flowmeter located between the HMU and the dump valve.

n-para.title: Engine Fuel System - General (Ref. Figs. and )
n-para.para:
The basic fuel system is comprised of the following units:
Hydromechanical fuel control unit (HFCU or HMU).
Engine-driven, two-stage cartridge-style fuel pump mounted in the HMU.
Fuel filter.
Fuel/oil heat exchanger.
Start/dump valve.
Fuel waste ejector.
Fuel shutoff valve.
Fuel manifold containing 22 main fuel nozzles and 2 hybrid nozzles.
Motive flow valve.

n-para.title: Electronic Engine Control (EEC) (Ref. Figs. thru )

figure.title: EEC Interface Block Diagram (One of Two Channels Shown)
EEC Power Sources, Automatic Transfer and Electronic Overspeed Protection - Block Diagram

n-para.para: Determination of correct N1 value is accomplished within the EEC. This module features two independent channels - either of which can fully control the engine. Should one channel become impaired e.g.: sensor fault, control is automatically transferred to the healthier channel. If both channels are impaired, engine control is achieved at reduced capacity.
Thrust lever angle (TLA) is sensed by the EEC and fuel flow (Wf) to the engine is regulated by electrical commands to the HFCU such that actual N1 value matches calculate required value.
Figure illustrates in block form how engine and airframe interface with one of two identical channels.

subpara.title: Calculation of Required N1 (Ref. Fig. )
subpara.para: Calculated required N1 is dependent on:

subpara.title: Thrust Lever Angle (TLA)
subpara.para: TLA is conveyed to each EEC channel via separate rotary variable differential transformer (RVDT) position transducers excited by EEC.

subpara.title: Pilot Select and Airframe Discretes
subpara.para: These digital inputs are switches, either pilot-actuated to select operating modes for EEC, or airframe-actuated status indications to condition programming within EEC.

subpara.title: Sensors
subpara.para: Several sensors send analog feedback signals to the EEC.

subpara.title: Pneumatic Signals
subpara.para: Raw pneumatic signals (P1 and P3) are sensed by the EEC and are converted to electrical signals within the EEC.

subpara.title: Engine Trims
subpara.para: Trims provide means of compensating for sensing error and standardizing indicated engine parameters.

subpara.title: N1 and N2 Electronic Overspeed Protection (Ref. Figs. and )
subpara.para: Four electronic overspeed protection systems (two software and two hardware) are provided for the two rotors:

subpara.chgdesc: The instruction for software overspeed protection (SW O/S PROT) has been revised.
subpara.title: Software Overspeed Protection (SW O/S PROT)
subpara.para: Each rotor is protected by two independent EEC software overspeed systems. The EEC will not permit speed of N1 and N2 engine rotors to exceed 105%, with transients to 106% up to 20 seconds during normal operation. If the speed of one of the two rotors exceeds 108%, the EEC software will send an engine trip command to the overspeed shutdown logic (Ref. Step ).

subpara.title: Hardware Overspeed Protection (HW O/S PROT)
subpara.para: Each rotor is also protected by two hardware shutdowns physically located within EEC but independent of EEC software. Should 110% be attained by either rotor, HW O/S PROT will send trip command to overspeed shutdown logic (Ref. step (3), following).

subpara.title: Overspeed Shutdown Logic
subpara.para: To prevent engine tripping due to malfunction of a single channel, two or more channels must have tripped and, of these channels, at least one must be a HW O/S PROT channel. If overspeed logic demands an engine trip via the overspeed solenoid (Ref. Fig. ), the EEC software will command Wf metering valve (MV) to close as a backup to the overspeed solenoid.

subpara.title: Normal Shutdown (Ref. Fig. )
subpara.para: Preferred shutdown is effected by simultaneous switch closures on both channel A and B discrete inputs “Normal Shutdown Hardware”. This will depress HW O/S PROT datums, therefore simulating overspeed. The EEC will then energize both coils of the overspeed solenoid in the HMU (Ref. Fig. ) to ultimately stop burn fuel flow. Upon initiation of normal shutdown, EEC main control (software) is simultaneously informed that HW O/S PROT's are attempting to shut down the engine. Both main controls will thus expect to see N2 decreasing; if after 5 seconds this does not occur, main control of the channel in control will close Wf metering valve (MV) in the HMU to terminate burn fuel flow.

subpara.title: Standby Shutdown (Ref. Fig. )
subpara.para: Standby shutdown provides an alternative means of shutting down the engine which is independent of EEC action. If the pilot selects this method of shutdown (via fire handle), power is directly applied to the shutdown solenoid in the HMU. Action of the overspeed solenoid to terminate burn fuel flow is described in Para.

subpara.title: Power Supplies to EEC (Ref. Fig. )
subpara.para: The EEC is normally supplied by a single engine-driven, dual winding, three phase permanent magnet alternator (PMA) mounted directly on the accessory gearbox (AGB). Each PMA winding supplies power to an EEC channel. Within each channel, PMA supply is rectified, then fed to two regulators. One regulator feeds the main power supply for EEC main control (software); the other feeds the power supply for hardware overspeed protection (HW O/S PROT).

For each channel, a voltage sensing circuit monitors incoming source to source to main power supply. For Channel A only, if the source is less than 18 VDC, main control A is automatically switched to airframe 28 VDC Bus 2. HW O/S PROT A is simultaneously switched to airframe 28 VDC Bus 1. For Channel B, when source is less than 18 VDC, both main control B and HW O/S PROT B are automatically switched over to airframe Bus 1.
Airframe busses are normal supplies for engine starting and act as back-up sources in event of loss of PMA-derived power.

n-para.title: Hydromechanical Fuel Control Unit (HFCU or HMU) (Ref. Figs. and )
n-para.para: The HMU is an electro-hydraulic transducer which changes EEC electrical signals to fuel flow. The HFCU regulates burn fuel flow, positions HP compressor inlet variable geometry, shuts down the engine during normal and abnormal circumstances and provides high and low fuel pressure protection.

subpara.title: Regulation of Burn Flow
subpara.para: Aircraft boost pump(s) supply fuel to an engine-driven two stage, cartridge-style pump inserted into the HFCU body. LP fuel from the first (centrifugal) stage passes through an external 10 micron filter, then returns to the inlet of the second (vane) stage of the fuel pump. HP fuel leaving the second-stage is routed to the Wf metering valve (MV). HP fuel is also supplied to a servo pressure regulator. EEC output (fuel demand) is, in effect, an MV position demand. The EEC electrical signal drives a torquemotor within the Wf controller which, in turn, positions a spool valve. Regulated servo pressure is then converted into two hydraulic signals which position MV. Wf controller has redundant windings - one for Channel A, the other Channel B. Either will modulate servo pressure to position MV. There is no mechanical minimum flow position for MV; Minimum position is dictated by EEC software.

Temperature compensation is effected within the MV by a valve and ported sleeve. A linear variable differential transformer (LVDT)-type transducer feeds MV position back to the EEC. Excitation power for LVDT is provided by the EEC.

To keep the relationship between EEC demand and resultant fuel flow constant regardless of fuel pump pressure variation, pressure differential across the MV is held constant by the spill valve. HP fuel from the upstream side of the MV is spilled so as to maintain 50 psid above downstream pressure. Spilled fuel passes through the fuel/oil heat exchanger where it is warmed by heat rejected from engine oil. Spill fuel then passes through the fuel filter before it enters the inlet of the fuel pumps second-stage.

subpara.title: Positioning of HP Compressor Geometry
subpara.para: Variable Inlet Guide Vanes (VIGV) and first-stage variable stators (1VS) are mechanically linked together and are automatically positioned to achieve peak compressor efficiency without encountering compressor surge. Optimum vane angle is computed by the EEC in response to certain sensors, pneumatic feedbacks and discretes (Ref. Fig. ) and is sent to HFCU as an electrical signal. This VIGV/1VS position demand signal energizes one of two windings of the VIGV/1VS controller (A or B, whichever EEC channel is controlling). This torquemotor valve alters the two hydraulic signals going to the VIGV/IVS actuator. The resultant differential pressure across the actuator vanes drives the actuator output shaft. A rotary variable differential transformer (RVDT)-type position transducer feeds back actuator position to EEC. When feedback matches demand, the controller equalizes the hydraulic signals and actuator movement ceases. Hydraulic signals are derived from regulated servo pressure.

subpara.title: Engine Shutdown
subpara.para: Preferred engine shutdown is by electronic overspeed simulation. This will energize the overspeed solenoid which redatums the high pressure relief valve (HPRV) such that it relieves at a lower pressure than minimum pressure valve (MPV) setting, causing MPV to close and fuel flow to engine nozzles to terminate.

If the pilot elects to stop the engine without utilizing EEC, a standby shutdown (via fire lever) is available which will directly energize the shutdown solenoid. This redatums the spill valve such that all flow passes through it. System pressure then falls below MPV set point; MPV closes and fuel flow to engine nozzles is terminated.

subpara.title: Underpressure and Overpressure Protection
subpara.para: All metered flow passes through the Minimum Pressure Valve (MPV) before it leaves the HFCU enroute to the fuel nozzles. This valve ensures that fuel pressure within the HFCU is high enough (300 psid) to allow proper functioning of HFCU hydraulic circuits. If minimum pressure is not maintained, MPV closes fully to terminate burn fuel flow. A tapping from MPV supplies lightoff (primary) fuel to the two hybrid fuel nozzles.
A high pressure relief valve (HPRV) is incorporated to fully open at 1310 psid to prevent overstressing HFCU and fuel pump by bypassing fuel back to the inlet of the fuel pump's second stage.

n-para.title: Fuel Pump (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: 25290: The fuel pump is a cartridge-type unit which can be extracted from the HMU without disassembly.
25290: The fuel pump is an integral part of HMU. Do not try to remove/re-install the fuel pump from 25290 HMU's.

The pump uses a high pressure vane stage and a centrifugal boost stage. Power is received from the Accessory Gearbox (AGB) by a coupling shaft driving the HP rotor/shaft which, in turn, drives the centrifugal pump.

n-para.title: Fuel Manifold (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The fuel manifold distributes secondary fuel to the engine combustion chamber and consists of 1 inlet fuel nozzle, 21 secondary fuel nozzles, 2 hybrid (primary and secondary) fuel nozzles and interconnecting transfer tubes.

Secondary fuel is admitted to the fuel manifold via the single inlet fuel nozzle. The inlet fuel nozzle and the 21 secondary fuel nozzles are simple air blast fuel atomizers, relying on the flow of P3 air through the combustion chamber liner for atomization.

The 2 hybrid fuel nozzles are located adjacent to the 2 engine igniter plugs and are basically secondary fuel nozzles modified to also admit primary fuel. The hybrid nozzles atomize primary fuel using fuel pressure and secondary fuel using air blast.

Primary fuel is supplied to the hybrid nozzles by a separate stainless steel fuel line, originating at the lower bypass duct next to the inlet fuel nozzle and running along the combustor outer case, adjacent to the secondary fuel manifold. Primary fuel flow remains on during normal engine operation.

n-para.title: Start and Fuel Dump Valve (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The fuel dump valve assembly is mounted with the fuel shut-off mechanism at the 6 o'clock position on the outer bypass duct. The function of the dump valve is to deliver metered fuel to the primary and secondary fuel manifolds and to dump residual fuel from the manifolds into the fuel waste ejector at engine shut down. The dump valve consists of a valve operating in a ported sleeve, held in the closed or dump position by a spring loaded piston. Five fuel flow connections are provided on the dump valve housing. The primary and secondary outlet ports are on the top face, while primary and secondary inlet ports are located on one side face. A dump port is located on the bottom face.

A starting fuel solenoid valve is integrated into the assembly, which schedules the supply of primary fuel from the HFCU to the hybrid nozzles during the starting cycle. During engine start-up, primary fuel is delivered by the HFCU to the primary inlet port. After light-up, when T4.5 reaches a preset temperature in the EEC, primary fuel is cut-off and the primary inlet port is connected to the secondary fuel, which now supplies fuel to both primary and secondary inlet ports. When the start valve is de-energized by the EEC, fuel is supplied to the hybrid nozzles by the secondary fuel supply. At engine shut down, fuel pressure ceases and spring pressure moves the valve to block the inlet ports. The dump port is now open to allow residual fuel in the manifold to drain to the fuel waste ejector.

n-para.title: Fuel Waste Ejector (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The fuel waste ejector is mounted at the 6 o'clock position on the engine, below the fuel dump valve. The waste ejector consists of a tank with inlet and outlet connections and a vent. The tank contains non-return valves, a motive flow ejector pump, a strainer and a float operated drain valve. The function of the waste ejector is to reduce atmospheric pollution and reduce fuel waste by returning fuel from the fuel dump valve to the fuel pump inlet as burn fuel.

During engine operation, LP fuel from the HFCU is ported to the inlet of the waste ejector; the fuel flow through the unit creates a venturi effect at the bottom of the ejector. When a sufficient amount of fuel from previous shutdowns has drained into the tank assembly the float will rise, causing a valve to unseat from an orifice. Fuel pressure acting on top of the orifice assembly together with the pressure drop at the bottom, opens a non-return valve located at the bottom of the orifice. Fuel is then drawn from the tank and conveyed to the inlet side of the fuel pump. When the tank fuel level drops, the float moves down and the orifice is covered by the valve. The non-return valve then closes, preventing fuel from the HFCU from entering the tank via the orifice.

n-para.title: Motive Flow Valve
n-para.para: 25290: The motive flow valve is bolted on the HFCU.
25290: The motive flow valve is an integral part of HMU. Do not try to remove/re-install the motive flow valve from 25290 HMU's.

The valve is a pressure regulator component which controls the high pressure fuel flow from the engine-driven fuel pump and route the fuel back to the ejector pump in the aircraft fuel tank. An EEC controlled solenoid is integrated in the motive flow system to control the on/off operation of the valve. A switch in the cockpit however, can over-ride the operation of the valve through the EEC.
Fuel Waste Ejector

subpara.title: Emergency Fuel Shut-off Actuating Mechanism

figure.title: Emergency Fuel Shut-off Valve and Actuating Mechanism

subpara.para: In the event of LP turbine shaft breakage (shear), the resultant axial rearward displacement of the shaft will actuate an automatic trigger mechanism which, via levers and cables, will actuate the fuel shut-off valve to terminate secondary fuel flow to the fuel manifold and thus prevent overspeed of the LP turbine assembly.

During normal operation, the actuating rod of the trigger mechanism is in close proximity to the LP turbine shaft. Actuating rod position is mechanically translated to normal (open) position on the fuel shut-off valve.

subpara.title: Fuel Shutoff Valve
subpara.para: In the normal position, fuel passes to the fuel manifold through the inlet port in the fuel shut-off valve piston assembly. A set of spring washers loaded against the piston seat, keeps the piston firmly butted against the head of the release plate. The release plate is restrained by shoulders formed on the inner faces of two pivoted control levers. These levers are prevented from moving apart by a counterbore in the head of cup-shaped tripper sleeve assembly, which engages the tips of the levers. A spring which encircles the tripper sleeve assembly bears against a circumferential shoulder on the tripper sleeve at one end and against the cover at the other end. Mating mirror-image profiles on the inner faces of the control levers afford clearance for a pin installed diametrically across the open end of the tripper sleeve.

A lug formed on the head of the tripper sleeve projects through the cover to connect with the overspeed control lever, which forms the final element of a mechanical linkage between the fuel shut-off valve and the overspeed actuating rod installed in the exhaust case.

Axial rearward displacement of the turbine shaft acts through mechanical linkages to draw the tripper sleeve against the compression spring. If this movement exceeds the permitted amount, the counterbore of the tripper sleeve is drawn clear of the tips of the pivoted cam surfaces of the pivoted control levers, and rotates the levers on their pivots. This allows the release plate to pass between the control levers as the shut-off valve piston moves to the right under the action of the spring washers and fuel pressure.

Displacement of the shut-off valve piston carries the inlet port out of register with the fuel passage in the fuel manifold inlet, substituting a second port which is closed at the outlet side by the shut-off valve. Fuel pressure acting on the stem of the valve presses it firmly against the open end of the delivery passage to cut off flow to the fuel manifold.
The fuel shut-off valve is not self-resetting.

n-para.title: Wiring Harnesses (Ref. Figs. thru )
n-para.para: Three separate wiring harnesses are utilized on the PW306A engine; the Rear Core, the Front Core and the Outer Wiring Harnesses.
Pin/socket arrangement for connectors is shown on Figure and Tables and . Similar connectors are keyed to ensure correct installation of harness to end device.

subpara.title: Rear Core Harness (Ref. Fig. )
subpara.para: The rear core harness consists of three separate multi-conductor leads protected by flexible and rigid conduit. These conductors bring N1 speed sensing signals and T45 thermocouple outputs from the N1/T45 terminal box mounted on the right side of the engine on Flange E to two separate receptacles (J27 and J28) mounted on the outer bypass duct i.e. the harness connects engine rear core (internal) devices to external receptacles.

subpara.title: Front Core Harness (Ref. Fig. )
subpara.para: The front core harness connects front core (internal) devices to two external receptacles mounted on the outer bypass duct on either side of the engine.
Quick-disconnect connectors are used at end devices and, where necessary, are keyed to ensure correct connection of the harness to end devices.
The harness is suitably insulated, shielded and overbraided for mechanical protection.

subpara.title: Outer Wiring Harness (Ref. Fig. )
subpara.para:
The outer wiring harness consists of a complex cable assembly which connects the front and rear harnesses to engine components outside the outer bypass duct and interfaces with the airframe. It is suitably insulated, shielded and is equipped with quick-disconnects for each end device.

general.para: Lubricate preformed packings, threads and mating surfaces with engine oil unless otherwise stated.
Install protective caps and plugs on disconnected tubes, component openings and electrical connectors after disassembly.

DO NOT LUBRICATE NUTS. Install fuel tube (2) with two
bolts (17) F24FB20-12 2 and two
nuts (5) F24FN05-08 2 . Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm). Torque nuts 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1-3.4 Nm).

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Remove
nut (13) F24FN05-04 1 ,
bolt (11) F24FB20-07 1 and
loop clamp (12) F24FC07-02 1 (Ref. View C).

Remove
nut (17) F24FN05-10 1 ,
bolt (15) F24FB20-13 1 and
loop clamp (27) F23EC07-15 1 (Ref. View D).

Remove two
bolts (5) F24FB20-06 2 and two
bolts (19) F24FB20-05 2 .

Remove
fuel bypass tube (2) F50FT17A01 1 from engine and discard preformed packings
(6) F24FP03-05 1 and
(18) F24FP03-05 1 .

Remove
nut (7) F23EN05-10 1 ,
bolt (9) F23EB20-10 1 and
loop clamp (8) F23EC07-14 1 (Ref. View B).

Remove
nut (23) F24FN05-05 1 ,
bolt (21) F24FB20-08 1 and
loop clamps (20) F24FC07-03 1 (Ref. View F).

Remove two
bolts (3) F24FB20-09 2 and two
nuts (25) F24FN05-05 2 .

Remove
fuel bypass tube (1) F50FT17A02 1 from engine and discard preformed packings
(4) F24FP03-06 1 and
(24) F24FP03-06 1 .

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Lubricate new
(4) F24FP03-06 1 and
(24) F24FP03-06 1 and install on
fuel bypass tube (1) F50FT17A02 1 .

DO NOT LUBRICATE NUTS. Install fuel bypass tube (1) using
bolts (3) F24FB20-09 2 and two
nuts (25) F24FN05-05 2 . Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm). Torque nuts 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).

Install
loop clamp (8) F23EC07-14 1 with
bolt (9) F23EB20-10 1 and
nut (7) F23EN05-10 1 (Ref. View B). Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).

DO NOT LUBRICATE NUTS. Install two
loop clamps (20) F24FC07-03 1 with
bolt (21) F24FB20-08 1 and
nut (23) F24FN05-05 1 (Ref. View F). Torque 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).

Lubricate new performed packings
(6) F24FP03-05 1 and
(18) F24FP03-05 1 and install on
fuel bypass tube (2) F50FT17A01 1 . Install fuel bypass tube on engine with two bolts
(5) F24FB20-06 2 and
(19) F24FB20-05 2 . Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).

Install
loop clamp (12) F24FC07-02 1 with
bolt (11) F24FB20-07 1 and
nut (13) F24FN05-04 1 (Ref. View C). Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).

DO NOT LUBRICATE NUTS. Install loop lamps
(14) F24FC07-05 1 and
(27) F23EC07-15 1 with
bolt (15) F24FB20-13 1 and
nut (17) F24FN05-10 1 (Ref. View D). Torque 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Remove
nut (7) F24FN05-11 1 ,
bolt (5) F24FB20-27 1 and
loop clamps (6) F24FC07-07 F24FC07-09 1,1 .

Remove
nut (17) F24FN05-11 1 ,
bolt (16) F24FB20-16 1 and
loop clamp (18) F24FC07-08 1 .

Remove bolts
(13) F24FB20-18 2 and
(10) F24FB20-17 2 and remove
fuel pressure tube (1) F50FT17A07 1 . Discard preformed packings
(11) F24FP03-14 1 and
(14) F24FP03-13 1 .

Remove
fuel strainer (15) F50FS51A02 F50FS51A01 1,1 .

DIRT MUST NOT ENTER THE FUEL SYSTEM. TAKE ALL NECESSARY PRECAUTIONS TO AVOID INGRESS OF FOREIGN MATERIAL. WHEREVER POSSIBLE, INSTALL PROTECTIVE CAPS OR PLUGS ON ALL EXPOSED OPENINGS BEFORE REMOVING THE FUEL TUBES.Remove bolts
(3) F24FB20-15 2 and
(8) F24FB20-14 2 and remove
fuel pressure tube (4) F50FT17A05 1 . Discard preformed packings
(2) F24FP03-12 1 and
(9) F24FP03-11 1 .
Remove fuel strainer (15).

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Lubricate new preformed packings
(2) F24FP03-12 1 and
(9) F24FP03-11 1 with engine oil (PWC03-001) and install on
fuel pressure tube (4) F50FT17A05 1 .

Install
fuel strainer (15) F50FS51A02 F50FS51A01 1,1 .

Install fuel pressure tube (4) with bolts
(3) F24FB20-15 2 and
(8) F24FB20-14 2 . Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).

Lubricate new preformed packings
(11) F24FP03-14 1 and
(14) F24FP03-13 1 with engine oil (PWC03-001) and install on
fuel pressure tube (1) F50FT17A07 1 .
Install fuel strainer (15).

Install fuel pressure tube (1) with bolts
(10) F24FB20-17 2 and
(13) F24FB20-18 2 . Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).

DO NOT LUBRICATE NUTS. Install two
loop clamps (6) F24FC07-07 F24FC07-09 1,1 with
bolt (5) F24FB20-27 1 and
nut (7) F24FN05-11 1 . Torque 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.10-3.4 Nm).

Install
loop clamp (18) F24FC07-08 1 to bracket (15) and secure with
bolt (16) F24FB20-16 1 and
nut (17) F24FN05-11 1 . Torque 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).

procedure.title: Restrictor Installation Procedure
procedure.step: Insert restrictor body U into bore of tube assy V until fully seated on shoulder AG
Drive expander pin W into bore of restrictor body U until exposed end of W and exposed end of U are flush ± .005 in. (0.127mm)
Ends of body U and pin W are to be flush or under surface of tube assy V after installation.

general.para: Lubricate preformed packings, threads and mating surfaces with engine oil unless otherwise stated.
Install protective caps and plugs on disconnected tubes, component openings and electrical connectors after dis-assembly.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.

n-para.title: Fuel Pump
n-para.caution: THE FUEL PUMP AND MOTIVE FLOW VALVE MUST BE REMOVED/REINSTALLED FROM 25290 HMU'S ONLY. 25290 HMU'S HAVE AN INTEGRAL FUEL PUMP AND MOTIVE FLOW VALVE. DO NOT TRY TO REMOVE FUEL PUMP AND/OR MOTIVE FLOW VALVE FROM 25290 HMU'S.

procedure.title: Removal (25290) (Ref. Fig. )

key.def: Fuel Tube (Fuel Waste Ejector Return to Fuel Pump)

procedure.step: DIRT MUST NOT ENTER THE FUEL SYSTEM. TAKE ALL NECESSARY PRECAUTIONS TO AVOID INGRESS OF FOREIGN MATERIAL. WHEREVER POSSIBLE, INSTALL PROTECTIVE CAPS OR PLUGS ON ALL EXPOSED OPENINGS.Disconnect airframe fuel supply from fuel pump inlet (Ref. Airframe Maintenance Manual) and cap openings.
Remove lockwire and loosen coupling nut (3).

Remove four
bolts (14) F50FB20-03 4 and
washers (13) F50FW03-13 4 .

Install two jacking screws (thread size 0.250-28 UNJF) in flange of
fuel pump (11) F23BP32-01 1 (Ref. View A).

DIRT MUST NOT ENTER THE FUEL SYSTEM. TAKE ALL NECESSARY PRECAUTIONS TO AVOID INGRESS OF FOREIGN MATERIAL. WHEREVER POSSIBLE, INSTALL PROTECTIVE CAPS OR PLUGS ON ALL EXPOSED OPENINGS BEFORE REMOVING THE FUEL PUMP. USE CARE WHEN REMOVING FUEL PUMP, SO THAT NO DAMAGE OCCURS TO FLANGE OF FUEL PUMP OR MATING SURFACE OF HMU.Remove fuel pump from HMU (1) by turning jacking screws inwards.

MAKE SURE NOT TO DAMAGE THE GEAR SHAFT SPLINE AND RETAINING CLIP.If fuel pump driveshaft disconnects from fuel pump, remove the fuel pump driveshaft from AGB gearshaft. Make sure not to damage the gearshaft spline and retaining clip.

Remove and discard preformed packings
(5) F50FP03-01 1 ,
(6) F50FP03-02 1 ,
(7) F50FP03-03 1 ,
(9) F50FP03-04 1 , and
(10) F50FP03-05 1 and
packing retainer (8) F50FR03-03 1 . The fuel pump driveshaft preformed packing (5) may have been removed as part of HMU removal (Ref. 73-20-01, HYDROMECHANICAL METERING UNIT - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES).

25290: The fuel pump is an integral part of the 25290 hydromechanical fuel control unit. Removal of the fuel pump from the 25290 HMU is not required, however removal of fuel pump driveshaft packing is required (Ref. 73-20-01, HYDROMECHANICAL METERING UNIT (HMU) - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES).

Remove
nipple (16) F50FN02-02 1 and discard
preformed packing (15) F50FP03-06 1 .

procedure.title: Installation (25290) (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install new
preformed packing (15) F50FP03-06 1 on
nipple (16) F50FN02-02 1 and install nipple in
fuel pump (11) F23BP32-01 1 . Torque 65 to 75 lb.in. (7.5-8.5 Nm).

25290: The fuel pump is an integral part of the 25290 hydromechanical fuel control unit. Installation of the fuel pump in the 25290 HMU is not required, however installation of a new fuel pump driveshaft packing is required before HMU installation (Ref. 73-20-01, HYDROMECHANICAL METERING UNIT (HMU) - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES).

Lubricate new preformed packings
(5) F50FP03-01 1 ,
(6) F50FP03-02 1 ,
(7) F50FP03-03 1 ,
(9) F50FP03-04 1 and
(10) F50FP03-05 1 and
packing retainer (8) F50FR03-03 1 with engine oil (PWC03-001) and install on fuel pump.

If fuel pump driveshaft has separated from fuel pump assembly, install the fuel pump driveshaft to the fuel pump assembly. Before assembly inspect as follows: Inspect drive shaft spline. Inspect the retaining clip. Examine for any sign or wear. Replace with new preformed packing (17). Preformed packing (17) is not supplied by P&WC, refer to CMM 73-10-02 (Vickers).
Align locating pin (2) on HMU interface with hole (12) in fuel pump flange. Carefully insert fuel pump into HMU.

Attach fuel pump with four
bolts (14) F50FB20-03 4 and
washers (13) F50FW03-13 4 . Torque 85 to 95 lbf.in. (9.6 - 10.7 Nm).

Connect fuel waste ejector return
tube (4) F50FT17A14 1 to fuel pump (11) with coupling nut (3). Torque 90 to 100 lb.in. (10.2-11.3 Nm) and lockwire (PWC05-089).

n-para.title: Adjustment/Test
n-para.para: Refer to Chapter 71-00-00, ADJUSTMENT/TEST for required checks following installation of fuel pump.

subject.title: 73.10.03 Fuel Filter and Fuel Waste Ejector

module.pageblock-title: FUEL FILTER AND FUEL WASTE EJECTOR - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES

general.para: Lubricate preformed packings, threads and mating surfaces with engine oil unless otherwise stated.
Install protective caps and plugs on disconnected tubes, component openings and electrical connectors after dis-assembly.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

procedure.title: Removal from Engine (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Remove the fuel pressure tubes from the fuel filter housing (Ref. Ch. 73-10-01).
Remove the oil pressure differential switch two mounting bolts from the filter housing and remove the electrical connector to the fuel pressure differential switch (Ref. Ch. 79-30-02).

Support
fuel filter housing (1) F41FH05A01 1 and remove two bolts (3), washers (2), bolt (5) and bracket (4) and remove fuel filter housing from accessory gearbox.
Place protective covers on all fuel filter housing openings.
Place removed parts in sealable plastic bags and identify with names and part numbers of contents.

procedure.title: Removal of Fuel Filter Element from Housing (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Remove three
nuts (11) F41FN05-04 3 and
flat washers (12) F41FW03-03 3 and remove
fuel filter cover (10) F41FC28-01 1 from
fuel filter housing assembly (25) F41FH05A01 1 . Remove and discard
preformed packing (13) F41FP03-09 1 .

Remove
retaining ring (9) F41FR20-01 1 and
fuel filter element (7) F41FF08-01 1 from fuel filter cover. Remove and discard
preformed packing (8) F41FP03-08 1 .

procedure.title: Removal of Fuel Filter Impending Bypass Switch and Filter Bypass Valve (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
FUEL FILTER IMPENDING BYPASS SWITCH (3) IS UNDER SPRING TENSION. BE CAREFUL WHEN REMOVING.Remove two
nuts (2) F41FN05-05 2 and
flat washers (1) F41FW03-01 2 and carefully remove
fuel filter impending bypass switch (3) F41FS66-01 1 and
spring (5) F41FS44-02 1 . Remove and discard preformed packings
(4) F41JP03-28 1 and
(6) F41JP03-27 1 .

Remove
filter bypass valve (26) F41FV01-02 1 from
fuel filter housing (25) F41FH05A01 1 .

procedure.title: Removal of Fuel Filter Drain Adapter (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Remove lockwire and remove
machine thread plug (16) F41FP26-02 1l . Remove and discard
preformed packing (17) F41FP03-06 1 .
Remove plug (16) and discard preformed packing (17).

Remove two
nuts (14) F41FN05-03 2 , two
washers (27) F41FW03-04 2 and remove
fuel filter drain adapter (15) F41FA03-02 1 using puller (PWC30128-11). Remove and discard
preformed packing (18) F41FP03-07 1 .

procedure.title: Removal of Air Bleed Adapter (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Remove lockwire and remove
bleeder tube plug (21) F41FP26-01 1 . Remove and discard
preformed packing (20) F41FP03-04 1 .

Remove two
nuts (22) F41FN05-06 2 and
flat washers (23) F41FW03-07 2 . Remove
air bleed adapter (19) F41FA03-01 1 . Remove and discard
preformed packing (24) F41FP03-05 1 .
Place all removed parts in clean, sealable plastic bags and tag with part numbers and description of contents.

procedure.title: Verify Seating of Bypass Valve (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Mount fuel filter housing on adapter plate (PWC60787) and secure adapter plate in vise.

Apply a thin even coat of layout dye (PWC05-041) to face of
bypass valve (26) F41FV01-02 1 .

Insert valve (26) into
fuel filter housing (25) F41FH05A01 1 , allowing valve to contact valve seat.
DO NOT ROTATE VALVE IN HOUSING.Remove valve from housing and inspect. A continuous ring around contact area should be visible. A broken ring will indicate incomplete valve seating.
Thoroughly clean valve face and valve seat (Ref. Cleaning). If above steps indicate lapping of valve seat is required, proceed to step . If lapping is not required, proceed to Subpara.
Apply engine oil to valve face.
Using lapping compound (PWC05-019) and lapping handle (PWC60788), lap valve face to valve seat.
Thoroughly clean parts using clean varsol (Ref. Cleaning).
Verify valve seating and repeat procedure until satisfactory result is obtained.

procedure.title: Assembly of Fuel Filter Bypass Valve (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install
bypass valve (26) F41FV01-02 1 and
spring (5) F41FS44-02 1 into
housing (25) F41FH05A01 1 .

Lubricate the threads and two new preformed packings
(4) F41JP03-28 1 and
(6) F41JP03-27 1 with engine oil (PWC03-001).

Install preformed packings (4 and 6) on the
fuel filter impending bypass switch (3) F41FS66-01 1 with expander (PWC90010).

Install fuel impending bypass switch (3) on fuel filter housing (25) and attach with two
flat washers (1) F41FW03-01 2 and self-locking
nuts (2) F41FN05-05 2 . Torque nuts 23 to 26 lb.in. (2.6-3.0 Nm). Do not lubricate the self-locking nuts and flat washer.

Functionally check bypass valve as follows: Install adapter (part of pressure test kit) (PWC60786) at fuel inlet port of housing (25). Blank off housing ports using seven slave preformed packings and seven plugs supplied with pressure test kit (PWC60786). Remove assembly from adapter plate and connect to fuel pressure rig. With fuel at 20 psi (137.9 kPa) check for leaks past valve. Maximum allowable leakage is 10 cc/min. Remove fuel filter housing from test rig and install on adapter plate (PWC60787). Remove adapter and plug installed in steps and preceding.

procedure.title: Assembly of Fuel Filter Housing (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Lubricate new
preformed packing (24) F41FP03-05 1 and install on
air bleed adapter (19) F41FA03-01 1 .

Install air bleed adapter (19) on
fuel filter housing (25) F41FH05A01 1 and secure with two
flat washers (23) F41FW03-07 2 and
self-locking nuts (22) F41FN05-06 2 . Torque nuts 23 to 26 lb.in. (2.6-3.0 Nm).

Lubricate new
preformed packing (20) F41FP03-04 1 and install on
bleeder tube plug (21) F41FP26-01 1 . Install plug into adapter (19) and torque 40 to 50 lb.in. (4.6-5.6 Nm).

Lubricate new
preformed packing (13) F41FP03-09 1 and install on
fuel filter cover (10) F41FC28-01 1 .

Lubricate new
preformed packing (8) F41FP03-08 1 and install on
fuel filter element (7) F41FF08-01 1 . Install filter element into filter cover (10) and secure with
retaining ring (9) F41FR20-01 1 .

Lubricate new
preformed packing (18) F41FP03-07 1 and install on
fuel filter drain adapter (15) F41FA03-02 1 . Install adapter on fuel filter housing (25) and secure with two
nuts (14) F41FN05-03 2 and
washers (27) F41FW03-04 2 . Torque nuts 23 to 26 lb.in (2.6-3.0 Nm).

Lubricate new
preformed packing (17) F41FP03-06 1 and install on
machine thread plug (16) F41FP26-02 1 . Install plug into adapter (15). Torque plug 65 to 75 lb.in. (7.5-8.0 Nm) and lockwire (PWC05-089).

WHEN INSTALLING FUEL FILTER COVER ON FUEL FILTER HOUSING, MAKE SURE FUEL FILTER ELEMENT IS CORRECTLY INSTALLED OVER HOUSING SLEEVE. MAKE SURE FILTER COVER IS FULLY SEATED BEFORE TIGHTENING AND TORQUING NUTS (11).Install fuel filter cover assembly (10) to the fuel filter housing (25) and secure with three
flat washers (12) F41FW03-03 3 and
self-locking nuts (11) F41FN05-04 3 . Torque nuts 23 to 26 lb.in (2.6-3.0 Nm).
Remove housing assembly from holding fixture.
Place protective covers on all fuel filter housing openings.
Place assembled fuel filter housing in clean, sealable plastic bag and tag with description and part number of contents.

procedure.title: Installation on Engine (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Locate fuel filter housing (1) on two dowel pins on accessory gearbox and secure with two washers (2) and bolts (3). Torque bolts 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).
Install bracket (4) and bolt (5) in bottom mounting hole of fuel filter housing. Torque bolt 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).
Install the fuel pressure tubes from the fuel filter housing (Ref. Ch. 73-10-01).
Install the oil pressure differential switch two mounting bolts from the filter housing (Ref. Ch. 79-30-02) and install the electrical connector to the fuel pressure differential switch.

procedure.title: Removal from Engine (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Disconnect Channel B N2 speed sensor connector, to improve tool access to filter cover (Ref. Ch. 77-10-01).

Remove three
nuts (8) F41FH05A01 1 ,
washers (7) F41FW03-03 3 , one nut (18) and washer (17) and separate shield (16) and
filter cover (6) F41FC28-01 1 from
filter housing (1) F41FH05A01 1 . Remove and discard
preformed packing (5) F41FP03-09 1 .

Remove
retaining ring (2) F41FR20-01 1 from filter cover (6) and remove
fuel filter (4) F41FF08-01 1 . Remove and discard
preformed packing (3) F41FP03-08 1 .

procedure.title: Installation on Engine (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install
fuel filter element (4) F41FF08-01 1 in
filter cover (6) F41FC28-01 1 and secure with
retaining ring (2) F41FR20-01 1 .

Lubricate new
preformed packing (3) F41FP03-08 1 with engine oil (PWC03-001) and install in fuel filter element (4).

Lubricate new
preformed packing (5) F41FP03-09 1 with engine oil (PWC03-001) and install in filter cover (6).

WHEN INSTALLING FUEL FILTER COVER ON FUEL FILTER HOUSING, MAKE SURE FUEL FILTER ELEMENT IS CORRECTLY INSTALLED OVER HOUSING SLEEVE. MAKE SURE FILTER COVER IS FULLY SEATED BEFORE TIGHTENING AND TORQUING NUTS (8).Install filter cover assembly on
fuel filter housing (1) F41FH05A01 1 and secure with three
nuts (8) F41FH05A01 1 and
washers (7) F41FW03-03 3 . Tighten and torque nuts 23 to 26 lb.in (2.6-3.0 Nm).
Re-connect Channel B N2 speed sensor connection (Ref. Ch. 77-10-01).

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Loosen nut (16) on transfer tube (15) and disconnect tube from waste ejector inlet
elbow (14) F24FE01-01 2 .

Loosen nuts (7 and 9) and disconnect transfer tubes
(6) F24FT17A03 1 and
(10) F50FT17A14 1 from outlet fitting (8).

Support
fuel waste ejector (4) F23BE03-01 1 and remove
bolts (1) F24FB20-22 2 ,
nuts (5) F24FN05-14 4 and
washers (2) F24FW03-07 4 securing ejector to
mounting bracket (3) F24FB40-01 1 .
Install protective caps and/or plugs on exposed openings.

25194: If necessary, remove mounting bracket (3) from outer bypass duct (19) by removing
bolts (17) F24FB20-23 3 and
washers (18) F24FW03-08 3 , three places.

25194: If necessary, remove mounting bracket (3) from outer bypass duct (19) by removing
bolts (17) F24FB20-23 3 ,
washers (18) F24FW03-08 3 and
gaskets (20) F24FG03-05 3 , three places.

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
25194: If removed, install
mounting bracket (3) F24FB40-01 1 on outer bypass duct (19) with
bolts (17) F24FB20-23 3 and
washers (18) F24FW03-08 3 , three places. Torque nuts 36 to 40 lb.in (4.0 to 4.6 Nm).

25194: If removed, Install mounting bracket (3) on outer bypass duct (19) with bolts (17), washers (18) and
gaskets (20) F24FG03-05 3 , three places. Torque nuts 36 to 40 lb.in (4.0 to 4.6 Nm).

If necessary, install fittings on fuel waste ejector as follows: Remove protective plugs and/or caps. Install
elbow (14) F24FE01-01 2 , using new
backing ring (12) F24FR12-01 2 and new
preformed packing (11) F24FP03-16 2 . Do not tighten
nut (13) F24FN05-13 2 at this time.

Locate
fuel waste ejector (4) F23BE03-01 1 on mounting bracket (3) and secure with four
bolts (1) F24FB20-22 4 ,
washers (2) F24FW03-07 4 and
self-locking nuts (5) F24FN05-14 4 . Tighten and torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).

Align tubes
(6) F24FT17A03 1 and
(10) F50FT17A14 1 with ejector fitting (8). Secure with nuts (7 and 9), tighten and torque nuts 90 to 100 lb.in. (10.2-11.3 Nm).
Align transfer tube (15) with elbow (14). Hold elbow, tighten and torque nut (13) 38 to 42 lb.in. (4.3 - 4.8 Nm). Hold elbow, tighten and torque nut (16) 90 to 100 lb.in. (10.2-11.3 Nm).
Lockwire (PWC05-089) nuts (7 and 9).

procedure.title: Fuel Filter Housing, Filter Cover and Bypass Valve
procedure.caution: DO NOT EXTEND, CONTRACT, BEND OR OTHERWISE DAMAGE FUEL FILTER BYPASS VALVE SPRING.
procedure.step: Wash parts in clean petroleum solvent (PWC11-027). If necessary, use a nylon bristle brush to remove contaminants.
Dry parts using clean, dry, filtered compressed air blast, or allow parts to stand and air dry.

procedure.title: Fuel Filter
procedure.step: Insert a small lamp into the inside bore of the filter element.
Visually inspect filter element for breaks, punctures or evidence of collapse. There must be no loose particles, broken bonds or joints.

general.para: Lubricate preformed packings, threads and mating surfaces with engine oil unless otherwise stated.
Install protective caps and plugs on disconnected tubes, component openings and electrical connectors after disassembly.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.
Refer to INTRODUCTION for alternate products, suppliers and suppliers addressess.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. and )

key.def: Loop Clamp (Ref. Installed on No. 4 Bearing Scavenge Tube)

procedure.step:
Remove
nuts B23NN05-27 28 (7, Fig. ),
washers (6) B23NW03-05 28 ,
gaskets (22) B23NG03-01 28 and
outer cover (5) B23NC28A07 1 . Discard gaskets.
Remove nuts (25, Fig. ), washers (26), bolts (24) and bottom fairing (23).
Remove bolts (3, Fig. ) and inner duct segment (4).
Remove bolt (13, Fig. ) and nut (14) that attaches tube bracket to the No. 4 scavenge oil tube.

Remove two
bolts (7) F50FB20-05 2 securing
fuel tube assembly (6) B22FT17A04 1 to bypass duct.

Remove
bolt (11) B22FB20-03 1 and
self-locking nut (4) B22FN05-02 1 securing
loop clamp (5) B22FC07-01 1 to angle bracket (10).
Remove and discard lockwire securing two coupling nuts (3).
Loosen two coupling nuts (3) and remove primary fuel tube assembly (6).

Remove two
transfer tubes (2) B22FT17-06 2 . Remove and discard four
preformed packings (1) B22FP03-03 4 .

Remove and discard two preformed packings
(8) F50FP03-16 1 and
(9) F50FP03-14 1 .
Remove loop clamp (5) from primary fuel tube assembly (6).
Install closures on all exposed openings.

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. and )
procedure.step:
Position
loop clamp (5) B22FC07-01 1 on
primary fuel tube assembly (6) B22FT17A04 1 .

Lubricate and install two new preformed packings
(8) F50FP03-16 1 and
(9) F50FP03-14 1 on primary fuel tube assembly (6).

Lubricate and install four new
preformed packings (1) B22FP03-03 4 on two
fuel transfer tubes (2) B22FT17-06 2 .
Insert two fuel transfer tube assemblies (2) into two primary fuel nozzle assemblies (12).
Install primary fuel tube assembly (6) by pushing adapter into outer bypass duct into two fuel transfer tubes (2) into primary fuel nozzles.
Install bolt (13) and nut (14) to loop clamp (15) securing tube bracket to the No. 4 scavenge oil tube. Torque nut (14) 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).

Secure tube adapter to outer bypass duct using two
bolts (7) F50FB20-05 2 . Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).

MAKE SURE THE ANTI-SEIZE COMPOUND MIXTURE WILL NOT PENETRATE THE FUEL PASSAGE OF THE PRIMARY NOZZLE.Lubricate threads of coupling nuts (3) with mixture of 20% engine oil (PWC03-001) and 80% anti-sieze compound (PWC06-004A).
Secure two coupling nuts (3) to two primary fuel nozzles (12). Torque 225 to 250 lb.in. (25-28 Nm).
Lockwire (PWC05-089) two coupling nuts (3) to bolts securing primary fuel nozzles.

Secure loop clamp (5) to angle bracket (10) using
bolt (11) B22FB20-03 1 and
nut (4) B22FN05-02 1 . Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).
Refer to Chapter 71-00-00 for required checks following installation of primary fuel tubes.
Install inner duct segment (4, Fig. ) with bolts (3). Tighten 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.5 Nm).
Install the bottom fairing (23, Fig. ) with bolts (24), washers (26) and nuts (25).

Install
outer cover B23NC28A07 1 (5, Fig. ),
gaskets (22) B23NG03-01 28 ,
washers (6) B23NW03-05 28 and
nuts (7) B23NN05-27 28 . Make sure gaskets are between duct and washers. Tighten nuts 23 to 26 lb.in (2.6-2.9 Nm) in a star pattern from top center of cover outward.

n-para.title: Primary Fuel Manifold and Nozzles
n-para.caution: EXTREME CARE MUST BE EXERCISED WHEN HANDLING FUEL NOZZLE ASSEMBLIES. FINGERPRINTS ON THE ORIFICE MAY PRODUCE POOR SPRAY PATTERN. CLEAN, LINT-FREE COTTON GLOVES OR SURGICAL GLOVES SHOULD BE WORN AT ALL TIMES WHEN HANDLING IS REQUIRED.
BOTH REPLACEMENT FUEL NOZZLES MUST BE FROM THE SAME MANUFACTURER.

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: Primary Fuel Manifold and Nozzles - Removal/Installation

procedure.step: Remove ignition exciters and mounting plate (Ref. 74-10-01).
Remove primary fuel tube assembly (Ref. Para. ). Primary fuel tube assembly must be fully removed from engine before primary nozzles removed.

Remove three
bolts (13) B22FB20-02 46 and three
retaining plates (14) B22FP16-01 24 and push back three
outer tubes (11) B22FT17-03
.

Remove two
bolts (15) B22FB20-01 2 and remove two
primary fuel nozzles (12) B22FN04-01 21 .

Discard
gaskets (16) B22FG03-01 24 and preformed packings
(8) B22FP03-01 48 and
(9) B22FP03-02 48 .

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install new
preformed packings (8) B22FP03-01 48 on
nozzles (12) B22FN04-01 21 .

Install new
preformed packings (9) B22FP03-02 48 on
inner fuel tubes (10) B22FT17-02
.

Slide one
outer fuel tubes (11) B22FT17-03
on fuel manifold. Slide remaining two outer fuel tubes on fuel nozzles (12).

Install new
gaskets (16) B22FG03-01 24 on fuel nozzles and insert nozzles into bosses in combustor outer case.

Secure each fuel nozzle with one
bolts (15) B22FB20-01 2 , fingertight.
Connect fuel nozzles with fuel manifold by sliding outer fuel tubes (11) into place.

Install outer fuel tubes in place with three
retaining plates (14) B22FP16-01 24 and
bolts (13) B22FB20-02 46 , fingertight.
Tighten bolts (13 and 15) 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Install primary fuel tube assembly (Ref. Para. ).
Install inner duct segment (4) with bolts (3). Tighten 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.5 Nm).

Install
outer cover (5) B23NC28A07 1 ,
gaskets (22) B23NG03-01 28 ,
washers (6) B23NW03-05 28 and
nuts (7) B23NN05-27 28 . Make sure gaskets are between duct and washers. Tighten nuts 23 to 26 lb.in (2.6-2.9 Nm) in a star pattern from top center of cover outward.
Refer to Chapter 71-00-00, ADJUSTMENT/TEST, for required checks following installation of fuel nozzles.

n-para.title: Secondary Fuel Manifold and Nozzles
n-para.caution: EXTREME CARE MUST BE EXERCISED WHEN HANDLING FUEL NOZZLE ASSEMBLIES. FINGERPRINTS ON THE ORIFICE MAY PRODUCE POOR SPRAY PATTERN. CLEAN, LINT-FREE COTTON GLOVES OR SURGICAL GLOVES SHOULD BE WORN AT ALL TIMES WHEN HANDLING IS REQUIRED.
BOTH REPLACEMENT FUEL NOZZLES MUST BE FROM THE SAME MANUFACTURER.

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. and )

figure.title: Secondary Fuel Manifold and Nozzles - Removal/Installation

procedure.step: Remove upper segments of outer bypass duct (Ref. Chapter 72-70-01)
Remove inner bypass ducts (Ref. Chapter 72-70-01)

Remove 21
bolts B22FB20-02 46 (8, Fig. ) and
tube retaining plates (9) B22FP16-01 24 .

Slide 21
fuel manifold tube assemblies (6) B22FT17A01 24 back, to disengage from adjacent fuel nozzle.

Remove three
bolts (10) B22FB20-01 2 and three
fuel nozzles (2) B22FN04A01 21 120 degrees apart, and install three locators (PWC43572).
Remove start and dump valve (Ref. Chapter 73-10-05, FUEL SHUTOFF AND DRAIN - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES).
Remove fuel shut off valve and transfer tubes (Ref. Chapter 73-10-05, FUEL SHUTOFF AND DRAIN - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES).

Remove one bolt (10) and
fuel inlet nozzle (1) B22FN04A02 1 .
Remove remaining 20 bolts (10) and fuel nozzles (2). Completely remove one nozzle before proceeding to the next.

Remove and discard 22
metal gaskets (11) B22FG03-01 24 from 21 fuel nozzles (2) and one fuel inlet nozzle (1).
Remove 22 fuel manifold tube assemblies (6) from fuel nozzles and fuel inlet nozzle.

Remove and discard 44
preformed packings (3) B22FP03-01 48 from fuel nozzles and fuel inlet nozzle.

Remove 22
inner fuel manifold tubes (5) B22FT17-02
from 22
outer fuel manifold tubes (7) B22FT17-03
. Remove and discard 44
preformed packings (4) B22FP03-02 48 .

Remove inner and outer manifold tubes
(10) B22FT17-02
and
(11) B22FT17-03
, (Fig. ) from adjacent primary nozzles.

Remove and discard
preformed packings (9) B22FP03-02 48 .
Remove primary manifold and nozzles (Ref. Subpara. ).
Place closures over all openings of fuel nozzles and fuel inlet nozzle and place in individual containers.

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Figs. and )
procedure.step:
Lubricate
preformed packings B22FP03-02 48 (4, Fig. ) with engine oil (PWC03-001) and install on 21
inner fuel manifold tubes (5) B22FT17-02
.

Lubricate
preformed packings B22FP03-02 48 (9, Fig. ) with engine oil (PWC03-001) and install on one
inner fuel manifold tube (10) B22FT17-02
.

Introduce one inner manifold tube (10), with side having an extra shoulder, into one
outer manifold tube (11) B22FT17-03
, through end with flats. Thread inner manifold tube (10) into outer manifold tube (11) until threaded shoulder on inner tube is trapped between shoulders on outer tube.

Introduce inner manifold tubes (5, Fig. ) with side having an extra shoulder, into
outer manifold tubes (7) B22FT17-03
through end with flats. Thread inner manifold tube (5) into outer manifold tube (7) until threaded shoulder on inner tube is trapped between shoulder on outer tube.

Lubricate
preformed packings (3) B22FP03-01 48 with engine oil (PWC03-001) and install on
inlet nozzle (1) B22FN04A02 1 .

Lubricate remaining preformed packings (3) with engine oil (PWC03-001) and install on
fuel nozzles (2) B22FN04A01 21 .

Lubricate
preformed packing B22FP03-01 48 (8, Fig. ) with engine oil (PWC03-001) and install on one fuel nozzle (2, Fig. )
Insert outer fuel tube assembly (11, Fig. ) into one fuel nozzle (2, Fig. ). Insert end of tube assembly without flats, into grooved end of fuel nozzle.

Insert
fuel manifold tube assemblies B22FT17A01 24 , (6, Fig. ) into fuel nozzles (2) and one primary fuel nozzle (1). Insert end of tube assembly without flats, into grooved end of fuel nozzle.

Install
metal gaskets (11) B22FG03-01 24 on 21 fuel nozzles (2) and one fuel inlet nozzle (1).

Insert fuel inlet nozzle (1) in combustion chamber outer case assembly, at bottom centre location. Make sure nozzle enters combustion chamber. Install
bolt (10) B22FB20-01 2 fingertight.
Install the fuel shut off valve with transfer tubes (Ref. Chapter 73-10-05, FUEL SHUTOFF AND DRAIN - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES).
Install the start and dump valve (Ref. Chapter 73-10-05, FUEL SHUTOFF AND DRAIN - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES).

Insert fuel nozzle assemblies (2) in combustion chamber outer case assembly, leaving two open bosses for primary fuel nozzles (Ref. View looking forward on fuel manifold). Install bolts (10) fingertight.
Slide fuel manifold tube assemblies (6) over fuel nozzles until retaining plate locking grooves are exposed.

Insert one
tube retaining plate (9) B22FP16-01 24 into locking groove of fuel inlet nozzle (1). Install
bolt (8) B22FB20-02 46 fingertight.
Insert tube retaining plates (9) into locking grooves in fuel nozzles (2) with bolts (8) fingertight.
Install primary manifold and fuel nozzles (Ref. Subpara ).
Tighten bolts (8 and 10) 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).
Install inner bypass duct (Ref. Chapter 72-70-01).
Install upper segments of outer bypass duct (Ref. Chapter 72-70-01).
Refer to Chapter 71-00-00 for checks required following installation of fuel manifold and nozzles.

procedure.title: Cleaning of Fuel Nozzles

address.co-name: Fuel nozzles are to be returned for cleaning and inspection to:
address.fax: (231) 798-0150Or you can clean and inspect fuel nozzles in accordance with the following procedure:

procedure.warning: USE FACE SHIELDS AND RUBBER GLOVES WHEN WORKING WITH CLEANING SOLUTION. DO CLEANING OPERATION IN A WELL VENTILATED AREA.
procedure.caution: USE EXTREME CARE WHEN HANDLING FUEL NOZZLE ASSEMBLIES. FINGERPRINTS ON THE ORIFICE MAY PRODUCE POOR SPRAY PATTERN. CLEAN, LINT FREE COTTON GLOVES OR SURGICAL GLOVES SHOULD BE WORN AT ALL TIMES WHEN HANDLING IS REQUIRED.
procedure.step:
The cleaning solutions listed (Ref. Table ) are recommended for immersion or ultrasonic cleaning of fuel nozzles:
Fuel Nozzle Cleaning Solutions
Cleaning Agent SpecificationMixture Concentration
Turco 4181, Powder (PWC11-046)2.0 - 3.0 lb/gal water
Ardox 185, Powder (PWC11-049)2.0 - 3.0 lb/gal water
Mag Chem HDL-202, Liquid (PWC11-061)30 - 35% by Volume in water
Ardox 185L, Liquid (PWC11-063)15 - 20% by Volume in water
Turco 4181L, Liquid (PWC11-064)50 - 75% by Volume in water
Turco 4781-7, Powder (PWC11-065)2.0 - 3.0 lb/gal water
Make a solution of cleaning agent (Ref. Table ) in water. Tap water may be used. Add the cleaning agent slowly to the water. Agitate the mixture to evenly mix the concentration.
Heat the solution to 179 to 199°F (82-93°C).

Clean the nozzle by immersion or ultrasonic method. Immersion Cleaning: Put the fuel nozzle fully into the solution for 30 to 90 minutes. If the temperature is lower, the immersion time will be longer. Remove nozzle and spray rinse with cold water over the solution tank. Ultrasonic Cleaning: An ultrasonic cleaner with a minimum frequency of 25khz and 6 to 11 watts/sq. in. of tank cross section is recommended. Carefully put the nozzles into the heated cleaning solution inside the tank and clean the nozzles for 15 to 60 minutes. The nozzles must be fully submerged under the surface of the solution by one inch minimum. Remove nozzle and spray rinse with cold water over the solution tank.
Check that the carbon is removed from the tip. If carbon deposits are still present on the tip, use a nylon bristle brush to loosen the carbon.
Repeat the cleaning until carbon is removed.
Put the nozzle fully into the cold water, then in water heated to 150 to 199°F (66 to 93°C). Keep nozzle in the tank until the temperature of the part is the same as the water temperature.
Remove the nozzle and dry by blowing with clean, oil free shop air.
Repeat the process for each nozzle.

procedure.title: Primary (Hybrid) Fuel Nozzle Visual Inspection
procedure.step: For the fuel nozzle visual inspection, refer to Component Maintenance Manual P/N 3070814.

procedure.title: Fuel Manifold Assembly Pressure Test (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: This procedure is used on fuel manifolds installed on a combustor prior to installation on the engine.
procedure.step: Install plug (PWC60712) (1) in main fuel passage of fuel inlet nozzle (2).
Install inlet adaptor (PWC60711) (3) in fuel inlet nozzle (2) and lock in place using locking clamp (PWC60710) (4).
Connect pressure test kit (PWC60718) to inlet adaptor (3).
Make sure test kit selector valve (6) is set in the OFF/TEST position.
Make sure pressure regulator valve (7) is closed (if regulator is not preset).
Open the shut off valve on the nitrogen cylinder (PWC05-050).
Adjust pressure regulator valve (7) until pressure is 100 to 150 psi (689.4-1034.2 kPa), if regulator is not preset.
Turn selector valve (6) to the COMBUSTOR position.
Make sure test kit pressure is 100 to 150 psi (689.4-1034.2 kPa).
Turn selector valve (6) to the OFF /TEST position.
Close the shut off valve on nitrogen cylinder.

NO DECREASE IN PRESSURE IS PERMITTED.Monitor test kit pressure gauge for 5 minutes minimum. If there is no decrease in pressure, go to step . If there is a decrease in pressure proceed as follows: Find the source of the leak. Repair the leak. Pressure test fuel manifold assembly Ref. Para. .
Turn selector valve (6) to BLEED OFF position.
Close pressure adjusting valve (7) on nitrogen cylinder (if regulator is not preset).
Remove clamp (4), test adapter (3), plug (1) and test kit (5).

procedure.title: Fuel Manifold Pressure Test - Combustor Installed on Engine (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: This procedure is used on an installed engine; eg: after HSI or changing primary fuel nozzles.
procedure.step: Disconnect the nacelle drain line from drain adapter (1), (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Connect hose assembly (6) of leak check fixture (PWC61792) (5) to drain adaptor (1).
Make sure test kit selector valve (3) is set in the OFF /TEST position.
Make sure the regulator valve on cylinder (2) containing nitrogen (PWC05-050) is closed.
Open the shut off valve on nitrogen cylinder (2).
Adjust pressure regulator valve on cylinder (2) until pressure is 100 to 150 psi (689.4-1034.2 kPa).
Turn selector valve (3) to the TO COMBUSTER position.
Make sure gauge (4) reads 100 to 150 psi (689.4-1034.2 kPa).
Turn selector valve (3) to the OFF /TEST position.
Close the shut off valve on nitrogen cylinder (2).

NO DECREASE IN PRESSURE IS PERMITTED.Monitor test kit pressure gauge (4) for 5 minutes minimum. If there is no decrease in pressure, go to step . If there is a decrease in pressure proceed as follows: Find the source of the leak. Repair the leak. Pressure test fuel manifold assembly (Ref. Para. and/or ).
Turn selector valve (3) to BLEED OFF position.
Close pressure adjusting valve on nitrogen cylinder (2).
Remove hose assembly (6) from drain adapter (1).
Connect the nacelle drain line to drain adapter (1), (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).

module.pageblock-title: FUEL SHUTOFF AND DRAIN - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES

general.para: Lubricate preformed packings, threads and mating surfaces with engine oil unless otherwise stated.
Install protective caps and plugs on disconnected tubes, component openings and electrical connectors after disassembly.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are identified in procedural text.
Refer to INTRODUCTION for alternate products, suppliers and suppliers addresses.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

fixtures-and-equipment.para: The fixtures, equipment and supplier tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: Fuel Start and Dump Valve - Removal/Installation

procedure.step: Set maintenance discrete to ON.
Remove the P34 connector (2) and check the connector for moisture. If necessary, dry the connector with a suitable heatgun.
Remove flowmeter and related items (Ref. AMM).

Remove the
bolts (3) F50LB20-31 1 ,
washers (4) F50FW03-12 2 and the dump valve from the fuel shut-off valve.

Remove the transfer tubes
(6) B24FT17-04 1 and
(7) B24FT17-03 1 from the dump valve.

Remove and discard the preformed packings
(5) B24FP03-06 2 and
(1) B24FP03-05 2 from the transfer tubes (6 and 7).

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install new preformed packings
(5) B24FP03-06 2 and
(1) B24FP03-05 2 on the transfer tubes (6 and 7).

Install the tubes
(6) B24FT17-04 1 and
(7) B24FT17-03 1 into the fuel dump valve.
Insert the fuel dump valve into the fuel shut-off valve. Make sure the transfer tubes are properly seated.

Install the
washers (4) F50FW03-12 2 and the
bolts (3) F50LB20-31 1 . Lubricate the bolts with engine oil (PWC03-001) and torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Install flowmeter and related items (Ref. AMM).

Do the following checks: Restore the electrical power to the appropriate system and reset the EEC power to ON. Set the TLA to the idle detent position. Check that the white fault lamp illuminates at the cockpit isolation panel, and that the MFD Code WB is annunciated. Pull the EEC circuit breaker to OFF. Set the maintenance test discrete to ON. Install the P34 connector (2) to start/dump valve. Tighten the connector 24 using one of the following methods:
SOFT JAWED PLIERS HAVE A DESIGN SLIP TORQUE OF 100 lb.in (11.3 Nm). DO NOT USE STEEL JAWED PLIERS TO TIGHTEN CONNECTORS.Tighten the connector using soft jawed pliers (PWC90012) or Glenair TG69. Apply reasonable force to make sure connector coupling nut is firmly tightened and the red band is covered.
WRENCH ASSEMBLY CONNECTOR HAS A DESIGN SLIP TORQUE OF 100 lb.in. (11.3 Nm).Tighten the connector with a wrench assembly connector (PWC58104) or Glenair TG70. Apply reasonable force to make sure connector coupling nut is firmly tightened and the red band is covered. Reset the EEC circuit breaker to ON. Set the maintenance test discrete to OFF.
Pull the EEC circuit breaker to OFF.
Function check the dump valve (Ref Subpara following).

procedure.title: Functional Check (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Remove two bolts (11) and tube (12) from dump valve.
Remove and discard preformed packing (13).
Remove tube (11) from fuel waste ejector (Ref. 73-10-03).
Fit suitable slave fitting to the dump valve outlet and connect fitting to a large vented drain bottle.
Do a wet motoring run (Ref. 71-00-00) and check that fuel does not leak from the dump valve during motoring.
Continuous dripping of fuel from the dump valve during a wet motoring indicates a damaged valve.
After motoring, make sure dump valve drains residual fuel to the drain bottle.
If fuel does not drain, replace dump valve.
Remove slave fitting and drain bottle.

Lubricate new preformed packing (13) with engine oil (PWC03-001) and install on tube (8). Fit tube in place and secure to fuel dump valve with bolts (9 and 15). Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Install transfer tube (11) to fuel waste ejector (Ref. 73-10-03).
Restore engine to standard operating conditions.

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Remove fuel start/dump valve (Ref. Para. ).

Remove lockwire and seal and loosen nuts
(10) F24FN05-03 1 and
(11) F24FN05-03 1 . Remove
fuel shutoff cable (8) F50FC01-01 1 from fuel shutoff valve control lever.

Remove
bolts (13) F24FB20-04 4 and
flat washers (12) F24FW03-03 4 . Pull
fuel shutoff valve (7) F24FV01-02 4 away from mounting pad and discard
preformed packings (6) F24FP03-04 2 .

Remove transfer tubes
(2) B24FT17-02 1 and
(4) B24FT17-01 1 and discard preformed packings
(1) B24FP03-04 2 ,
(3) B24FP03-02 1 and
(5) B24FP03-02 1 .
Plug/cap all openings.

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Lubricate two new
preformed packings (6) F24FP03-04 2 with engine oil (PWC03-001), and install on
fuel shutoff valve (7) F24FV01-02 4 .

Lubricate new preformed packings
(1) B24FP03-04 2 ,
(3) B24FP03-02 1 and
(5) B24FP03-02 1 with engine oil (PWC03-001), and install on transfer tubes
(2) B24FT17-02 1 and
(4) B24FT17-01 1 . Insert transfer tubes into fuel shutoff valve.

Install fuel shutoff valve on mounting pad of bypass duct, being careful to insert transfer tubes (2 and 4) into fuel inlet nozzle. Install four
bolts (13) F24FB20-04 4 and
washers (12) F24FW03-03 4 . Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Install fuel start/dump valve (Ref. Para. ).

Attach
fuel shutoff cable (8) F50FC01-01 1 to fuel shutoff valve control lever and check adjustment.

procedure.title: Resetting Procedure (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Remove lockwire, seal,
nuts (4) F24FN05-03 2 and
spacer (3) F24FS33-04 1 securing fuel shutoff cable (2) to
control lever (8) F24FL02-02 1 .

Remove two
bolts (6) F24FB20-03 2 ,
washers (5) F24FW03-02 2 and remove
overspeed control linkage housing (7) F24FH05-03 1 from
fuel inlet and shutoff valve housing (1) F24FH05A01 1 . Ensure
release plate (9) F24FP16-01 1 does not fall from assembly.

Push control lever (8) to slightly withdraw
tripper sleeve assembly (15) F24FT08A01 1 , thus allowing
control levers (13) F24FT08-02
to pivot freely.
Adjust control levers (13), using a soft-faced tool, to centralize with hole in tripper sleeve assembly (15).
Release pressure from control lever (8). Tripper sleeve (15) will snap into place if control levers (13) are centralized. Repeat steps (3) and (4), if necessary, until levers are reset.
DO NOT HAMMER FUEL SHUT-OFF VALVE TRIPPER SLEEVE.Using a soft drift apply even pressure on tripper sleeve to make sure sleeve is fully seated.
Insert narrow end of release plate (9) between control levers (13) so that head of release plate contacts end of piston assembly in fuel inlet and shutoff valve assembly (1).
Fuel shutoff valve is now reset.
Measure Dimension AA between lug on tripper sleeve assembly (15) and rear face of control linkage housing (7). This dimension is used when installing the fuel shutoff cable.
Install control linkage housing (7) on fuel inlet and shutoff valve housing (1) with two bolts (6) and washers (5). Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.5 Nm).
Adjust emergency fuel shutoff cable (Ref. Para. ).
Install lockwire (PWC05-089) and seal between nuts (4).

procedure.title: Visual Inspection
procedure.step: Visually inspect the cable mechanism for corrosion.
Borescope the cable mechanism in the exhaust case. Check for corrosion and security. Check the plunger assembly for any leakage from the oil seal.
Visually inspect the fuel shut off mechanism for corrosion.
Check for correct security (Ref. Para , Periodic Inspection).

procedure.title: Periodic Inspection (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: Refer to Ch. 05-20-00, Periodic Inspection for inspection intervals.
procedure.step: Measure emergency fuel shut-off tripper Dim. T and record.
DO NOT HAMMER FUEL SHUT-OFF VALVE TRIPPER SLEEVE.Using a soft drift apply even pressure on tripper sleeve (15) to make sure sleeve is fully seated.
Measure emergency fuel shut-off tripper Dim. T. Re-rig if Dim. T is less than 0.008 inch.
Do Engine Ground Checks No. 1 and No. 2 (Ref. 71-00-00).
Advance TLA to normal take-off detent. Hold in this position for as long as possible for a maximum of two minutes. Move TLA to ground idle to allow engine to stabilize.
Shut engine down per Check No. 3 (Ref. Ch. 71-00-00).
Check for security and leakage.

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
DO NOT CAUSE FUEL SHUT-OFF MECHANISM TO TRIP BY LETTING THE CONTROL LEVER MOVE OUT.Carefully remove lockwire, lead seal, nuts
(14) F24FN05-03 2 ,
(15) F24FN05-03 2 and
spacer (16) F24FS33-04 1 from the lower end of control
cable (7) F50FC01-01 1 .
Remove cable end from control lever.

Remove
cotterpin (3) F36FP04-02 1 ,
pin (1) F36FP04-01 1 and cable end from bellcrank (2). Discard cotterpin (3).
Move bellcrank (2) to forward position and secure to exhaust case with lockwire (PWC05-089). This will prevent disengagement of cable from actuating lever inside exhaust case.

Unlock
keywasher (19) F24FW03-04 1 and remove with
nut (18) F24FN05-02 1 . Discard key washer.

Remove
nut (11) F24FN05-01 1 ,
bolt (9) F24FB20-02 1 and
clamp (10) F24FC07-01 1 .
Remove lockwire and loosen nut (4).
Remove fuel shut-off cable from engine by pulling upwards through fairing of bypass duct (22).

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
If lower end of
cable assembly (7) F50FC01-01 1 was not removed from bypass duct (22) or fuel shut-off valve control lever (13) go to step .
Put the threaded end of cable assembly (7) through holes at bottom of inner and outer bypass ducts (21, 22).

Install housing end of cable assembly on outer bypass duct with
keywasher (19) F24FW03-04 1 and
nut (18) F24FN05-02 1 . Torque nut 62 to 85 lb. in. (7.0-9.5 Nm.). Bend tabs on keywasher to lock nut.

DO NOT CAUSE FUEL SHUT-OFF MECHANISM TO TRIP BY LETTING THE CONTROL LEVER MOVE OUT.Engage cable with
pulley (17) F24FP07-01 1 of fuel shut-off valve and connect end of cable to control lever (13) with
spacer (16) F24FS33-04 1 and nuts
(15) F24FN05-03 2 ,
(14) F24FN05-03 2 , finger tight.

Install cable assembly (7) loosely to bracket (8) with
clamp (10) F24FC07-01 1 ,
nut (11) F24FN05-01 1 and
bolt (9) F24FB20-02 1 .
Remove nut (4) from cable housing and turn nut (6) all the way on.
Install cable assembly (7) through bracket (5) and loosely secure with nut (4).

Install cable end on exhaust case bell crank (2) with
pin (1) F36FP04-01 1 and secure with
cotterpin (3) F36FP04-02 1 . Remove lockwire from bellcrank.

procedure.title: Adjustment (Rigging) (Ref. Figs. and )

figure.title: Emergency Fuel Shutoff Valve - Resetting Procedure

key.def: Fuel Inlet and Shut-off Valve Housing

procedure.note: Expansion of the engine due to normal operating temperature will cause the fuel shut-off cable to pull the tripper sleeve out from the fuel shut-off valve housing. This is an acceptable condition provided the tripper sleeve can be pushed back with a soft faced hammer to a minimum of 0.008 inch below the end of the housing.
procedure.step: Remove fuel waste ejector (Ref. 73-10-03).

DO NOT HAMMER FUEL SHUT-OFF VALVE TRIPPER SLEEVE.Using a soft drift apply even pressure on
tripper sleeve F24FT08A01 1 (15, Fig. ) to make sure sleeve is fully seated.

Measure and record dimension AA (Ref. Fig. ) from the lug on tripper sleeve assembly (15) to the rear face of
housing (7) F24FH05-03 1 , using depth micrometer. Dimension AA = distance from end of tripper sleeve to end of housing before tightening cable.

If lower end of the
cable assembly F50FC01-01 1 (7, Fig. ) was not removed from bypass duct (22) or fuel shut-off valve control lever (13), set Dimension S as follows: Adjust nuts
(15) F24FN05-03 2 and
(14) F24FN05-03 2 to obtain Dimension S (Ref. Fig. ,View A) where: Dimension S = 0.540 to 0.580 inch (13.7-14.7mm). Dimension S = Length of cable end extending beyond fuel shut-off valve lever. Tighten the nut (15) against nut (14). Hold nut (15) and tighten and torque nut (14) 24 to 36 lb.in. (2.7-4.1 Nm). Measure Dimension S to make sure it is within limits.

DO NOT HAMMER FUEL SHUT-OFF VALVE TRIPPER SLEEVE.Using a soft drift apply even pressure on
tripper sleeve F24FT08A01 1 (15, Fig. ) to make sure sleeve is fully seated.

Set tension on tripper sleeve as follows: Adjust nuts (4 and 6, Fig. ) to obtain Dimension T (Ref. Section A-A Fig. ), where: Dimension T = (Dimension AA - 0.005) ± 0.003 inch The tripper sleeve is set when the cable tension pulls the sleeve out 0.005 ± 0.003 inch from it's seated position in the housing. Tighten nut (4), snug against bracket (5). Torque nut (4) 62 to 85 lb.in. (7.0-9.6 Nm).
DO NOT LUBRICATE THREADS. Position cable in hole to dimensions shown in Section A-A, by adjusting
clamp (10) F24FC07-01 1 . Torque nut (11) 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1-3.4 Nm).
DO NOT HAMMER FUEL SHUT-OFF VALVE TRIPPER SLEEVE.Using a soft drift apply even pressure on tripper sleeve (15, Fig. ) to make sure sleeve is fully seated. Check Dimension T and adjust if necessary (Ref. Step ).
Lockwire (PWC05-089) nuts (4 and 6, Fig. ).
Lockwire (PWC05-089) nuts (14 and 15) and install suitable seal to nuts.
Install fuel waste ejector (Ref. 73-10-03).

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Remove lockwire and fuel drain valve assembly (1).

Remove
transfer tube (3) F50FT17-06 1 with puller (PWC30128-6).

Remove and discard preformed packings
(2) F50FP03-13 1 ,
(4) F50FP03-19 1 and
(5) F50FP03-18 1 .

If necessary, disassemble fuel drain valve assembly (1) by removing
retaining ring (9) F23FR20-01 1 , drain valve
(8) F22FV01A01 1 or
(10) F22FV01A01 1 and
spring (7) F50FS44-04 1 from
drain valve adapter (6) F50FA03-06 1 .

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install lubricated preformed packings
(4) F50FP03-19 1 and
(5) F50FP03-18 1 on
transfer tube (3) F50FT17-06 1 .
Install transfer tube (3), with pusher (PWC30128-6), through outer bypass duct into gas generator.

If necessary, assemble drain valve adapter assembly (1) as follows: 25192 and 25201: Place
spring (7) F50FS44-04 1 inside
drain valve adapter (6) F50FA03-06 1 and position the
drain valve (8) F50FV01-02 1 with bottom side facing the adapter. Push the valve against the spring and install
retaining ring (9) F23FR20-01 1
25192 and 25201: Place spring (7) inside drain valve adapter (6) and position the
drain valve (10) F50FV01-02 1 with bottom side facing the adapter. Push the valve against the spring and install retaining ring (9).

Install drain valve adapter as follows: 25192 and 25201: Lubricate threads of drain valve adapter (1) and preformed packing (5) with engine oil (PWC03-001). Install preformed packing (5) onto drain valve adapter (1). Install drain valve adapter (1) into the lower bypass duct and torque 225 to 250 lb. in.
