25378: Install gasket (16) on J30 connector (15) and position connector in left lower bypass duct half with master keyway at top center. Attach with nut plate (14), four washers (13) and four screws (12) (Ref. View B). Torque the screws 6 to 7 lbf.in. (0.6-0.8 Nm).

Position
loop clamp (18) F50EC07-01 1 on wiring harness (1). Attach clamp (18) to right lower side fairing with
bolt (17) B23EB20-01 1 (Ref. Detail C). Torque bolt 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

Position
loop clamp (35) A15EC07-01 1 on wiring harness (1). Attach clamp to P3 tube assembly (36) with
bolt (34) A15EB20-06 1 and
nut (33) A15EN05-01 1 (Ref. View J). Torque nut 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

DO NOT LUBRICATE THREADS.Position
loop clamp (31) A15EC07-01 A15AC07-17 1,1 on wiring harness (1). Attach clamps (31) to
bracket (32) A15EB40-05 1 with
bolt (30) A15AB20-20 1 and
self-locking nut (29) A15AN05-17 1 (Ref. View J). Torque nut 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).

DO NOT LUBRICATE THREADS.Position
loop clamp (28) A15AC07-09 A15EC07-01 1,1 on wiring harness (1). Attach clamps (28) to P3 adapter flange mounted bracket with
bolt (27) A15AB20-29 1 and
self-locking nut (26) A15AN05-42 1 (Ref. View H). Torque nut 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).

DO NOT LUBRICATE THREADS.Position
loop clamp (24) A15EC07-01 1 on wiring harness (1). Attach clamps (24),
spacer (23) A15AS33-04 1 with
bolt (25) A15AB20-24 1 and
self-locking nut (22) A15AN05-17 1 (Ref. View F). Torque nut 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).

DO NOT LUBRICATE THREADS.Position
loop clamp (21) A15EC07-01 1 on wiring harness (1). Attach clamps (21),
spacer (44) A15AS33-05 1 to flange mounted bracket with
bolt (20) A15AB20-20 1 and
self-locking nut (19) A15AN05-17 1 (Ref. View E). Torque nut 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).
Install upper section of bypass ducts (Ref. Ch. 72-70-01).
Install top P2.8 supply tube (Ref. 75-30-01).
Restore electrical power to appropriate system and reset EEC circuit breaker.
Select maintenance test discrete OFF after wiring harness installation (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Refer to Chapter 71-00-00 for checks following installation of engine wiring harness.
Pull EEC circuit breaker to OFF.

n-para.title: General (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The spark ignition system has been developed to provide the engine with an ignition system capable of quick light up over a wide temperature range. Two exciter units, two individual high tension cable assemblies and two spark igniters are utilized. The system is energized from the aircraft normal 28 volt DC supply and will operate in the 9 to 30 volt range.

n-para.title: Ignition Exciter (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The dual ignition exciter units are mounted and secured to a bracket on the right-hand side of the bottom section of the outer bypass duct. Four flexible absorption mounts are interposed between the mounting bracket and the bypass duct, thus dampening the effect of engine-induced vibration. Each exciter unit is secured to the mounting bracket with four bolts. Eight plate nuts are riveted on the mounting bracket to receive the exciter unit mounting bolt. Electrical bonding is achieved by a copper strap between the two units and a cable between one of the units and the rudder bias system transfer tube.

The ignition exciters are sealed units containing electronic components encased in an epoxy resin. The exciters transform the DC input to a pulsed high voltage output through solid state circuitry, a transformer and diodes.

n-para.title: Ignition Cables (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The two individual ignition cable assemblies carry the electrical energy output from the ignition exciters to the engine-mounted spark igniters. Each lead assembly consists of an electrical lead encased in a flexible metal braiding. Coupling nuts at each end of the assembly facilitate connection to respective connectors on ignition exciter and spark igniter.

n-para.title: Spark Igniters (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para:
Two spark igniters, located at 4 and 5 o'clock positions respectively on the combustion chamber outer case, are screwed through bosses on the case to locate in the combustion chamber. The igniters are in the form of a threaded plug with a central positive electrode enclosed in an annular semi-conducting material. The electrical potential developed by the ignition exciter is applied across the gap between the central conductor and the igniter shell (ground). As this potential increases, a small current passes across the air gap. This current increases until the air between the central conductor and the shell ionizes. When ionization occurs, high energy discharges across the surface of the semi-conductor. The spark always occurs somewhere in the annular space between the central conductor and shell.
Ignition System Components

general.para: Lubricate preformed packings, threads and mating surfaces with engine oil unless otherwise stated.
Install protective caps and plugs in disconnected tubes, component openings and electrical connectors after disassembly.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.
Refer to INTRODUCTION for alternate products, suppliers and suppliers addresses.

n-para.title: Removal/Installation
n-para.warning: VOLTAGE OUTPUT OF IGNITION EXCITER IS SUFFICIENT TO CAUSE A LETHAL ELECTRICAL SHOCK. RESIDUAL VOLTAGE IN IGNITION EXCITER MAY BE DANGEROUSLY HIGH. MAKE SURE IGNITION IS SWITCHED OFF. DISCONNECT INPUT CONNECTOR FIRST (REF. AIRFRAME MAINTENANCE MANUAL) AND ALLOW AT LEAST SIX MINUTES TO ELAPSE BEFORE FURTHER WORK IS ATTEMPTED. DISCONNECT IGNITER CABLES AT EXCITER BEFORE DISCONNECTING AT IGNITER PLUGS. ALWAYS USE INSULATED TOOLS TO REMOVE CABLE COUPLING NUTS. DO NOT TOUCH OUTPUT CONNECTORS OR COUPLING NUTS WITH BARE HANDS.
n-para.caution: DO NOT LET IGNITION CABLE BRAIDING OR FERRULES ROTATE WHEN TURNING COUPLING NUTS.

procedure.title: Removal of Ignition Exciters (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Isolate power from ignition system.
Remove igniter cable assemblies from connectors of ignition exciters.

Remove sealant from
bolts (6) F23JB20-02 1 at
electrical lead (4) F23JC01-01 1 and
connecting strap (7) F50JS25-02 1 . Remove eight bolts (6), three washers
(5) F23JW03-01 2 and
(8) F50JW05-01 2 and connecting strap (7).
25378: Remove the bolt (3) and washer (2) from the electrical bracket (1) and remove the electrical bracket (1) from the electrical lead (4).
25378: Remove the nut (15) and spacer (16) from electrical lead (4) at the bypass duct.
Remove electrical lead (4) and two ignition exciters (9) from mounting plate (13).

Remove mounting plate (13) if necessary, by removing
bolts (10) F23JB20-01 4 and
washers (11) F23JW03-02 4 .

procedure.title: Installation of Ignition Exciters (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Position
mounting plate (13) F50JP16-01
on bypass duct and secure with four
bolts (10) F23JB20-01 4 and
washers (11) F23JW03-02 4 . Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

Position
ignition exciters (9) F50JE07-01 2 with input connectors towards front of engine on mounting plate and secure with
bolts (6) F23JB20-02 1 . Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

Clean contact area of
connecting strap (7) F50JS25-02 1 with isopropyl alcohol (PWC11-014) and install with bolts (6) and
washers (8) F50JW05-01 2 . Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

25378: Clean contact area on ends of
lead (4) F23JC01-01 1 , bracket (1) and ignition exciter (9) with isopropyl alcohol (PWC11-014).

25378: Clean contact area on ends of
lead (4) F23JC01-01 1 and ignition exciter (9) with isopropyl alcohol (PWC11-014).

25378: Lubricate threads of the two bolts (3) and (6) with engine oil (PWC03-001). Install lead with bolts
(3) F23JB20-02 1 and (6) and washers
(2) F23JW03-01 2 and
(5) F23JW03-01 2 . Torque the bolts 36 to 40 lbf.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

25378: Lubricate threads of the bolt (6) and nut (15) with engine oil (PWC03-001). Install one end of the lead with the bolt (6) and washer (5) at the ignition exciter and the other end of the lead with nut (15) and spacer (16) at the bypass duct. Torque the bolt (6) and nut (15) 36 to 40 lbf.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Apply a coat of sealant (PWC09-001) to electrical contact areas on connecting strap (7) and lead (4).
Connect ignition cable assemblies to connectors on ignition exciters (Ref. Subpara ).
Reconnect input cable to ignition exciter (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).

procedure.title: Removal of Ignition Cables (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Loosen coupling nuts (24) and disconnect
ignition cables (23) F23JC01-02 2 from
ignition exciters (11) F50JE07-01 2 .

Remove
nut (10) F23JN05-02 1 ,
spacer (9) F23JS33-01 1 and
bolt (8) F23JB20-03 1 . Remove two
loop clamps (7) F23JC07-03 2 .

If necessary, remove two
nuts (20) B23NN05-24 2 ,
washers (22) B23NW03-06 2 ,
bolt (21) B23NB20-28 2 and
bracket (19) F23JB40-03 1 .

Remove
nut (6) F23JN05-02 1 ,
bolt (5) F23JB20-04 1 and two
clamps (4) F23JC07-03 2 .

Remove four
bolts (3) F23JB20-05 4 , two
brackets (2) F23JB40A02 2 and two
grommets (1) F23JG17-01 2 .

Remove screws (17) and fairing (18) to gain access to
grommet (13) B23NG17-01 1 and remove grommet from stiffener ring of inner bypass duct.

Remove
bolt (16) F23JB20-06 1 ,
clamp (15) F23JC07-04 1 and
cushion (14) F23JC20-01 2 .
25384: Remove bolt (26), spacer (27) and loop clamp (28).
Loosen coupling nuts (12) and disconnect ignition cables from spark igniters.

procedure.title: Installation of Ignition Cables (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Install spark igniters (Ref. Subpara. ).

UNDER NO CIRCUMSTANCES IS LUBRICANT GREASE OR SILICONE, OR LUBRICANTS SUCH AS PETROLATUM TO BE USED ON ANY IGNITION COMPONENT. DO NOT ALLOW ANY LUBRICANT TO COME IN CONTACT WITH CENTRAL CONDUCTORS OF CABLES. SUCH CONTACT MAY RESULT IN A HIGH RESISTANCE PATH, POSSIBLY GENERATING HEAT AND OXIDATION.Connect cable coupling nuts (12) to
spark igniters (25) B22JI01-01 2 . Torque 240 to 260 lb.in. (27.1-29.4 Nm).
25384: Attach the loop clamp (28) to the ignition cable (23) and install with spacer (27) and bolt (26). Torque bolt 36 to 40 lbf.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

Install
grommet (13) B23NG17-01 1 around cables and slide into stiffener of inner bypass duct.

Position
cushion (14) F23JC20-01 2 and
clamp (15) F23JC07-04 1 on igniter cables and fasten to fairing with
bolt (16) F23JB20-06 1 . Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Install fairing (18) with screws (17) and torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

Place two
grommet halves (1) F23JG17-01 2 around cables and press into boss on outer bypass duct. Secure with two
brackets (2) F23JB40A02 2 and four
bolts (3) F23JB20-05 4 . Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm) in a star pattern.

Install two
loop clamps (4) F23JC07-03 2 with
bolt (5) F23JB20-04 1 and
nut (6) F23JN05-02 1 . Torque 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1-3.4 Nm).

UNDER NO CIRCUMSTANCES IS LUBRICANT GREASE OR SILICONE, OR LUBRICANTS SUCH AS PETROLATUM TO BE USED ON ANY IGNITION COMPONENT. DO NOT ALLOW ANY LUBRICANT TO COME IN CONTACT WITH CENTRAL CONDUCTORS OF CABLES. SUCH CONTACT MAY RESULT IN A HIGH RESISTANCE PATH, POSSIBLY GENERATING HEAT AND OXIDATION.Connect cable coupling nuts (24) to ignition exciters. Torque 140 to 160 lb.in. (15.8-18.1 Nm).

DO NOT LUBRICATE THREADS. Locate
bracket (19) F23JB40-03 1 on rear flange of lower outer bypass duct, on fifth and sixth holes with two
bolt (21) B23NB20-28 2 ,
washers (22) B23NW03-06 2 and
nuts (20) B23NN05-24 2 . Torque 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1-3.4 Nm).

DO NOT LUBRICATE THREADS. Install two
loop clamps (7) F23JC07-03 2 ,
spacer (9) F23JS33-01 1 ,
bolt (8) F23JB20-03 1 and
nut (10) F23JN05-02 1 . Torque 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1-3.4 Nm).

procedure.title: Removal of Spark Igniters (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Isolate power from ignition system.

Carefully remove coupling nuts (3) of igniter cable assemblies and from
spark igniters (2) B22JI01-01 2 .
Ground cable electrodes to spark shield to ensure complete electrical discharge.

Unscrew and remove spark igniters (2) and
gaskets (1) B22JG03-01 2 .
Remove gasket from each spark igniter.

procedure.title: Installation of Spark Igniters (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install
gaskets (1) B22JG03-01 2 on each
spark igniters (2) B22JI01-01 2 .

MAKE SURE THE FLOATING COLLAR AROUND THE IGNITER BOSS ON THE COMBUSTION CHAMBER LINER MOVES FREELY BEFORE INSTALLING SPARK IGNITERS. INSTALL IGNITERS BY HAND UNTIL SEATED TO ENSURE THAT NO BINDING OR FOULING OCCURS.Carefully install spark igniters with gaskets into bosses in combustion chamber outer case at 4 and 5 o'clock positions on engine without using tools, until igniters are seated.
Torque igniters 300 to 360 lb.in. (33.9-40.7 Nm).

procedure.title: Inspection of Ignition Exciter
procedure.step: Inspect for security, signs of damage and general condition.
Inspect input and output connectors for damage. Check threads for corrosion.

procedure.title: Inspection of Ignition Cables
procedure.step: Check for chafing, cuts, abrasions or other damage.
Check for security of installation.
Check operation of cables (Ref. Para. ).

procedure.title: Inspection of Spark Igniters (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Inspect the external sheath of each igniter at Dia. A for chafing and wear: Replace igniter if the following limits are exceeded: 0.0115 in. at the deepest point all around 360 degrees. 0.025 in. at deepest point over 0.350 in. circumference.

Inspect end face (View B) for: Blockage of air hole. If any air hole is blocked, reject igniter. Reduction in any air hole area. Reject igniter if evident. Erosion of electrodes. Erosion up to 0.118 inch deep is acceptable. Localized erosion of electrodes. Erosion up to 0.125 in. deep is acceptable provided 75 percent of the original surface remains within the 0.118 inch erosion band. If erosion exceeds any of these limits, reject igniter. Erosion of ground electrodes is acceptable up to 0.400 in. diameter. Measure at tip of the inner diameter (Ref. Fig. ).
Check operation of spark igniters (Ref. Para. ).

procedure.title: Cleaning of Ignition Exciter
procedure.step: Remove all corrosion residue, using a stainless steel wire brush, taking care not to damage gold plating on the terminal pins.

Clean affected surface thoroughly, using a clean, lint-free cloth moistened with isopropyl alcohol (PWC11-014) or acetone (PWC11-012) or ardrox leeder 1064K (PWC11-023+) or desoclean 45 (PWC11-025+) or envirosolv 655 (PWC11-005+).
Apply light film of spray lubricant (PWC06-005) to cleaned areas.

procedure.title: Cleaning of Spark Igniters
procedure.caution: DROPPED IGNITERS MAY SUFFER INTERNAL DAMAGE NOT DETECTABLE BY TEST. DISCARD ANY IGNITER THAT HAS BEEN DROPPED.

DO NOT TRY TO REMOVE ANY HARD CARBON DEPOSITS FROM CENTER ELECTRODE AS SUCH DEPOSITS AID THE FUNCTIONING OF THE IGNITER. ANY ABRASIVE ACTION IN GAP AREA MAY IMPAIR FUNCTIONING BY THE REMOVAL OF SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIAL. DO NOT USE WIRE BRUSH TO CLEAN.
procedure.step: Install a suitable cap over electrode end of igniter to prevent contamination by cleaning fluid.

Clean inside of terminal well with a felt swab soaked in isopropyl alcohol (PWC11-014) or acetone (PWC11-012) or ardrox leeder 1064K (PWC11-023+) or desoclean 45 (PWC11-025+) or envirosolv 655 (PWC11-005+). Do not damage terminal pin during cleaning operation.
Dry using clean, dry, filtered compressed air.

n-para.title: Adjustment/Test
n-para.warning: VOLTAGE OUTPUT OF IGNITION EXCITER IS SUFFICIENT TO CAUSE A LETHAL ELECTRICAL SHOCK. RESIDUAL VOLTAGE IN IGNITION EXCITER MAY BE DANGEROUSLY HIGH. ENSURE IGNITION IS SWITCHED OFF. DISCONNECT INPUT CONNECTOR FIRST (REF. AIRFRAME MAINTENANCE MANUAL) AND ALLOW AT LEAST SIX MINUTES TO ELAPSE BEFORE FURTHER WORK IS ATTEMPTED. DISCONNECT IGNITER CABLES AT EXCITER BEFORE DISCONNECTING AT IGNITER PLUGS. ALWAYS USE INSULATED TOOLS TO REMOVE CABLE COUPLING NUTS. DO NOT TOUCH OUTPUT CONNECTORS OR COUPLING NUTS WITH BARE HANDS.
n-para.caution: DO NOT ALLOW IGNITION CABLE BRAIDING OR FERRULES TO ROTATE WHEN TURNING COUPLING NUTS.

procedure.title: Function Test
procedure.caution: BEFORE SWITCHING ON IGNITION TO DO AN OPERATIONAL CHECK, DO A DRY MOTORING RUN 71-00-00, ADJUSTMENT/TEST TO MAKE SURE NO FUEL REMAINS IN GAS GENERATOR CASE.
procedure.step: Switch ignition system OFF.
Isolate electrical power from ignition system (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Disconnect one igniter input lead at exciter unit.
Restore electrical power to ignition system (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Switch ignition ON.
Listen for regular frequency snapping sound. Switch ignition OFF.
Reconnect igniter cable to exciter unit and remove igniter cable from other exciter unit. Repeat steps and .
If snapping sound is not heard on either check, replace ignition exciter and repeat steps through .
If snapping sound is not heard on one check only, replace associated spark igniter and/or ignition cable and repeat operation check. If spark igniter still fails, replace ignition exciter.
Repeat steps through .
Restore ignition system to standard operating condition.
Refer to Chapter 71-00-00 for checks following installation of ignition system components.

n-para.title: General
n-para.para: High pressure (HP) compressor discharge air is bled off to provide pressurizing air for bearing compartment oil seals, cooling air for the turbine section, air for the compressor bleed valves and hot air for anti-icing protection of the low pressure (LP) compressor stator and nose cone. Additionally, bleed air is provided for the Electronic Engine Control and for aircraft services.

n-para.title: Bearing Compartment Seals - Pressurizing Air (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: Oil is contained within the bearing compartments by bleeding air pressure through carbon seals and/or labyrinth seals towards each bearing. The labyrinth seals used on the engine consist of two parts: a labyrinth and a runner. The rotating labyrinths have a series of annular grooves machined in their outer surfaces, while the corresponding runners have plain or honeycombed surfaces. Each matched pair forms an airseal and controls the required pressure gradient.

P2.8 pressurizing air, bled from the fourth-stage of the HP compressor, is split into two paths; one is ducted through the intermediate case and into the hollow LP and HP compressor shafts, where it is directed to the Nos. 1, 2 and 4 bearing compartments. The second path passes through the gas generator case via an internal passageway into the No. 3 bearing compartment.

The carbon seals at the rear of the No. 1 bearing and at the front of the No. 2 bearing are pressurized by the flow of air passing through the intermediate case into the intershaft space. Holes at the front of the LP shaft direct the air into the labyrinth seal at the front of the No. 1 bearing. Air is allowed to leak through the labyrinth to form a pressure seal, and is then vented to the inlet air stream behind the inlet cone.

Holes in the HP compressor shaft direct a portion of the intershaft flow of air to the rear labyrinth and carbon seal of the No. 2 bearing. Air leakage through the seals exits into the gas stream at the first-stage of the HP compressor rotor.

Air pressure inside the LP shaft flows forward into the nose cone and rearward into the front labyrinth seal of the No. 4 bearing compartment, venting into the exhaust gas stream behind the third-stage LP turbine. The No. 4 bearing compartment is sealed at the rear by the LP turbine case, hence no labyrinth seal is required at the rear.

P2.8 air entering the No. 3 bearing compartment is directed around the bearing into the front and rear bearing covers, pressurizing the front and rear labyrinth and carbon seals. Impeller backface air assists in the pressurization and is allowed to leak into the bearing compartment. Excess air flows through holes in the HP turbine shaft and the HP turbine assembly into the intershaft space.
The air entering the bearing compartments is also used to assist the oil scavenge flow to the accessory gearbox from where it is vented to atmosphere through the centrifugal breather.

n-para.title: High Pressure (HP) Turbine Disks and Stators - Cooling Air (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: Air from around the combustion chamber liner (P3) passes through the HP turbine disk air nozzle and the HP turbine baffle to cool the HP turbines and stators. Air from the nozzle is directed at the hub of the first-stage HP turbine disk and is directed across the disk face by a cover. The cover directs the air through the blade roots and into the hollow turbine blades, exiting into the gas path through holes in the trailing edges. Cooling air for the second-stage HP turbine disk flows from the impeller backface, through holes in the HP turbine disk assembly and is directed along the disk faces through holes in the interstage baffle and a stacked multi-stage seal. The air then passes through the second-stage blade roots and exits into the gas stream.

Cooling air passing around the outside diameter of the HP turbine assembly is directed by the HP turbine baffle to the shroud segments and stator assemblies. Hollow vanes on the first-stage HP turbine stator assembly allow internal flow of cooling air which exits the vanes through holes in the trailing edges.
P2.8 air leaving the intershaft space at the rear of the HP turbine assembly is directed across the LP turbine disk faces and through the blade roots and exits into the gas stream.

n-para.title: Anti-icing - Hot Air (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The nose and LP compressor inner stator are heated by pressurized hot air (P2.8) routed from the fourth-stage compressor. A solenoid valve controls the flow to the inner stator while the nose cone is fed hot air continuously.

The nose cone is heated by hot air flowing from the inside of the LP shaft, through the hollow nose cone extension and into the double-walled nose cone. A small part of the air is discharged through the nose cone central tie bolt. The hot air inside the nose cone vents into the air stream ahead of the fan. The hot air which heats the nose cone follows a different path from the rest of the anti-icing air and hence is not controlled by the anti-icing solenoid valve.

A transfer tube from the solenoid valve directs the flow of hot air into a cavity in the intermediate case to heat the inner fan stators. Air exiting from the fan stators is vented into the core air-flow.

n-para.title: Compressor Bleed Valves (Ref. Figs. and )
n-para.para: The bleed valves consist of two-position (open/closed) piston type valves, operating in ported housings. The P2.8 bleed valve pistons are spring loaded open, allowing compressor air to vent into the bypass air-flow. When P3 compressor discharge pressure from the solenoid valve is applied, spring force is overcome and the pistons are closed. The pistons are supported in their housings by two sealing rings and a guide pin. The inner piston ring is metal, while the outer ring is made from heat-resistant plastic. The piston rings seal the chamber at the top of the piston, while the guide pin permits full travel of the piston in either direction, to open or close the housing ports.

The compressor bleed solenoid valve located at the top of the HP compressor rear case, supported by a bracket on the rear flange controls the P3 air supply to P2.5 valves (3 and 9 o'clock positions) and P2.8 valve (7 o'clock position). Another bleed valve solenoid at 7 o'clock position controls the bleed valve at 11 o'clock position. The valve is normally closed, blocking the flow of P3 air from the diffuser to the compressor bleed valves. The solenoid consists of a dual coil housing surrounding an armature assembly, attached to a shaft and ball-type piston. The piston is spring-loaded closed until the solenoid is energized by the EEC, causing the armature to overcome the spring force, opening the valve and directing P3 air to the bleed valves.

n-para.title: Linear Stator Vane Actuator (Ref. Fig.)
n-para.para: The linear actuator is located on the top of the HP compressor case. The actuator body is mounted to the rear flange of the front HP compressor case by a supporting bracket. The actuator piston rod is connected to the master lever of the HP CVV drive system. The master lever is free to pivot on Teflon lined bushings.

The linear actuator uses fuel from the HMU for hydraulic power. The actuator is controlled by a torquemotor valve contained in the HMU. An electrical signal from the EEC energizes one of two windings (Channel A or B) on the torquemotor valve, which alter the two hydraulic (fuel pressure) signals going to the actuator. Fuel pressure from the actuator directs the fuel into the cylinder assembly. The differential pressure in the cylinder causes linear movement of the piston, thus driving the actuator output levers. A third transfer tube drains internal fuel leakage from the actuator to an airframe supplied drain.

Displacement of the piston is sensed by a linear variable differential transformer (LVDT)-type position transducer in the actuator, which converts the signal from mechanical to electrical, and feeds the signal back to the EEC. When the electrical feedback signal from the actuator matches the EEC-calculated demand signal, hydraulic signals are equalized and actuator movement ceases.

n-para.title: Airframe Services
n-para.para: Pads, located at the 3 and 9 o'clock positions on the gas generator case and the HP compressor rear case, enable airframe supplied equipment to utilize engine P3 compressor discharge air pressure. The pads provide off-take of air from around the diffuser pipes.

general.para: Use engine oil to lubricate preformed packings, threads and mating surfaces, unless otherwise stated.
Install protective caps and plugs on disconnected tubes, component openings and electrical connectors after sub-assembly.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.
Refer to INTRODUCTION for alternate products, suppliers and suppliers addresses.

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.caution: ENSURE AIRFRAME ELECTRICAL POWER IS OFF WHEN HANDLING ELECTRICAL CONNECTORS.
ENSURE CONNECTOR PLUGS ARE FREE OF MOISTURE; IF NECESSARY, DRY USING HEAT GUN.
DO NOT FORCE OR STRETCH HARNESS WHEN INSTALLING CONNECTORS OR SECURING LOOP CLAMPS.
USE ONLY APPROVED TOOLS TO TIGHTEN HARNESS CONNECTORS. CONNECTORS ARE PROPERLY TIGHTENED WHEN ONLY BLUE COLOR BAND IS VISIBLE; RED COLOR BAND MUST NOT BE VISIBLE.
procedure.step: Select maintenance test discrete ON before anti-ice solenoid valve removal (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Remove engine nacelle, sufficient to gain access to engine by-pass duct (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Remove upper portion of by-pass duct (inner and outer) (Ref. 72-70-01).

Remove two
bolts (1) A15AB20-06 2 securing
P3 tube assembly (2) A15AT17A12 1 to
solenoid valve (3) A15BV01-01 1 .

25095: Remove
nut (14) A15AN05-34 2 ,
bolt (15) A15AB20-28 2 and
clamp (16) A15AC07-05 2 from the
bracket (17) A15AB40-15 1 .

Remove
nut (18) A15AN05-11 1 ,
bolt (19) A15AB20-08 1 and
clamp (20) A15AC07-01 1 from bracket (21).
Remove the lockwire and P3 tube coupling nut (22). Remove P3 tube assembly (2).
Disconnect electrical connector P18 (4) at solenoid valve.

Remove two
nuts (5) A15AN05-04 2 ,
bolts (6) A15AB20-05 2 and
retaining plate (7) A15AB40-12 1 .

Slide
transfer tube (8) A15AT17-04 1 part way into
anti-icing tube (9) A14AT17A01 1 , remove solenoid valve (3) together with
gasket (10) A15AG03-14 1 , discard gasket.

DO NOT PRY ON HP COMPRESSOR CASE MOUNTED ELBOW TO ASSIST REMOVAL OR INSTALLATION OF VALVE.Remove transfer tubes (8) and
(11) A15AT17-05 1 , remove and discard
seals (12) F50AS06-06 A15AS06-05 2,2 .

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
DO NOT LUBRICATE PLAIN SEALS.Install new plain
seals (12) F50AS06-06 A15AS06-05 2,2 on transfer tubes
(8) A15AT17-04 1 and
(11) A15AT17-05 1 . Install open end of seals toward open end of tube.

Install
retaining ring (13) A15AR20-04 1 on tube but do not engage in slot.
Install transfer tube (11).

Slide transfer tube (8) part way into
anti-icing tube (9) A14AT17A01 1 .

Insert
gasket (10) A15AG03-14 1 into recess of
solenoid valve (3) A15BV01-01 1 .
Note position of airflow arrow on solenoid valve (3) and install valve onto transfer tube (11). Slide transfer tube (8) into open end of solenoid valve.

DO NOT LUBRICATE THREADS. Install
retaining plate (7) A15AB40-12 1 and secure using two
bolts (6) A15AB20-05 2 and
nuts (5) A15AN05-04 2 , torque nuts 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).
Install retaining ring (13) on slot of tube (8).

USE ONLY APPROVED TOOLS TO TIGHTEN WIRING HARNESS CONNECTORS. CONNECTORS ARE FULLY TIGHTENED WHEN ONLY THE BLUE COLOR BAND IS VISIBLE, RED COLOR BAND MUST NOT BE VISIBLE. Install electrical connector P18 (4) onto solenoid valve. Torque connector P18 (4) 24 to 29 lb.in. (2.7-3.3 Nm).

Secure
P3 tube assembly (2) A15AT17A12 1 to solenoid valve using two
bolts (1) A15AB20-06 2 , torque bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).
Attach P3 tube assembly with coupling nut (22). Torque coupling nut 90 to 100 lb.in. (10-11 Nm) and safety with lockwire (PWC05-089).

DO NOT LUBRICATE THREADS.Install
clamp (20) A15AC07-01 1 ,
bolt (19) A15AB20-08 1 and
nut (18) A15AN05-11 1 on bracket (21). Torque nut 27 to 30 lb.in (3.0-3.4 Nm).

DO NOT LUBRICATE THREADS.25095: Install
clamp (16) A15AC07-05 2 ,
bolt (15) A15AB20-28 2 and
nut (14) A15AN05-34 2 on the
bracket (17) A15AB40-15 1 . Torque nut 27 to 30 lb.in (3.0-3.4 Nm).
Assemble by-pass duct (Ref. 72-70-01).
Assemble engine nacelle (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Restore electrical power to appropriate system and reset EEC circuit breaker to ON.
Select maintenance test discrete to OFF.
Refer to Chapter 71-00-00 for checks following installation of anti-ice solenoid valve.
Restore aircraft to normal operating condition (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).

general.para: Use engine oil to lubricate preformed packings, threads and mating surfaces, unless otherwise stated.
Install protective caps and plugs on disconnected tubes, component openings and electrical connectors after sub-assembly.

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: The following procedure applies to either the right or left-hand cabin bleed air tube assembly.
procedure.step:
Remove six
bolts (2) F50AB20-26 6 or (7),
LP bleed pad cover (3) F50AC28-02 1 , or shipping cover (8) and
cabin air tube retainer (9) F50AR03-02 1 , as applicable, and
LP bleed pad gasket (4) F50FG03-04 2 . Discard gasket (4).

Remove
cabin air bleed tube assembly (6) F50AT17A01 F50AT17A01 1,1 using puller (PWC60714). Remove and discard preformed packings
(1) F50AP03-02 2 and
(5) F50AP03-04 2 .
Repeat steps (1 and 2) to remove cabin air bleed tube assembly (6) from opposite side of engine.
Place protective covers on cabin air bleed covers and store in sealable plastic bags.

Remove five
bolts (10) pw306a-751002-001-0130 10 and shipping cover from
HP bleed air tube (11) F50AT17-05 2 .

Remove two
bolts (14) F50AB20-02 4 securing HP bleed air tube (11) to compressor case.

Remove HP bleed air tube (11). Remove and discard gaskets
(12) F50AG03-06 2 and
(13) F50AG03-05 2 .
Repeat steps , and to remove remaining HP bleed air tube.
Place protective covers on bleed air tubes. Store tubes in sealable plastic containers.

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: Although cabin air can be taken from either the left or right-hand side of the engine, the cabin air tube retainer (9) is normally installed on the engine left-hand side at engine assembly.
procedure.step:
Lubricate new preformed packings
(1) F50AP03-02 2 and
(5) F50AP03-04 2 and install on
cabin air bleed tube assembly (6) F50AT17A01 F50AT17A01 1,1 .
Install cabin air bleed tube assembly through right-hand LP bleed pad on outer bypass duct; ensure tube is seated in bleed air boss on gas generator case.

Install
gasket (4) F50FG03-04 2 and
cover (3) F50AC28-02 1 on LP bleed pad and secure with six
bolts (2) F50AB20-26 6 . Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).
Lubricate preformed packings (1 and 5) and install on remaining cabin air bleed tube assembly (6).
Install cabin air bleed tube assembly (6) through left-hand LP bleed pad on outer bypass duct; ensure tube is seated in bleed air boss on gas generator.

Install new gasket (4),
cabin air tube retainer (9) F50AR03-02 1 and shipping cover (8) on LP bleed pad and secure with six bolts (7). Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).

Install new
gasket (12) F50AG03-06 2 and
metal gasket (13) F50AG03-05 2 over
HP air bleed tube (11) F50AT17-05 2 .

Install HP bleed tube (11) through right-hand HP bleed pad on outer bypass duct, and secure with two
bolts (14) F50AB20-02 4 . Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).

Secure outer flange of HP bleed tube (11) to bleed pad on outer bypass duct with five
bolts (10) pw306a-751002-001-0130 10 . Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).
Repeat steps , and to install left-hand HP bleed tube (11).
Place protective covers over right and left-hand HP bleed tubes.

Install protective caps and plugs on disconnected tubes, component openings and electrical connectors after disassembly.

procedure.title: Access to P2.8 Bleed Valves

procedure.title: Removal of Bottom P2.8 Compressor Bleed Valve (25095) (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: Bottom P2.8 Compressor Bleed Valve - Removal/Installation (25095)

procedure.step:
Remove
nuts (1) A15AN05-01 2 ,
bolts (2) A15AB20-15 2 and

Remove lockwire and disconnect coupling nut (13).

Remove

Remove
tube (4) A15AT17A02 1 and

Remove
nut (14) A15AB20-29 1 ,

Remove
bolts (10) A15AS02-03 3 ,

procedure.step:

Install
sleeve spacer (5) A15AS33-01 1 into

retaining ring (6) A15AR20-01 1 .

DO NOT OVER-EXTEND METAL SEAL RING (5) DURING INSTALLATION. GAP MUST BE 0.035 TO 0.065 INCH WHEN INSTALLED.Install
seal ring (7) A15AS06-01 1 into groove on bleed valve piston (4).
Install piston (4) into bleed valve housing (8).

MAKE SURE HELICAL SPRING IS ASSEMBLED ON THE CORRECT SIDE OF THE PISTON.Install
helical spring (3) A15AS44-01 1 into groove of piston (4).

Install
bleed valve seat (2) A15AS16-01 1 . Coat threads of
screws (1) A15AS02-02 3 with anti-seize compound (PWC06-004) and secure bleed valve seat to bleed valve housing (8). Torque screws 10 to 11.5 lb.in. (1.1-1.3 Nm).

procedure.title: Compressor Bleed Valves
procedure.step: Wash parts in clean alcohol (PWC11-014) or acetone (PWC11-012). If necessary, use nylon bristle brush to remove contaminants.
Dry parts with clean, dry, filtered compressed air blast, or allow parts to stand and air dry.

procedure.title: Compressor Bleed Valve Housing
procedure.step: Visual checks: Check bleed valve piston bore for burnishing. Light surface burnish is acceptable. Check piston shaft guide for security, scores or scratches. Polish using crocus cloth to remove raised metal. Check all other machined surfaces for raised metal and sharp edges. Stone to remove. Check for local surface damage. Damage is acceptable to 0.005 inch deep and not acceptable beyond 0.008 inch deep. Damage from 0.005 to 0.008 inch deep can be blended to a maximum depth of 0.010 inch.

Dimensional checks: Inspect piston shaft guides for wear as follows: For P2.5 bleed valve housing, reject housing if diameter is less than 0.2350 inch (Fits and Clearances REF. NO. 1235). For P2.8 bleed valve housing, reject housing if diameter is less than 0.2337 inch (Fits and Clearances REF. NO. 1293). Inspect bore diameter for wear as follows: For P2.5 bleed valve housing, reject housing if dimension is more than 2.4060 inch (Fits and Clearances REF. NO. 1231). For P2.8 bleed valve housing, reject housing if dimension is more than 1.8420 inch (Fits and Clearances REF. NO. 1289).

procedure.title: Compressor Bleed Valve Piston
procedure.step: Visual checks: Check valve seat area for wear or damage. Reject if damage is evident. Check sealing ring and retaining ring grooves for nicks, burrs or raised metal. Stone to remove raised metal or sharp edges. Check all other surfaces for local surface damage. Stone to remove. Damage is acceptable to 0.002 inch deep and not acceptable beyond 0.005 inch deep. Damage from 0.002 to 0.005 inch deep can be blended to a maximum depth of 0.005 inch.

Dimensional checks: Check sealing ring groove as follows: For P2.5 bleed valve piston, reject piston if groove is more than 0.129 inch. For P2.8 bleed valve piston, reject piston if groove is more than 0.0975 inch. Check remainder of P2.5 bleed valve piston dimensions (Ref. Fits and Clearances REF. NOs. 1231, 1232, 1234 and 1235). Check remainder of P2.8 bleed valve piston dimensions (Ref. Fits and Clearances REF. NOs. 1289, 1290, 1292 and 1293).

procedure.title: Sleeve Spacer
procedure.step: Visual checks: Check for any surface damage. Reject if damage is evident.

Dimensional checks: For P2.5 bleed valve, reject sleeve if bore diameter is more than 0.2385 inch (Ref. Fits and Clearances REF. NO. 1235). For P2.8 bleed valve, reject sleeve if bore diameter is more than 0.2357 inch. (Ref. Fits and Clearances REF. NO. 1293). For P2.5 bleed valve, reject sleeve if outside diameter is less than 0.4930 inch (Ref. Fits and Clearances REF. NO. 1234). For P2.8 bleed valve, reject sleeve if outside diameter is less than 0.4964 inch. (Ref. Fits and Clearances REF. NO. 1292).

procedure.title: Compressor Bleed Valve Seat
procedure.step: Visual checks: Check valve seat area for wear and damage. Reject if damage is evident. Check all other machined surfaces for raised metal and sharp edges. Stone to remove. Check for local surface damage. Damage is acceptable to 0.005 inch deep and not acceptable beyond 0.008 inch deep. Damage from 0.005 to 0.008 inch deep can be blended to a maximum depth of 0.010 inch.

Dimensional checks: For P2.5 bleed valve seat, reject if inside bore diameter is more than 2.0810 inch (Ref. Fits and Clearances REF. NO. 1232). For P2.8 bleed valve seat, reject if inside bore diameter is more than 1.5050 inch. (Ref. Fits and Clearances REF. NO. 1290).

procedure.title: Visual Inspection
procedure.note: Disassembly or removal is not required to perform this task.
This task is to be performed during replacement of front core harness and BOV's solenoid (Ref. 05-20-00, SCHEDULED MAINTENANCE CHECKS).
procedure.step: Visually inspect all four BOV’s in situ. Check the general condition and cleanliness of the valves.
Make sure that all BOV’s are in fully open position.
Do the bleed valve operational check (Ref. 71-00-00, POWER PLANT - ADJUSTMENT/TEST).

n-para.title: Adjustment/Test
n-para.warning: DO NOT PLACE HANDS INTO BLEED VALVE AREA BEFORE OR DURING BLEED VALVE CHECK.
IF IT IS NECESSARY TO WORK AROUND BLEED VALVES WHILE TEST EQUIPMENT IS CONNECTED, CLOSE BALL VALVE AND REMOVE INLET AND OUTLET AIR LINES FROM FLOWMETER.

procedure.title: Flowmeter Preparation
procedure.step: Make sure Power Switch of flowmeter (PWC60790) is OFF and safety pin is installed.
Make sure air pressure valve is CLOSED.
Make sure flow meter adjustment is turned in, fully CW.
Make sure 110 VAC is not connected.

procedure.title: Function and Leak Check of Handling BOV System
procedure.step: Disconnect engine P3 supply tube from the handling, upper, BOV solenoid valve.
Disconnect engine wiring harness connector J30, Channel B, from bypass duct.
Install wiring harness connector from flowmeter on J30 receptacle on bypass duct.
Connect air supply tube from flowmeter to upper BOV solenoid using slave gasket, bolts and washers. Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb. in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
DO NOT PLACE HANDS INTO BLEED VALVE AREA BEFORE OR DURING BLEED VALVE CHECK.Visually check that all three bleed valves are OPEN.
Connect shop air to flowmeter.
Set pressure to 100 psi.
Open air pressure valve.
Turn flowmeter adjustment out, CCW, two turns.
DO NOT PLACE HANDS INTO BLEED VALVE AREA BEFORE OR DURING BLEED VALVE CHECK.Visually check that all BOVs remain OPEN. If the BOVs start to close, the solenoid is stuck open and must be replaced.
Connect 110 VAC to flowmeter.
Turn power switch ON to energize BOV solenoid.
WARNING: DO NOT PLACE HANDS INTO BLEED VALVE AREA BEFORE OR DURING BLEED VALVE CHECK.Visually check that all 3 bleed valves CLOSE.
Record BOV leakage shown on flow meter. Read the value from the bottom of the ball on the flow meter.
The maximum allowable leakage is 26.5 SCFH.
If leakage exceeds limit (Ref. Step ), put leak check fluid (PWC05-007) on all connecting flanges to determine source of leak.
If leaks are present at flanges replace gasket, re-torque bolts and repeat test.
If leakage still exceeds limit (Ref. Step ), check individual components (Ref. Para. and ).
Turn power switch OFF and visually check that all three valves OPEN under spring pressure.
If any valve does not open, tap it lightly with a rubber hammer.
If the bleed valve still does not open, replace the valve and repeat the test.

If it is required to work around bleed valves while test equipment is still attached to engine, the following precautions must be taken: Close ball valve and remove inlet and outlet lines from the flowmeter. Turn BOV power switch OFF and place the safety pin in the switch guard.
Reduce control pressure to zero, close the air pressure valve and turn flowmeter adjustment fully IN, CW.

procedure.title: Function and Leak Check of Starting BOV System
procedure.step: Disconnect P3 supply line to the start, lower, BOV solenoid valve.
Remove outer wiring harness connector J30.
Connect P3 solenoid line to AIR OUT of flowmeter with gasket, washers and bolts. Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb. in.
Connect test cable to connector J30.
DO NOT PLACE HANDS INTO BLEED VALVE AREA BEFORE OR DURING BLEED VALVE CHECK.Visually check that starting BOV is OPEN.
Adjust flowmeter to 100 psi, open air pressure valve and turn flowmeter adjustment out, CCW, two turns.
DO NOT PLACE HANDS INTO BLEED VALVE AREA BEFORE OR DURING BLEED VALVE CHECK.Visually check that start BOV is still OPEN. If valve starts to close, the solenoid is stuck open and must be replaced.
Connect 110 VAC.
Turn flowmeter power switch ON to energize solenoid.
DO NOT PLACE HANDS INTO BLEED VALVE AREA BEFORE OR DURING BLEED VALVE CHECK.Visually check that start BOV CLOSES.
Record BOV system leakage. Read the value from the bottom of the ball on the flowmeter.
Max leakage is 10.9 SCFH.
If leakage exceeds limits (Ref. Step ) apply leak check fluid (PWC05-007) to all connecting flanges. If leaks are present at flanges replace gasket, re-torque bolts and repeat Steps thru ).
If leakage is still above limits (Ref. Step ) check individual components (Ref. Para and following).
Turn flowmeter power switch OFF.
DO NOT PLACE HANDS INTO BLEED VALVE AREA BEFORE OR DURING BLEED VALVE CHECK.Visually check that start BOV opens under spring action.
If valve does not open, tap housing lightly with rubber faced hammer. If it still does not open, the valve may be seized and must be replacing.

If it is required to work around bleed valves while test equipment is still attached to engine, the following precautions must be taken: Close ball valve and remove inlet and outlet lines from the flowmeter. Turn BOV power switch OFF and place the safety pin in the switch guard.
Reduce control pressure to zero, close the air pressure valve and turn flowmeter adjustment fully IN, CW.

procedure.title: Leak Check of BOV Solenoid
procedure.step: Disconnect P3 air out from the solenoid.
Install blanking cover with gasket. Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb. in.
Adjust control pressure to 100 psi, open air pressure valve and turn flowmeter out (CCW) two turns.
Turn power switch ON and check for leaks, max. 3 SCFH.
Turn power switch OFF and remove blanking cover.
Check for leakage, max. 3 SCFH.
Reduce control pressure to zero, close the air pressure valve and turn flowmeter in (CW) two turns.
Remove air line from the upper solenoid.
Remove 110 VAC from flowmeter.
Remove test cable from connector J30.
Replace solenoid if air leak limit (Ref. Step ) is exceeded.

procedure.title: Leak Check of BOV
procedure.note: There are four BOV's. The handling system has two P2.5 and one P2.8 valves. The starting system has one P2.8 valve. It is recommended to test the leak rate of the P2.8 valve if either the start or handling system exceeds the leak limits and the solenoid leak test is correct.
procedure.step: Disconnect the air supply to the valve to be tested.
Connect flowmeter AIR OUT to the BOV with gasket, washers and bolts. Torque bolts 36 to 40 lb. in.
Adjust flowmeter to 100 psi, open air pressure valve and turn flowmeter adjustment out, (CCW), two turns.
DO NOT PLACE HANDS INTO BLEED VALVE AREA BEFORE OR DURING BLEED VALVE CHECK.Visually check to see that the bleed valve CLOSES.
Check leakage is 7.9 SCFH.
Replace valve if limit is not met.
Reduce control pressure air pressure to zero, and check that valve CLOSES.
Disconnect flowmeter from BOV.
Repeat for remaining BOVs.

row.entry: Shaft - Guide Pin, Compressor Bleed Valve Piston
Shaft - Guide Pin, Compressor Bleed Valve Piston

figure.title: Compressor Bleed Valves - Fits and Clearances

general.para: Lubricate preformed packings, threads and mating surfaces with engine oil unless otherwise stated.
Install protective caps and plugs on disconnected tubes, component openings and electrical connectors after disassembly.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.
Refer to INTRODUCTION for alternate products, suppliers and addresses.

procedure.title: Access to BOV Solenoid Valve
procedure.step: Remove the outer bypass duct and inner bypass duct(s) (Ref. 72-70-01, BYPASS DUCTS - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES) to allow access.

procedure.title: Removal of P2.5 Bleed Valve Tube (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Remove
nut (1) A15AN05-20 1 ,
bolt (2) A15AB20-23 1 ,
clamp (3) A15AC07-03 2 P3 solenoid
adapter (4) A15BV01-02 1 and
tube (5) A15AT17A19 1 .

procedure.title: Removal of P3 Tube to Lower Solenoid Valve (25095) (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: P3 Tube to Lower Solenoid Valve - Removal/Installation (25095)

procedure.step:
Remove
nut (1) A15AN05-20 1
bolt (2) A15AB20-23 A15AB20-23 1,1 and
clamp (3) A15AC07-03 2 on
tube (4) A15AT17A19 1 from bracket (5).

Remove bolt (2) from
bracket (6) A15AB40A10 1 and clamp (3) on tube (4).

procedure.title: Removal of P3 Tube to Lower Solenoid Valve (25095) (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: P3 Tube to Lower Solenoid Valve - Removal/Installation (25095)

procedure.step:
Remove
nuts (1) A15AN05-33 A15AN05-20 1,1 ,
bolts (2) A15AB20-23 1 and
clamps (3) A15AC07-03 3 .

Remove
bolt (6) A15AB20-26 1 and
clamp (7) A15AC07-03 3 .

Remove two
bolts (8) A15AB20-17 2 , two
washers (9) A15AW03-07 2 ,
tube (4) A15AT17A19 1 and
gasket (10) A15AG03-11 1 . Discard the gasket.
Remove the coupling nut (5) and tube (4).

procedure.title: Removal of P3 Solenoid Valves (25297) (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.caution: MAKE SURE AIRFRAME ELECTRICAL POWER IS OFF WHEN REMOVING/INSTALLING OF ELECTRICAL CONNECTORS.
DO NOT FORCE OR STRETCH HARNESS WHEN INSTALLING CONNECTORS OR LOOP CLAMPS.
TIGHTEN HARNESS CONNECTORS WITH APPROVED TOOL ONLY. CONNECTORS ARE PROPERLY TIGHTENED WHEN ONLY BLUE COLOR BAND IS VISIBLE.
procedure.step: Disconnect P13 connector (12), P14 connector (13), P37 connector (14) and P38 connector (15).

Remove two
nuts (1) A15AN05-18 2 and
bolts (2) A15AB20-21 2 from
bracket (3) A15AB40-10 ref . Remove
solenoid valve (4) A15BV01-02 1 .

Remove one
washer (5) A15AW03-04 2 two
bolts (6) F50AB20-27 2
adapter (7) A15AA03-01 1 and
gasket (8) A15AG03-02 1 .

Remove two
nuts (9) A15AN05-14 2
bolts (10) A15AB20-12 2 and
solenoid valve (11) A15BV01-02 1 .

procedure.title: Installation of P3 Solenoid Valves (25297) (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
ENSURE AIRFRAME ELECTRICAL POWER IS OFF WHEN HANDLING ELECTRICAL CONNECTORS. ENSURE CONNECTOR PLUGS ARE FREE OF MOISTURE; IF NECESSARY, DRY USING HEAT GUN. DO NOT FORCE OR STRETCH HARNESS WHEN INSTALLING CONNECTORS OR SECURING LOOP CLAMPS. USE ONLY APPROVED TOOLS TO TIGHTEN HARNESS CONNECTORS. CONNECTORS ARE PROPERLY TIGHTENED WHEN ONLY BLUE COLOR BAND IS VISIBLE.Install
solenoid valve (1) A15BV01-02 1 with two
bolts (2) A15AB20-12 2 and
nuts (3) A15AN05-14 2 . Torque nuts fingertight.

Install
adapter (4) A15AA03-01 1 and
gasket (5) A15AG03-02 1 with two
bolts (6) F50AB20-27 2 and one
washer (7) A15AW03-04 2 . Torque bolts fingertight.

Attach
solenoid valve (8) A15BV01-02 1 to
bracket (9) A15AB40-10 ref with two
bolts (10) A15AB20-21 2 and
nuts (11) A15AN05-18 2 . Torque nuts 27 to 30 lb. in. dry.

Engage master keyway and install P13 connector (12) to the fan side and P14 connector (13) to the exhaust side on the upper compressor bleed valve solenoid. Tightly hold the connector coupling nut with soft-jawed pliers (PWC90012) and apply hand pressure to tighten the nut until the pliers slip. Measurement of the actual torque is not required.

Engage master keyway and install P37 connector (14) to the fan side and P38 connector (15) to the exhaust side on the lower compressor bleed valve solenoid. Tightly hold the connector coupling nut with soft-jawed pliers (PWC90012) and apply hand pressure to tighten the nut until the pliers slip. Measurement of the actual torque is not required.

procedure.title: Removal of P3 Solenoid Valves (25297) (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
MAKE SURE AIRFRAME ELECTRICAL POWER IS OFF WHEN REMOVING/INSTALLING ELECTRICAL CONNECTORS. DO NOT FORCE OR STRETCH HARNESS WHEN INSTALLING CONNECTORS OR LOOP CLAMPS.Removal of Upper Solenoid Valve: Disconnect P13 connector (19) and P14 connector (20). Remove
bolts (1) A15EB20-04 2 and
(3) A15AB20-12 2 , nuts (2) and
(4) A15AN05-14 2 from the support brackets (10 and 11). Remove
solenoid valve (9) A15BV01A02 1 . Remove two
bolts (18) F50AB20-27 2 ,
washer (17) A15AW03-04 2 , bracket (16),
adapter (15) A15AA03-01 1 and
gasket (14) A15AG03-02 1 . Discard gasket (14).

Removal of Lower Solenoid Valve: Disconnect P37 connector (21) and P38 connector (22). Remove
bolts (5) A15EB20-12 2 and
(7) A15AB20-21 2 , nuts (6) and
(8) A15AN05-18 2 from the support brackets (12) and (13). Remove solenoid valve (9).

procedure.title: Installation of P3 Solenoid Valves (25297) (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.caution: MAKE SURE AIRFRAME ELECTRICAL POWER IS OFF WHEN HANDLING ELECTRICAL CONNECTORS.
MAKE SURE CONNECTOR PLUGS ARE FREE OF MOISTURE; IF NECESSARY, DRY WITH HEAT GUN.
DO NOT FORCE OR STRETCH HARNESS WHEN INSTALLING CONNECTORS OR ATTACHED LOOP CLAMPS.
USE ONLY APPROVED TOOLS TO TIGHTEN HARNESS CONNECTORS. CONNECTORS ARE CORRECTLY TIGHTENED WHEN ONLY BLUE COLOR BAND IS VISIBLE.
procedure.step:
Installation of Upper Solenoid Valve: Attach
solenoid valve (9) A15BV01A02 1 on support brackets (10 and 11) with two
bolts (1) A15EB20-04 2 and
(3) A15AB20-12 2 and two nuts (2) and
(4) A15AN05-14 2 . Tighten the nuts with fingers. Torque nuts (2) 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1 to 4.5 Nm). Torque nuts (4) 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1 to 3.4 Nm). Install
adapter (15) A15AA03-01 1 and
gasket (14) A15AG03-02 1 with two
bolts (18) F50AB20-27 2 ,
washer (17) A15AW03-04 2 and bracket (16). Torque the bolts 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1 to 3.4 Nm). Engage master keyway and install P13 connector (19) to the fan side and P14 connector (20) to the exhaust side on the compressor bleed valve solenoid (9). Tightly hold the connector coupling nut with soft-jawed pliers (PWC90012) and apply hand pressure to tighten the nut until the pliers slip. Measurement of the actual torque is not required.

Installation of Lower Solenoid Valve: Attach solenoid valve (9) on support brackets (12 and 13) with two
bolts (5) A15EB20-12 2 and
(7) A15AB20-21 2 and two nuts (6 and 8). Torque the nuts (6) 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1 to 4.5 Nm). Torque the nuts
(8) A15AN05-18 2 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1 to 3.4 Nm). Engage master keyway and install P37 connector (21) to the fan side and P38 connector (22) to the exhaust side on the compressor bleed valve solenoid (9). Tightly hold the connector coupling nut with soft-jawed pliers (PWC90012) and apply hand pressure to tighten the nut until the pliers slip. Measurement of the actual torque is not required.

procedure.title: Installation of P3 Tube to Lower Solenoid Valve (25095) (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install
tube (4) A15AT17A19 1 on
bracket (6) A15AB40A10 1 with clamp (3) and bolt (2). Torque bolt 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

Install
clamp (3) A15AC07-03 2 on tube (4) and attach to bracket (5) with
bolt (2) A15AB20-23 A15AB20-23 1,1 and
nut (1) A15AN05-20 1 . Torque nut 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).

procedure.title: Installation of P3 Tube to Lower Solenoid Valve (25095) (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install
tube (4) A15AT17A19 1 with
gasket (10) A15AG03-11 1 , two
washers (9) A15AW03-07 2 and two
bolts (8) A15AB20-17 2 . Torque bolt 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Install the tube coupling nut (5) and torque the nut 90 to 100 lb.in. (10-11 Nm).

DO NOT LUBRICATE THE THREADS.Install
clamp (7) A15AC07-03 3 and
bolt (6) A15AB20-26 1 . Torque nut 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm) dry.

DO NOT LUBRICATE THE THREADS.Install
clamps (3) A15AC07-03 3 with
nuts (1) A15AN05-33 A15AN05-20 1,1 and
bolts (2) A15AB20-23 1 on tube (4). Torque nut 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).

procedure.title: Installation of P2.5 Bleed Valve Tube (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install
tube (1) A15AT17A19 1 to P3
solenoid adapter (2) A15BV01-02 1 , attach
clamp (3) A15AC07-03 2 with
bolt (4) A15AB20-23 1 and

Install protective caps and plugs on disconnected tubes, component openings and electrical connectors after dis-assembly.

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: P3 Air Tubes And Transducer - Removal/Installation

procedure.step:
Disconnect the P39 harness connector from
P3 transducer (2) F50AS19-01 1 . Check connector for moisture. If present dry with suitable heat gun.

Disconnect the coupling nut of the
P3 air tube assembly (3) F50AT17A03 1 from P3 transducer (2).

Remove two
bolts (9) F50AB20-44 2 and P3 transducer (2).
Disconnect the coupling nut and remove P3 air pressure tube (3).

Remove
cap assembly (4) F50AC06-03 1 .

Remove two bolts
(6) F23AB20-08 1 and
(8) F23LB20-02 1 .

Disconnect the coupling nut and remove
P3 tube assembly (1) F50AT17A03 1 .

Remove two loop clamps
(5) F23AC07-06 1 and
(7) F23LC07-02 1 .

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install
P3 air pressure transducer (2) F50AS19-01 1 on bypass duct. Attach with two
bolts (9) F50AB20-44 2 . Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).

Install
P3 tube (1) F50AT17A03 1 on the outer bypass duct. Tighten coupling nut hand tight.

Install
P3 air tube assembly (3) F50AT17A03 1 between transducer (2) and tube assembly (1). Tighten coupling nuts hand tight.

Install loop clamps
(5) F23AC07-06 1 and
(7) F23LC07-02 1 on tube assembly (1). Attach with bolts
(6) F23AB20-08 1 and
(8) F23LB20-02 1 . Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).
Torque the coupling nuts of tube assemblies (1) and (3) 270 to 300 lb.in. (30.5-34.0 Nm) and lockwire with (PWC05-089).

Install
cap assembly (4) F50AC06-03 1 on P3 tube (1). Torque cap 270 to 300 lb.in. (30.5-34.0 Nm) and lockwire with (PWC05-089).

RED COLOR BAND ON CONNECTOR MUST NOT BE VISIBLE AFTER TORQUING.Install harness connector P39 on transducer (2). Tighten the connector using one of the following methods:
SOFT JAWED PLIERS HAVE A DESIGN SLIP TORQUE OF 100 lb.in (11.3 Nm). DO NOT USE STEEL JAWED PLIERS TO TIGHTEN CONNECTORSTighten the connector using soft jawed pliers (PWC90012) or Glenair TG69. Apply reasonable force to make sure connector coupling nut is firmly tightened and the red band is covered.
WRENCH ASSEMBLY CONNECTOR HAS A DESIGN SLIP TORQUE OF 100 lb.in. (11.3 Nm).Tighten the connector with a wrench assembly connector (PWC58104) or Glenair TG70. Apply reasonable force to make sure connector coupling nut is firmly tightened and the red band is covered.

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Select maintenance test discrete ON (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Remove the access cowling and apron (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Remove the right and left forward, upper, outer, bypass ducts (Ref. 72-70-01, BYPASS DUCTS, MAINTENANCE PRACTICES).
Remove the upper left and right, inner, bypass duct segments (Ref. 72-70-01, BYPASS DUCTS, MAINTENANCE PRACTICES).

Remove lockwire from nuts
(3) A15NN05-09 2 ,
(19) A15NN05-10 2 ,
(7) A15NN05-10 2 and
(14) A15NN05-09 2 and internally threaded rods
(22) A15NR11-01 2 and
(6) A15NR11-01 2 .
NUT (19) IS LEFT HAND THREAD.While holding rod (6), loosen nuts (3 and 19).
NUT (7) IS LEFT HAND THREAD.While holding rod (22), loosen nuts ( 7 and 14).

Move
actuator shaft (5) A15BA02-01 1 to the closed position.

Remove
cotter pin (9) A15NP04-13 2 ,
nut (8) A15NN05-20 2 and
bolt (12) A15NB20-15 2 .

DO NOT ATTEMPT TO REMOVE THE OTHER THREE BOLTS FROM MASTER LEVER (23). THESE BOLTS HAVE A TIGHT FIT AND SHOULD BE REMOVED IN A SHOP, IF REQUIRED.Remove
cotter pin (2) A15NP04-13 7 ,
nut (1) A15NN05-20 7 .

Remove
bolt (34) A15NB20-15 7 securing the actuator rod to the master lever.

EXTREME CARE MUST BE TAKEN NOT BEND OR CAUSE ANY UNDUE STRESS TO TUBE ASSEMBLY DURING REMOVAL OF ACTUATOR Remove two bolts (29) attaching
fuel tube assembly (28) A15FT17A01 1 to actuator manifold. Loosen or remove bolts along the length of tube assembly (28) as necessary to ease retraction.

Remove threaded rods (6 and 22). Remove
master lever (18) A15NL02A05 1 .
Disconnect the P24 and P25 connectors (25 and 26). Remove four clamps/brackets securing actuator harness. Make note of the orientation and locations of the clamps and brackets.
Remove actuator harness connector attaching nuts (35, 36). Remove connector (30) and (31).

Remove four
bolts (24) A15NB20-14 4 securing actuator to mounting bracket (11). Remove
actuator (23) A15BA02-01 1 .
Remove and discard preformed packings (32, 33).
Install protective covers on all tube and actuator openings.

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. and )
procedure.step: Select maintenance test discrete ON (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).

Install
nut (3) A15NN05-09 2 on
rod-end (4) A15NC17-03 2 .

NUT (7) IS LEFT HAND THREAD.Install
nut (7) A15NN05-10 2 on
rod-end (10) A15NC17-01 2 .

TITANIUM PARTS, WEAR CLEAN LINT FREE GLOVES AND HANDLE WITH CARE.Move
IGV (16) A15NR12A08 1 and
first-stage vane rings (15) A15NR12-11 1 to the closed position.

Lubricate and install two new preformed packings (32) and one new preformed packing (33) on
actuator (23) A15BA02-01 1 using engine oil (PWC03-001).

Position actuator (23) on bracket (11) engaging tube assembly (28). Attach actuator with four
bolts (24) A15NB20-14 4 . Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).

Attach
tube assembly (28) A15FT17A01 1 to actuator (23) with bolts (29). Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).

NUT (19) IS LEFT HAND THREAD.Install
nut (19) A15NN05-10 2 on rod-end (20).
Install nut (14) on rod-end (17).

Position
master lever assembly (18) A15NL02A05 1 in
gas generator case (21) B24NC05A01 1 .

Connect
yoke (13) A15NL02A04 1 to bracket (11) with
bolt (12) A15NB20-15 2 and
nut (8) A15NN05-20 2 . Torque nut 90 to 100 lb. in. (10.1-11.3 Nm). Install
cotter pin (9) A15NP04-13 2 .

Move
actuator rod (5) A15BA02-01 1 toward the open position until holes of rod (5) and master lever (18) are aligned, and install
bolt (34) A15NB20-15 7 and
nut (1) A15NN05-20 7 . Torque nut 90 to 100 lb. in. (10.1-11.3 Nm) and install
cotter pin (2) A15NP04-13 7 .

START TURNING BOTH THREADED RODS ON SIMULTANEOUSLY.Install
threaded rod (22) A15NR11-01 2 on rod ends (4) and
(20) A15NC17-01 2 and
threaded rod (6) A15NR11-01 2 on rod ends (10) and
(17) A15NC17-03 2 .

Adjust threaded rods (22 and 6) simultaneously until the results are as follows: The nominal length of the inlet guide vane actuator rod between the centers of rod ends (4 and 20) is 5.850 to 5.590 in. (14.860-15.113 cm). Tighten nuts fingertight only. The nominal length of the first stage vane actuator rod between the centers of rod ends (10 and 17) is 6.150 to 6.250 in. (15.621-15.875 cm). Tighten nuts fingertight only.
Replace or torque any clamps or bolts affected during removal of tube actuator.

MAKE SURE THE WIRING HARNESS DOES NOT MAKE CONTACT WITH ANY STATIC OR MOVING COMPONENTS. ADJUST HARNESS IN THE FOUR CLAMPS AND BRACKETS AS NECESSARY AND MAKE SURE THE HARNESS DOES NOT INTERFERE WITH THE IGV LINK BRACKET WHEN IN FULL CLOSE POSITION.Position actuator harness in the same location as noted at disassembly. Install actuator wiring harness (1) with four
clamps (2) A15FC07-03 F15EC07-01 3,1 and
bracket (3) F15EB40-01 1 (Ref. Fig. ).
Apply electrical contact enhancer to connectors (Ref. 70-00-00, CLEANING).
Attach connectors (30 and 31) to bracket (27) with nuts (35 and 36). Torque nut 45 to 50 lb. in. (5.08-5.65 Nm.) and install lockwire (PWC05-089).

MAKE SURE THAT AIRFRAME ELECTRICAL POWER IS OFF WHEN CONNECTING ELECTRICAL CONNECTORS. MAKE SURE THAT ALL CONNECTOR PLUGS ARE CLEAN AND DRY. DRY USING A HEAT GUN IF NECESSARY.Apply electrical contact enhancer to connectors (Ref. 70-00-00, CLEANING).
Engage master keyway and install P24 connector (26) and P25 connector (25) on stator vane actuator.

TIGHTEN HARNESS CONNECTORS WITH APPROVED TOOL ONLY.Tighten the connectors (25 and 26) using one of the following methods:
SOFT JAWED PLIERS HAVE A DESIGN SLIP TORQUE OF 100 lb.in (11.3 Nm). DO NOT USE STEEL JAWED PLIERS TO TIGHTEN CONNECTORSTighten the connector using soft jawed pliers (PWC90012) or Glenair TG69. Apply reasonable force to make sure connector coupling nut is firmly tightened and the red band is covered.
WRENCH ASSEMBLY CONNECTOR HAS A DESIGN SLIP TORQUE OF 100 lb.in. (11.3 Nm).Tighten the connector with a wrench assembly connector (PWC58104) or Glenair TG70. Apply reasonable force to make sure connector coupling nut is firmly tightened and the red band is covered.
Measure the clearance between actuator wiring harness and secondary air tube. The clearance should be 0.125 in. (3.18 mm) minimum. Actuator wiring harness clamps can be adjusted to get clearance.
Rig actuator (Ref Subpara. following).

procedure.title: Rigging Procedure (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Move actuator rings (15 and 16) toward the open position until rigging pins (PWC43312) can be inserted through VIGV ring (16) and first-stage compressor vane (15) into the slot in the left side HP compressor case.

MAKE SURE RIGGING PINS STAY IN PLACE DURING ADJUSTMENT. MAKE SURE THE CORRECT RIGGING TOOL IS USED.Adjust threaded rods (22 and 6) simultaneously until rigging tool (PWC60802) can be installed through rod (5) and housing (23).
MAKE SURE THE CORRECT RIGGING TOOL IS USED.Adjust threaded rods (6 and 22) until rigging pin (PWC43312) and tool (PWC60802) can be easily inserted and removed simultaneously.
Check that rods are in safety by trying to pass a 0.050 to 0.055 inch (1.2-1.4 mm) diameter wire through each witness hole of each threaded rod. Wire must not pass through.
Turn rod-ends until the bearing housings are parallel in the attaching brackets.
NUT (19) IS LEFT HAND THREAD. Hold threaded rod and tighten locknuts (3 and 19) 90 to 100 lb.in. (10-11.3 Nm).

Install safety cable on locknuts (3 and 19) and turnbuckle (22) with crimper (PWC90025) and test block (PWC90026) (Ref. Chapter 70-00-00, MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). If possible, set safety cable short ferrule at turnbuckle hole (22).

NUT (7) IS LEFT HAND THREAD.Hold threaded rod and tighten locknuts (7) and
(14) A15NN05-09 2 90 to 100 lb.in. (10-11.3 Nm).

Install safety cable on locknuts (7 and 14) and turnbuckle (6) with crimper (PWC90025) and test block (PWC90026) (Ref. Chapter 70-00-00, MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). If possible, set safety cable short ferrule at turnbuckle hole (6).
Make sure that safety cable ferrules does not touch actuator bracket by moving actuator ring drive system to fully close and fully open position.
Remove rigging tool (PWC60802) and pins (PWC43312).
Restore electrical power and reset EEC circuit breaker to ON.
Select maintenance test discrete to OFF.
Install the upper left and right, inner, bypass duct segments (Ref. 72-70-01, BYPASS DUCTS, MAINTENANCE PRACTICES).
Install the right and left forward, upper, outer, bypass ducts (Ref. 72-70-01, BYPASS DUCTS, MAINTENANCE PRACTICES).
Install the access cowling and apron (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Refer to Chapter 71-00-00, POWER PLANT - ADJUSTMENT/TEST for checks following installation of IGV actuator.

n-para.title: General (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The engine indicating system consists of two pressure/temperature (P1/T1) probes, the T4.5 wiring harness, the N1/N2 speed sensors and the vibration sensor on the intermediate case.

The engine diagnostic system is an integrated diagnostic unit (engine installed EDU) and on-board computer interface system that provides continous recording of engine performance parameters and other engine related data.

n-para.title: Speed Sensors (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The speed sensors consist of three magnetic inductance probes, which transmit N1 and N2 speeds in the form of analog electrical signals, via the outer wiring harness to the airframe and the EEC.

The N2 speed sensors consist of two probes, located on the right side of the accessory gearbox. Rotation of a spur gear on the alternator gearshaft in the AGB induces a pulsating voltage in each of the three coils in each N2 sensor. The frequency of this EMF is a function of HP rotor rotational speed and can thus be interpreted by the EEC and airframe avionics as RPM.

The N1 speed sensors are located behind the No. 4 bearing, in the exhaust case, and operate on the same principle as the N2 sensors. A phonic wheel mounted behind the No. 4 bearing on the LP shaft, induces a voltage in the N1 sensors.

n-para.title: T4.5 Thermocouple Wiring Harness (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The T4.5 system consists of two thermocouple half-harnesses, each having four mineral-insulated, alumel/chromel thermocouples, connected in parallel and joined at a sealed intermediate junction box. The eight thermocouples are mounted externally on the LP turbine case, behind Flange E and protrude into the gas path behind the second-stage HP turbine at station 4.5. A flexible lead from each intermediate junction box joins at the N1/T4.5 terminal box. The alumel and chromel terminal posts in the N1/T4.5 terminal box provide the connection point for the rear core wiring harness. To prevent inadvertent cross-connection, the lugs and terminal bolts are of different diameters, alumel being larger in diameter and slightly magnetic (negative polarity).

An externally mounted “classed” trim plug, located on the EEC, provides trim compensation to the T4.5 signal, to ensure a correct T4.5 to T4.0 relationship. The trim plug resistance value is determined during final engine acceptance checks and is recorded on the engine data plate. The trim plug may only be replaced in the field by an identically adjusted and sealed unit.

n-para.title: P1/T1 System (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para:
The P1/T1 system consists of two probes which protrude into the engine inlet air stream, immediately in front of the fan case. The sensors supply each channel; A and B of the EEC, with a dedicated T1 signal, while a single probe provides P1 input to the transducer block of the EEC. Both probes are identical in construction, but the P1 output on one probe is redundant and therefore blanked. Both probes are electrically anti-iced via the airframe DC bus when engine anti-icing is selected.
Engine Indicating System

n-para.title: Engine Diagnostic System (EDS) (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The engine diagnostic is interfaced into the aircraft Maintenance Diagnostic Computer (MDC) system and can be accessed through the maintenance mode on the Multi-Function Display (MFD) and selecting Propulsion System Diagnostics on the maintenance menu.

The EDS system consists of the engine mounted EEC, EDU and cockpit mounted avionics devices such as a Data Base Unit (DBU), a Display Control Panel (DCP) and a Multi-Function Display (MFD) on the pilot and co-pilot intrument panels. Associated equipment consists of the aircraft interface wiring harness (UART and a test connector) and a cockpit Pilot Manual Request switch (two push button switches). The system is powered by an engine driven PMA, or the aircraft 28 VDC power bus, for back up. The EEC's from each engine supply data from 2 channels to the EDU via RS422 UART.

The system records and displays engine operational data and EEC generated fault codes. The system serves as an on-board diagnostic computer and permits data transfer to a ground based computer via a 3.5 inch diskette. The data is monitored, analyzed and stored in the EDS memory under specific files (exceedance, trends, faults). In summary the system primary functions are:
Assist in engine fault isolation by recording exceedances, events, fault codes by displaying real time engine parameters and status words.
Assist in Engine Condition Trend Monitoring (ECTM) with snap shot recording.
Assist in flight and total time counting by recording engine/aircraft flight cycle and total time.

EDS interface components are as follows:
Data Base Unit (DBU): Used to download diagnostic data to a 3.5 inch floppy disk.
Display Control Panel (DCP): Provides keys for controlling the Multi Function Display.
Multi-Function Display (MFD): Used for displaying the EDS data when in maintenance mode.
Aircraft Maintenance Switch (in cockpit): The switch is located on the right side of the pedestal (co-pilot side). The switch when actuated to ON position will re-configure the MFD to display maintenance mode menus and activate the EDS system display.
Pilot Manual Request Buttons: The two buttons (one each for left hand and right hand engines) are also located on the right side of the pedestal (co-pilot side). The request buttons will allow the pilot or technician to record engine parameters into the EDS memory in case of abnormal engine operation (fluctuation, abnormal loss of power, sudden ITT split, etc.). This information can be later extracted by the technician for assistance in fault isolation.
