n-para.title: Removal/Installation
n-para.caution: MAKE SURE AIRFRAME ELECTRICAL POWER IS OFF WHEN REMOVING/INSTALLING CONNECTORS.

procedure.title: N1 Speed Sensor Removal

key.def: N1 Speed Sensor and Cable (Channel A)
N1 Speed Sensor and Cable (Channel B)

procedure.step:
Channel A and Channel B Removal (Ref. Fig. ): Select maintenance test discrete ON (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual). Remove lower inner rear bypass duct segment (Ref. Chapter 72-70-01, BYPASS DUCTS - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). This will ease the routing of the cable through the exhaust case. Disconnect N1 speed sensor and cable from N1/T4.5 terminal box (Ref. Chapter 77-20-01, T4.5 THERMOCOUPLES - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). 25185: Remove two bolts
(2) F36EB20-01 5 and
(10) F36EB20-01 5 , two nuts
(3) F36EN05-01 5 and
(6) F36EN05-01 5 and three loop clamps
(1) F33EC07-04 2 and
(4) F33EC07-04 2 . 25185 and 25228: Remove three bolts
(2) F36EB20-01 5 ,
(10) F36EB20-01 5 and
(21) F36EB20-01 5 , three nuts
(3) F36EN05-01 5 ,
(6) F36EN05-01 5 and
(22) F36EN05-01 5 and five loop clamps
(1) F33EC07-04 2 ,
(4) F33EC07-04 2 and
(20) F33EC07-04 2 . 25228: Remove
bolt (10) F36EB20-01 5 ,
nut (6) F36EN05-01 5 and two
loop clamps (4) F33EC07-04 2 . Remove four
bolts (9) F36EB20-01 5 , four
nuts (5) F36EN05-01 5 and four
loop clamps (11) F36EC07-01 4 . Remove the two
guide tubes (12) F36JG06-01 2 . 25228: Attach a piece of Teflon lacing cord about five feet in length to the sheath of the N1 speed sensor cables
(7) D36BS19-01 1 and
(8) D36BS19-02 1 . The Teflon lacing cord will be used to pull the replacement cable through exhaust case (15) and guide tubes (12). Remove 12
bolts (16) D36NB20-17 12 and
exhaust cone (17) D36NC15-01 1 (Ref. Chapter 72-50-03, EXHAUST CASE - REMOVAL/INSTALLATION). Channel B: Remove two
bolts (14) D36JB20-01 2 and disassemble the N1 speed sensor (8) from its mounting point in the
exhaust case (15) D36NC05A05 1 . Remove and discard
preformed packing (13) D36JP03-01 1 . Channel A: Remove two
bolts (18) D36JB20-01 2 and disassemble the N1 speed sensor (7) from its mounting point in the exhaust case (15). Remove and discard
preformed packing (19) D36JP03-01 1 . 25228: Carefully pull the N1 speed sensor cables (7 and 8), with the Teflon lacing cord attached, through the guide tubes (12) and exhaust case (15). Disconnect the Teflon lacing cord from the sheath. 25228: Carefully pull the N1 speed sensors and cables through
exhaust case (15) D36NC05A05 1 . Keep the N1 speed sensors and cables in a protective container.

procedure.title: N1 Speed Sensor Installation
procedure.caution: DO NOT PULL, TWIST OR SHARPLY BEND INDIVIDUAL WIRE CONNECTOR LEADS.
DO NOT ATTACH LOCKWIRE TO THE WIRE CONNECTOR LEADS OR APPLY TAPE AROUND BUNDLED CONNECTOR LEADS, TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO THE LEADS.
procedure.step:
Channel A and Channel B Installation (Ref. Fig. ): 25228:
DO NOT ATTACH THE TEFLON LACING CORD TO WIRE CONNECTORS AS DAMAGE TO CABLE WILL RESULT. ATTACH THE TEFLON LACING CORD TO THE SHEATH OF SPEED SENSOR, WHEN ATTACH, USE ELECTRICAL TAPE AND WIND THE LACING CORD WITH ALL SIX ELECTRICAL CONNECTORS TOGETHER TO AVOID DAMAGE TO THE WIRE DURING INSTALLATION. MAKE SURE THAT THE TEFLON LACING CORD IS PULLING ON THE SHEATH OF THE SPEED SENSOR AND NOT ON THE WIRES.Attach Teflon lacing cord, used during the removal procedure, to the sheath of the N1 speed sensors and cables
(7) D36BS19-01 1 and
(8) D36BS19-02 1 .
DO NOT PULL INDIVIDUAL WIRE CONNECTOR LEADS.Wind the N1 speed sensor cable wire connector leads with electrical tape (PWC05-191) to prevent damage to the
exhaust case (15) D36NC05A05 1 and
guide tubes (12) F36JG06-01 2 .
DO NOT PULL THE N1 SPEED SENSOR CABLE BY THE CONNECTION CODED WIRE WITH EXCESSIVE FORCE, AS THIS MAY CAUSE BUNCHING OF THE CABLE SHEATH, RESULTING IN INTERNAL DAMAGE TO THE CABLE.Slowly and carefully pull the Teflon lacing cord, attached to the N1 speed sensor cables, through the exhaust case (15) and guide tube (12). If the sheath of the cable starts to bunch, carefully remove the probe and start again. 25228: Hold individual wires connector leads together and carefully put the N1 speed sensor cables through the
exhaust case (15) D36NC05A05 1 . Lockwire is NOT to be used for the removal/installation of the Post-SB25228 N1 speed sensor and cable. Channel B: Install
preformed packing (13) D36JP03-01 1 on
N1 speed sensor (8) D36BS19-02 1 and install the sensor in the exhaust case (15). Channel A: Install
preformed packing (19) D36JP03-01 1 on
N1 speed sensor (7) D36BS19-01 1 and install the sensor in the exhaust case (15).
BEFORE APPLYING THE TORQUE TO THE BOLTS, MAKE SURE THE N1 SPEED SENSOR CABLE ROUTING THROUGH THE EXHAUST CASE AND GUIDE TUBE IS CORRECT.Apply anti-seize compound (PWC06-009) to the threads of four bolts
(14) D36JB20-01 2 and
(18) D36JB20-01 2 and secure two N1 speed sensors (7 and 8) to the exhaust case installation points. Torque the bolts 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm.). Install the two
guide tubes (12) F36JG06-01 2 with four
loop clamps (11) F36EC07-01 4 , four
bolts (9) F36EB20-01 5 and four
nuts (5) F36EN05-01 5 . Torque the bolt 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1-3.4Nm.). 25185: Install
bolt (2) F36EB20-01 5 ,
loop clamp (1) F33EC07-04 2 and
self-locking nut (3) F36EN05-01 5 . Torque the bolt 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1-3.4 Nm.). Assemble two
loop clamps (4) F33EC07-04 2 and secure with
bolt (10) F36EB20-01 5 and
nut (6) F36EN05-01 5 . Torque the bolt 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1-3.4 Nm.). 25185 and 25228: Install
bolt (2) F36EB20-01 5 ,
loop clamp (1) F33EC07-04 2 and
self-locking nut (3) F36EN05-01 5 . Torque the bolt 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1-3.4 Nm.). Assemble
loop clamps (4) F33EC07-04 2 and tighten with
bolt (10) F36EB20-01 5 and
nut (6) F36EN05-01 5 . Torque the bolt 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1-3.4 Nm.). Assemble two
loop clamps (20) F33EC07-04 2 and secure with
bolt (21) F36EB20-01 5 and
nut (22) F36EN05-01 5 . Torque the bolt 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1-3.4 Nm.). 25228: Assemble loop clamps (4) and secure with bolt (10) and nut (6). Torque the bolt 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1-3.4 Nm.). Make sure the N1 speed sensor cables routing through the conduit in the exhaust case (15) and the guide tubes (12) is correct. Install
exhaust cone (17) D36NC15-01 1 and secure with twelve
bolts (16) D36NB20-17 12 (Ref. Chapter 72-50-03, EXHAUST CASE - REMOVAL/INSTALLATION). Install N1 speed sensor cable in N1/T4.5 terminal box (Ref. Chapter 77-20-01, T4.5 THERMOCOUPLES - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES). Put electrical power back to applicable system. Set maintenance test discrete to OFF.

procedure.title: Removal of Channel A, N2 Speed Sensor (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Select maintenance test discrete ON (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Drain oil from accessory gearbox (2) (Ref. 72-00-00, SERVICING).
Disconnect outer wiring harness connector P9 (7).

Remove two
bolts (6) F41EB20-03 4 and
washers (5) F41EW03-02 3 .

Remove
speed sensor (4) F41BS19-01 2 and discard
preformed packing (3) F41EP03-02 2 .

procedure.title: Installation of Channel A, N2 Speed Sensor (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install new
preformed packing (3) F41EP03-02 2 on speed sensor (4).

Insert
speed sensor (4) F41BS19-01 2 into boss in accessory gearbox (2) with two
bolts (6) F41EB20-03 4 and
washers (5) F41EW03-02 3 . Tighten bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).
Apply electrical contact enhancer to connectors (Ref. Chapter 70-00-00, CLEANING).

TIGHTEN CONNECTORS USE WITH APPROVED TOOL ONLY. CONNECTORS ARE PROPERLY TIGHTENED WHEN ONLY THE BLUE COLOR BAND IS VISIBLE.Connect outer wiring harness connector P9 (7) to N2 speed sensor (4). Tighten the connector using one of the following methods:
SOFT JAWED PLIERS HAVE A DESIGN SLIP TORQUE OF 100 lb.in (11.3 Nm). DO NOT USE STEEL JAWED PLIERS TO TIGHTEN CONNECTORS.Tighten the connector using soft jawed pliers (PWC90012) or Glenair TG69. Apply reasonable force to make sure connector coupling nut is firmly tightened and the red band is covered.
WRENCH ASSEMBLY CONNECTOR HAS A DESIGN SLIP TORQUE OF 100 lb.in. (11.3 Nm).Tighten the connector with a wrench assembly connector (PWC58104) or Glenair TG70. Apply reasonable force to make sure connector coupling nut is firmly tightened and the red band is covered.
Install accessory gearbox drain plug (Ref. Chapter 72-00-00, SERVICING), and service as required.
Restore electrical power to appropriate system and reset EEC circuit breaker ON.
Select maintenance test discrete OFF.
Pull EEC circuit breaker to OFF.

procedure.title: Removal of Channel B, N2 Speed Sensor (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Select maintenance test discrete ON (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Drain oil from accessory gearbox (2) (Ref. 72-00-00, SERVICING).
Disconnect outer wiring harness connector P10 (8).

Remove two
bolts (9) F41EB20-03 4
washer (10) F41EW03-02 3
loop clamp (13) F41EC07-35 1 .

Remove
speed sensor (11) F41BS19-01 2 and discard
preformed packing (12) F41EP03-02 2 .

procedure.title: Installation Channel B, N2 Speed Sensor (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install new
preformed packing (12) F41EP03-02 2 on
speed sensor (11) F41BS19-01 2 .

Insert speed sensor (11) into boss in accessory gearbox (2) and secure with two
bolts (9) F41EB20-03 4
washer (10) F41EW03-02 3 and
loop clamp (13) F41EC07-35 1 . Tighten and torque bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).
Apply electrical contact enhancer to connectors (Ref. 70-00-00, CLEANING).

USE ONLY APPROVED TOOLS TO TIGHTEN WIRING HARNESS CONNECTORS. CONNECTORS ARE PROPERLY TIGHTENED WHEN ONLY THE BLUE COLOR BAND IS VISIBLE; RED COLOR BAND MUST NOT BE VISIBLE.Connect external wiring harness connector P10 (8) to N2 speed sensor (11). Tighten the connector using one of the following methods:
SOFT JAWED PLIERS HAVE A DESIGN SLIP TORQUE OF 100 lb.in (11.3 Nm). DO NOT USE STEEL JAWED PLIERS TO TIGHTEN CONNECTORSTighten the connector using soft jawed pliers (PWC90012) or Glenair TG69. Apply reasonable force to make sure connector coupling nut is firmly tightened and the red band is covered.
WRENCH ASSEMBLY CONNECTOR HAS A DESIGN SLIP TORQUE OF 100 lb.in. (11.3 Nm).Tighten the connector with a wrench assembly connector (PWC58104) or Glenair TG70. Apply reasonable force to make sure connector coupling nut is firmly tightened and the red band is covered.
Install accessory gearbox drain plug(Ref. 72-00-00, SERVICING), and service as required.
Restore electrical power to appropriate system and reset EEC circuit breaker ON.
Select maintenance test discrete OFF.
Pull EEC circuit breaker to OFF.

general.para: Lubricate preformed packings, threads and mating surfaces with engine oil unless otherwise stated.
Install protective caps and plugs on disconnected tubes, component openings and electrical connectors after disassembly.

n-para.title: N1/T45 Terminal Box
n-para.caution: ENSURE AIRFRAME ELECTRICAL POWER IS OFF WHEN HANDLING RECEPTACLES AND PLUGS.
ENSURE PLUGS AND RECEPTACLES ARE FREE OF MOISTURE; IF NECESSARY, DRY USING HEAT GUN.
DO NOT FORCE OR STRETCH HARNESS WHEN INSTALLING CONNECTORS OR SECURING SELF-LOCKING LOOP CLAMPS.
USE ONLY APPROVED TOOLS TO TIGHTEN WIRING HARNESS CONNECTORS. CONNECTORS ARE PROPERLY TIGHTENED WHEN ONLY BLUE COLOR BAND IS VISIBLE; RED COLOR BAND MUST NOT BE VISIBLE.

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )

key.def: T4.5 in Alumel and Chromel Connectors (Ref.)
T4.5 in Alumel and Chromel Connectors (Ref.)
T4.5 out (part of rear core wiring harness)
N1 out (CH. A, part of rear core wiring harness)
N1 out (CH. B, part of rear core wiring harness)
T4.5 out Alumel and Chromel Connectors (Ref.)

procedure.step: Remove four self-locking nuts (12) and terminal box cover (13).
Remove self-locking nuts alumel (21), chromel (20) and remove T4.5 wire connectors (7, 14 and 25) from terminal block (23).

Remove lockwire and unscrew "T4.5 OUT" harness connector (15) from
terminal box (19) F33BB16-01 1 .
Remove lockwire and unscrew "T4.5 IN" harness connectors (1) and (16) from terminal box (19).
Remove 12 self-locking nuts (22) from bus-bars (24) and remove wire connections.
Remove lockwire and unscrew "N1 OUT" harness connectors (17 and 18) from terminal box (19).
Remove self-locking nut (8), bolt (11) and bracket (9) from terminal box (19).
Withdraw "N1 IN" cables (2 and 3) from terminal box (19).

Remove three
self-locking nuts (6) F33EN05-01 3 , three
bolts (10) F33EB20-01 3 and remove terminal box from support (5).
Remove three bolts (4) and terminal box support (5) from Flange E.

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Secure terminal box support (5) on Flange E with three bolts (4). Torque 85 to 95 lb.in. (9.5-11.0 Nm).

Install
terminal box (19) F33BB16-01 1 on terminal support (5) with three
self-locking nuts (6) F33EN05-01 3 and
bolts (10) F33EB20-01 3 . Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).
Insert "N1 OUT CH. B" harness (18) into terminal box (19). Torque harness coupling nut 45 to 55 lb.in. (5.0-5.5 Nm).
Insert "N1 OUT CH. A" harness (17) into terminal box (19). Torque harness coupling nut 45 to 55 lb.in. (5.0-5.5 Nm).
Lockwire (PWC05-089) coupling nuts on harness (17 and 18).
Install N1 wire connections on bus bar (24). Refer to View A for color coding.

MAKE SURE THAT N1 SPEED PROBES FERRULE ARE INSERTED INTO THE TERMINAL BOX TO PREVENT THE WIRE FROM CHAFING ON THE SIDE OF THE TERMINAL BOX. MAKE SURE THE TERMINAL BOX BRACKET (1) HOLDS THE N1 SPEED PROBE BY THE AREA A (REF. FIG. ).Insert N1 cables (2 and 3) into terminal box (19) and secure with bracket (9) and self-locking nut (8). Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Install wire connections on bus-bar (24). Refer to View A for color coding. Torque post nuts (22) 3.5 to 4 lb.in. (0.3 - 0.4 Nm).
Install "T4.5 IN" cables (1, 16) to terminal box (19). Torque coupling nuts 15 to 25 lb.in. (1.6-2.8 Nm) and lockwire (PWC05-089).
Install "T4.5 OUT" cable (15) in terminal box (19). Torque 15 to 25 lb.in. (1.6-2.8 Nm).
Install T4.5 wire connections (7, 14 and 25) on terminal block (23) with self-locking nuts; chromel (20) and alumel (21). Refer to View A for correct installation.
Install large alumel nut (21) and torque 24 to 40 lb. in. (2.8-4.6 Nm).
Install small chromel nut (20) and torque 15 to 20 lb.in. (1.6-2.8 Nm).
Lockwire (PWC05-089) coupling nuts (15 and 16).
Secure terminal box cover (13) with four self-locking nuts (12). Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).

n-para.title: N1 Speed Probes Terminal Strip Replacement

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: N1 Speed Probes Terminal Strip - Removal/Installation

procedure.step:
Remove four self-locking nuts (1) and
terminal box cover (2) pw306a-772001-001-0180 1 .

Remove the nuts (6) and disconnect N1 speed probes wire connection from the
terminal strip (5) pw306a-772001-001-0190 2 .
Remove nuts (3) and spacers (4).
Remove and discard the terminal strip (5).

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install new
terminal strip(s) (5) pw306a-772001-001-0190 2
Install spacers (4).
Install self-locking nuts (3).
Torque nuts (3) to 32 to 36 lb.in. (3.6-4.0 Nm).
Install N1 speed probes wire connection to the terminal strip (5), refer to figure for color coding.
Install the nuts (6). Torque nuts 3.5 to 4 lb.in. (0.3-0.4 Nm).

Attach
terminal box cover (2) pw306a-772001-001-0180 1 with four self-locking nuts (1). Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Select maintenance test discrete ON before wiring harness removal (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Disconnect the electrical power to appropriate system and pull EEC circuit breaker to the OFF position.
Disconnect T4.5 wiring harness from N1/T4.5 terminal box (Ref. Para. ).

Remove four
nuts (4) F33EN05-02 2 ,
bolts (3) F33EB20-02 2 and
loop clamp (5) F33EC07-01 2 .
Remove bolts (6) on bracket (10) and retain bracket (13).
Remove two bolts (6) and bracket (14).

Remove 16
bolts (8) C35EB20-01 16 securing T4.5 probes in LP turbine case.

Carefully remove two
wiring harnesses (1) F50BW17-05 2 from engine. Discard eight
ring-seals (12) F50ES06-01 8 and
gasket (11) C35EG03-01 8 .

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Apply a light coat of anti-seize compound (PWC06-009) to eight new
ring-seals (12) F50ES06-01 8 and install on T4.5 probes (9).

ENSURE RING-SEALS (12) AND GASKET (11) ARE NOT DAMAGED DURING INSTALLATION.Install eight new
gasket (11) C35EG03-01 8 on T4.5 probes and carefully insert probes into their respective bosses on LP turbine case.

Apply a light coat of anti-seize compound (PWC06-009) to 16
bolts (8) C35EB20-01 16 and secure T4.5 probes to LP turbine case. Torque 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).
Secure bracket (10), part of lower wiring harness together with bracket (15) at the 8 o'clock position using two bolts (6). Torque bolts 85 to 95 lb.in. (9.5-11 Nm).
Secure other bracket (10), part of upper wiring harness with bracket (13) at the 2 o'clock position, and using bolts (6). Torque bolts 85 to 95 lb.in. (9.5-11 Nm).
Install two bolts (6) and bracket (14). Torque bolts 85 to 95 lb.in. (9.5-11 Nm)

Install four
loop clamp (5) F33EC07-01 2
bolts (3) F33EB20-02 2 and
self-locking nuts (4) F33EN05-02 2 . Torque 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm).

Connect
T4.5 wiring harnesses (1) F50BW17-05 2 to N1/T4.5 terminal box (2) (Ref. Para. ).
Restore electrical power to appropriate system and reset EEC circuit breaker ON.
Select maintenance test discrete OFF after wiring harness installation and before engine operations (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Refer to Chapter 71-00-00 for checks following installation of T4.5 thermocouple wiring harness.

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Remove chromel and alumel nuts (20 and 21).
Remove T4.5 IN and OUT wires from terminal block (23).
Remove bolts, nuts, and terminal block (23) from terminal box (19).

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Install terminal block (23) inside terminal box (19) with bolts, bolt heads outside box, and nuts.
Torque nuts 32 to 36 lb. in.
Fit T4.5 IN and OUT wires on terminal block (23). Refer to View A for correct location.
Install large alumel nut (21) and torque 24 to 40 lb. in. (2.8-4.6 Nm).
Install small chromel nut (20) and torque 15 to 20 lb.in. (1.6-2.8 Nm).
Check function of T4.5 system (Ref. Para. ).

procedure.title: Procedure
procedure.step: Information transferred to ADJUSTMENT/TEST.

Inspect wiring as follows: Check insulation and wires for cracks or chafing. Reject if cracks are found or if wires are exposed or damaged. Check terminal lugs for looseness or cracks. Reject if found. If harness is rejected, return to P&WC for evaluation and possible repair.

Inspect metal tubing as follows: Check for nicks, dents, scores or scratches. Reject if core is exposed. Check for cracks. Reject if found. Check for deformation. Reject if kinked or if sharp bend radii exist.
Check connector threads for damage. Chase threads using a 0.500-20UNJF 3A die.

Inspect thermocouple probes as follows (Ref. Fig. ): Nicks, dents, pitting, scratching, fretting and oxidation on probe body and flanges is acceptable. Check piston ring. Replace if broken or the piston ring is not free to move around the groove. Check probe for cracks. Replace harness if any cracks are found. Check probe tip for bulging, heavy oxidation with material loss exposing the core, impact damage causing sharp indentations or sharp bending. Replace harness if any of these conditions are found. Tip leaning up to 10 degrees from the center axis is acceptable providing there are no sharp bends. Tip pitting and erosion is acceptable providing the core is not exposed.

n-para.title: Adjustment/Test
n-para.note: Thermocouples are connected in parallel and damaged thermocouples have a very small effect on the total system resistance value. To troubleshoot the ITT system each component, external wiring harness, rear core harness and two, upper and lower ITT/T4.5 thermocouple harnesses must be tested individually per checks 2, 3 and 4 (Ref. Paras. , and ).

procedure.title: Check 1 - ITT/T4.5 System Functional Check (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: Irrespective of the results of ITT/T4.5 System functional Check, test upper and lower T4.5 thermocouple harnesses per check 4 (Ref. Para. )
Make sure the full ITT/T4.5 system is disconnected from the EEC. If check 1 values are not within the limits specified, do check 2, 3 and 4 (Ref. Paras. , and ) to isolate faulty component.
procedure.step: Do the continuity resistance check as follows: Examine multi-tester or ohmmeter calibration before you do the resistance check. Make sure that the engine is cooled down to ambient temperature. T4.5 temperature must be below 50°C (122°F) before checking component resistance. Disconnect the connector P1 from the EEC and connect the test leads to pin E and pin F. Record the resistance value. Turn the test leads to opposite pins to reverse polarity (lead previously on E is now on F and other lead previously on F is now on E). Record the resistance value. The two readings must be done in quick steps. The voltage produced by the thermocouples may affect the ohmmeter reading if the instrument is not designed to make allowance for it. If T4.5 thermocouple body temperature is below 50°C (122°F) and the readings in steps and are different, this tester is not the right instrument for this check. The resistance limits between pin E and pin F is: 4.68 to 11.11 ohms.
Do the insulation resistance check as follows: The resistance to shield on pins E and F is 0.2 megohms minimum at 45 volts DC or AC.

procedure.title: Check 2 - External Wiring Harness Assembly (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Do the continuity resistance check of the external wiring harness as follows: Examine multi-tester or ohmmeter calibration before you do the resistance check. Make sure that the engine is cooled down to ambient temperature. T4.5 harness temperature must be below 50°C (122°F). Disconnect the external wiring harness connector P1 from the EEC. Examine the connector for moisture. If necessary, dry the connector with a suitable heatgun. Disconnect the P27 connector from the J27 connector. Examine the connector for moisture. If necessary, dry the connector with a suitable heatgun. Connect the tester leads to pin F of the P1 connector and pin B of the P27 connector (Alumel/Alumel connection). Record the resistance value. The limit is 0.5 to 2.00 ohms. Examine the continuity resistance between pin E of the P1 connector and pin A of the P27 connector (Chromel/Chromel connection). Record the resistance value. The limit is 2.00 to 4.50 ohms. Replace wiring harness if the resistance value is not within the limits.

Do the insulation resistance check as follows: Examine the insulation resistance to shield on pins (A and B). Limit is 2 megohms minimum at 45 volts DC or AC. Replace the wiring harness if the resistance value is not within the limits.

procedure.title: Check 3 - ITT/T4.5 Rear Core Harness Assembly (Ref. Figs. and )
procedure.step: Do the continuity resistance check of the rear core harness assembly as follows: Make sure that the engine is cooled down to ambient temperature. T4.5 temperature must be below 50°C (122°F). Disconnect the T4.5 wire terminals (7, 14 and 25) from the terminal block (23). (Ref. Para. ). Disconnect the P27 connector from the J27 connector (Ref. Fig. ). Examine the connector for moisture. If necessary, dry connector with a suitable heatgun. Connect the tester leads to alumel terminal of the T4.5 out connector (25) (Fig ) and pin B of the J27 connector (Alumel/Alumel connection). Record the resistance value. Limit is 0.40 to 1.20 ohms. Connect the tester leads to chromel terminal of the T4.5 out connector (25) (Fig ) and pin A of the J27 connector (Chromel/Chromel connection). Record the resistance value. The limit is 0.80 to 2.20 ohms.

Do the insulation resistance check of the rear core harness assembly as follows: Examine the insulation resistance to shield on each pins (A and B). Limit is 2 megohms minimum at 45 volts DC or AC. Connect T4.5 wire terminals (7, 14 and 25) again to terminal block (23) (Ref. Para. ). Replace the wiring harness if the resistance value is not within the limits.

procedure.title: Check 4 - ITT/T4.5 Upper and Lower Thermocouple Harnesses (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Do the continuity resistance check of upper and lower T4.5 thermocouple harnesses as follows: Examine multi-tester or ohmmeter calibration before you do the resistance check. Make sure that the engine is cooled down to ambient temperature. T4.5 temperature must be below 50°C (122°F) before checking component resistance. Gain access to the T4.5 terminal box. Disconnect the T4.5 wire terminals (7, 14 and 25) from the terminal block (23) (Ref. Para. ). Examine the upper T4.5 thermocouple harness continuity resistance. Connect the test leads to alumel and chromel terminals (7) of upper T4.5 in thermocouple harness (1). Record the continuity resistance value (Ref. Fig. ). Turn the test leads to opposite pins to reverse polarity (lead previously on alumel is now on terminal chromel and the other lead previously on terminal chromel is now on alumel. Record continuity resistance value. The two readings must be done in quick steps. The voltage produced by the thermocouples may affect the ohmmeter reading if the instrument is not designed to make allowance for it. If T4.5 thermocouple body temperature is below 50°C (122°F) and the readings in steps and are different, this tester is not the right instrument for this check. Do step thru step again to test lower T4.5 thermocouple harness (16) continuity resistance between alumel and chromel terminals (14). The continuity resistance limit between the upper T4.5 harness terminals or between the lower T4.5 harness terminals is 2.18 +/- 0.2 ohms. However, a continuity resistance of 2.6 +0.4/-0.6 ohms of either upper or lower harness is acceptable for continuing in service provided the remaining T4.5 harness continuity resistance is within the specified limits of 2.18 +/- 0.2 ohms. Continuity resistance of an average of 2.6 ohms indicates one thermocouple in the respective T4.5 harness (either upper or lower) is unserviceable. An engine having one thermocouple unserviceable can remain in service. Remove T4.5 thermocouple harness with resistance outside the limits and test per check 5 - (Ref. Para. ).

Examine the insulation resistance of the upper and lower T4.5 thermocouple harness and terminal block: Examine that the insulation resistance between each terminals (7 and 14) of T4.5 wire harness (1 and 16) and engine casing is 0.2 megohms minimum at 45 volts DC or AC. Examine insulation resistance between each box terminal studs (Alumel and Chromel) and the engine casing. The limit is 0.2 megohms minimum at 45 volts DC or AC. Replace the harness or the terminal block with insulation resistance lower than 0.2 megohms. Install the terminals (7, 14 and 25) again on the terminal box studs (Ref. Para. ).

procedure.title: Check 5 - Individual Thermocouple Heat Response (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: This check cannot be done with the engine installed on the aircraft. It is intended to confirm the results of check 4 (Ref. Para. ). The test should be done with the T4.5 thermocouple harnesses removed from the engine or the LP module assembly removed from the engine.
Examine multi-tester or ohmmeter calibration before you do the resistance check.
procedure.step: Disconnect the terminals (7, 14 and 25) (Ref. Para. ).
Remove the upper and/or lower T4.5 thermocouple harness from the engine (Ref. Para. ).
Connect the tester leads to upper T4.5 thermocouple harness terminals (7) (Ref. Fig. ).

DO NOT HEAT THE THERMOCOUPLE MORE THAN 538°C (1000°F).Heat each thermocouple tip one after the other and make sure that there is a voltage reading indication is in the same direction for each thermocouple.
Do step thru step again to test the lower T4.5 thermocouple harness terminals (14) (Ref. Fig. ).

If the insulation resistance check fails and the engine was not operating just before this check, bake the thermocouple assembly at 93°C (200°F) to dry out possible moisture and do the check 4 again (Ref. Para. ).
Replace the thermocouple assembly if any of the four thermocouples does not react properly to heat, or insulation resistance check is not within the specified limits.
Install the T4.5 thermocouple harnesses again on the engine (Ref. Para. ).
Connect the thermocouple terminals again (Ref. Para. ).

general.para: Lubricate preformed packings, threads and mating surfaces with engine oil unless otherwise stated.
Install protective caps and plugs on disconnected tubes, component openings and electrical connectors after disassembly.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

fixtures-and-equipment.para: The fixtures, equipment and supplier tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Select maintenance test discrete ON (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).

Remove electrical connectors P22 (10) and P23 (4) from sensors
(9) F13BS19-01 1 and (8).
Remove lockwire and disconnect coupling nut (5) on P1 tube (6) from sensor (8).
Remove two bolts (12), washers (11), nuts (7) and P1/T1 sensors (8, 9) from shipping brackets (13), or remove P1/T1 sensors from engine inlet cowl (Ref. AMM) as applicable.

If sensor (9) is being replaced, remove
cap (3) F13AC06-01 1 .
If applicable, remove four bolts (14), nuts (1), washers (2) and shipping brackets (13).
Place protective covers on electrical connectors and tube ends.

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: If applicable, install two shipping brackets (13) with two bolts (14), washers (2) and nuts (1). Torque nuts 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.3 Nm).

Install
cap (3) F13AC06-01 1 on
sensor (9) F13BS19-01 1 . Torque cap 70 to 80 lb.in. (7.9-9.0 Nm) and secure with lockwire (PWC05-089).
Install P1/T1 sensors (8, 9) with two washers (11), bolts (12) and nuts (7), on shipping brackets (13) or engine inlet cowl (Ref. AMM) as applicable.
Torque nuts (7) 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0-4.6 Nm) at each location.
Apply anti-seize compound (PWC06-009) to coupling nut (5).
Torque coupling nut (5) 50 to 60 lb.in. (5.6- 6.7 Nm) and secure with lockwire (PWC05-089).
Apply electrical contact enhancer to connectors (Ref. 70-00-00, CLEANING).

TIGHTEN CONNECTORS WITH APPROVED TOOL(S) ONLY.Attach connectors (10, 4) to P1/T1 sensors (9, 8). Tighten each connector by hand until witness band on the mating receptacle is covered. Tighten the connector using one of the following methods:
SOFT JAWED PLIERS HAVE A DESIGN SLIP TORQUE OF 100 lb.in (11.3 Nm). DO NOT USE STEEL JAWED PLIERS TO TIGHTEN CONNECTORS Tighten the connector using soft jawed pliers (PWC90012) or Glenair TG69. Apply reasonable force to make sure connector coupling nut is firmly tightened and the red band is covered.
WRENCH ASSEMBLY CONNECTOR HAS A DESIGN SLIP TORQUE OF 100 lb.in. (11.3 Nm).Tighten the connector with a wrench assembly connector (PWC58104). Apply reasonable force to make sure connector coupling nut is firmly tightened and the red band is covered.
Select maintenance test discrete OFF (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).

procedure.title: Removal (Ref Fig. )
procedure.step:
Remove lockwire and disconnect coupling nut (16) from
sensor (19) F13BS19-01 1 .

Remove lockwire and disconnect coupling nut (10) from
tube (11) F13AT17A12 1 .
If applicable, remove bolt (3), loop clamp (4) and nut (5) from shipping bracket (2).
If applicable, remove bolt (12), loop clamp (13) and nut (7) from shipping bracket (9) and remove air tube (6).
If applicable, remove shipping brackets as follows: Remove two bolts (1), nuts (18), washers (17) and shipping bracket (2). Remove two bolts (8), nuts (15), washers (14) and shipping bracket (9).

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: If applicable, install shipping brackets as follows: Install shipping bracket (2) using two bolts (1), nuts (18) and washers (17). Torque nuts (18) 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.3 Nm). Install shipping bracket (9) using two bolts (8), nuts (15) and washers (14). Torque nuts (15) 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.3 Nm).
Apply anti-seize compound (PWC06-009) to coupling nuts (10, 16).

Install air
tube (6) F13AT17A11 1 to
sensor (19) F13BS19-01 1 and
tube (11) F13AT17A12 1 . Tighten coupling nuts (10, 16) fingertight.
Install loop clamp (4) on tube (6) and secure to shipping bracket (2) if applicable, with bolt (3) and nut (5), or inlet cowl (Ref. AMM) as applicable. Torque nuts (5) 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.3 Nm).
Install loop clamp (13) on tube (6) and secure to shipping bracket (9) if applicable, with bolt (12) and nut (7), or inlet cowl (Ref. AMM) as applicable. Torque nuts (5) 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.3 Nm).
Torque tube coupling nuts (10, 16) 50 to 60 lb.in. (5.6-6.7 Nm) and secure with lockwire (PWC05-089).

n-para.title: P1 Air Pressure Tube to EEC

procedure.step:
Remove lockwire and disconnect coupling nut (2) from
tube (11) F13AT17A12 1 .
Remove lockwire and disconnect coupling nut (7) from EEC fitting (15).

Remove bolts
(9) F13AB20-01 1 ,
(10) F13AB20-04 1
nut (14) F13AN05-02 1 ,

bolt (6) F13AB20-05 1 and
bracket (5) F13AB40-08 1 from EEC.

cap (12) F13EC06-01 1 on

Install
bolt (10) F13AB20-04 1 and
bracket (8) F13AB40-07 1 . Torque bolt 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

Install

nut (14) F13AN05-02 1 . Torque bolt 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

figure.title: P1 Air Pressure Tube to EEC - Removal/Installation

general.para: Use engine oil to lubricate preformed packings, threads and mating surfaces, unless otherwise stated. THE EDU CAN BE DAMAGED BY ELECTROSTATIC DISCHARGE. INSTALL PROTECTIVE CAPS OVER THE OUTSIDE OF ELECTRICAL CONNECTORS. DO NOT INSTALL PROTECTIVE CAPS ON THE INSIDE OF ELECTRICAL CONNECTOR SLEEVES. IMPROPER INSTALLATION OF CAP CAN DAMAGE THE INSIDE OF THE CONNECTOR (Ref. 70-00-00, REMOVAL/INSTALLATION).
Install protective caps and plugs on disconnected tubes, component openings and electrical connectors after sub-assembly.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

entry.note: Ref. INTRODUCTION for more details.
The cable equipment that is included in the DPHM kit may be purchased separately through all tooling suppliers.

fixtures-and-equipment.para: The fixtures, equipment and supplier tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

procedure.title: EDS Access Procedures (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: Cockpit mounted maintenance switches must be ON to access the Maintenance Mode on the Multi-Function Display (MFD), then the pilot's Display Control Panel (DCP) can select and control Maintenance Mode on the left MFD or the copilot's DCP can control the MFD on the right hand side . If Maintenance Mode is selected on both pilot's and co=pilot's DCPs, only the pilot's DCP is in control and both MFD screens will display the same information (Ref. AMM).
If a Data Transmission Unit (DTU) is installed, it is necessary to pull the DTU's circuit breaker to access the Engine Diagnostic System (EDS) or download the Engine Diagnostic Unit (EDU).
procedure.step: Power ON the EICAS and EDS system (Ref. AMM).

Select maintenance switch to ON, buttons ED, PFD to OUT positions and turn the Data Control Panel (DCP) Mode key clockwise to select to Maintenance Mode on the MFD. (Refer to the Aircraft Maintenance Manual for switches and push button locations and functions).

The maintenance menu will be displayed on the MFD. Use the keys in the DCP to go to the desired menu as follows:
RDR
FMS
ET
TFC
MAG/TRUE
The lettered keys are used and the function of each key is defined at the bottom of each screen.

From the maintenance menu move the cursor using the DCP keys and select "Propulsion System Diagnostic" to access the selection menu for engine diagnostic system. By selecting "PROPULSION SYSTEM DIAGNOSTICS", the operator can examine engine diagnostic data such as fault data, trend, mission analysis, pilot request data, engine operational data and the real time display.
The display will ask to select the EEC from the left (port) or right (starboard) engine.

The selection menu will now appear and offer 9 options. The cursor is automatically positioned at "PROPULSION DISK DOWNLOAD" option. The 9 options are as follows:
Propulsion Disk Download
Engine Operational Data
Propulsion Fault Data
Engine Exceedance Data
Trend Analysis Data
Spare
Pilot Request Data
Installation Configuration Data
On-Ground Engine Operation Data (Real Time Data)

procedure.title: Downloading EDU Data
procedure.caution: IF INABILITY TO DOWNLOAD THE EDU, DO NOT SWAP EDU AND/OR EEC FOR TROUBLESHOOTING PURPOSE. PROCEED WITH THE MAINTENANCE MANUAL, FAULT ISOLATION CHART, WITH FAULT CODE “YZ”.
procedure.note: Engine selection is determined when selecting Left or Right engine on the Propulsion System Diagnostic menu.
procedure.step: Select "PROPULSION DISK DOWNLOAD" from the selection menu. Follow instructions on the MFD screen for downloading data.
For menu selection during downloading refer to (Figure , Downloading EDU Data).
The system will download on the diskette and will indicate when the operation is complete. Download may take up to 20 minutes per engine.

procedure.title: Engine Operational Data
procedure.step:
Return to the main selection menu using the TFC menu key and move the cursor down or up to the "ENGINE OPERATIONAL DATA" menu using DCP keys and press the key to select. This option will display the following three menu selections of operational data on the MFD:
Flight Data
Operational Data
Accumulated Data

The Flight Data selection displays the following information:
No. of in-flight Shutdowns
Flight duration
No. in-flight start accels
TLAI APR duration
TLAI takeoff duration
TLAI climb duration
Reverse thrust duration
No. of APR achieved

The Operational Data selection displays the following information:
No. of flight legs
No. of touch and go's
Engine operation duration
Ground start accel duration

The Accumulated Data selection displays the following information:
No. of flight legs
No. of in-flight shut-downs
No. of touch downs
TOT flight duration
TOT operation duration
TOT ground start duration
In-flight start duration
Cycles/hour
Average monthly usage

procedure.title: Propulsion Fault Data (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Return to the main selection menu using the TFC menu key and select the "PROPULSION FAULT DATA" menu by moving the cursor down or up then use the key to select.

There are 3 possible menus from that option:
MFD fault codes
Engine data at time of fault
Discrete status at time of fault

By moving the cursor to the appropriate timestamp and selecting it, details of engine parameters, continuous data and discretes will be displayed (Ref. Fig. - Standard Parameter Lists, Propulsion Fault Data). The data shown on the MFD screen are extracted from the snapshot recording corresponding to the selected fault code.
Up to 10 pages of fault data can be displayed, starting with the latest codes. When no fault has occurred, the following message will be displayed "NO OCCURRENCE OF FAULT DATA".

procedure.title: Engine Exceedance Data
procedure.step: Select the "ENGINE EXCEEDANCE DATA" menu by moving the cursor down or up then use the key to select.
If any of the following parameter's (ITT, N1, N2, Take Off Duration, Oil Temperature and Oil Pressure) red line limit is exceeded, the EDS will send an exceedance message on the EICAS display.
The message will only be displayed when the aircraft is on the ground to warn the operator to check the EDS.
The maximum number of exceedances shall be three pages, starting with the most recent exceedance.
By moving the cursor to the appropriate time stamp and then selecting it, the 4 pages of the Standard Parameter List will be displayed (Ref. Fig. - Standard Parameter Lists, Propulsion Fault Data).
If there are no faults stored in the fault history log the following message will be displayed: "NO OCCURRENCE OF EXCEEDANCE DATA".

procedure.title: Trend Analysis Data
procedure.step: Select the "TREND ANALYSIS DATA" menu by moving the cursor down or up then use the key to select.
For the operator who wishes to use ECTM, engine data is automatically captured by the EDS. A snapshot is taken at max cruise altitude, once the engine parameters have stabilized.
The operator can view up to the latest 10 records.

The EDS shall display a list of the most recent trend recordings. The operator shall be able to view the 10 most recent trend recordings. When the operator selects a trend recording, the EDS shall display the standard parameter list.
If there are no trend recordings stored, the EDS shall display: NO OCCURRENCE OF TREND DATA.

procedure.title: Pilot Request Data
procedure.step: Return to the main selection menu using the TFC menu key and select the "PILOT REQUEST DATA" menu by moving the cursor down or up and use the key to select.
This option will display the engine data that was recorded when the EDS record switch is activated.

This will allow the pilot or technician to request data recording of engine parameters into the EDS memory, in case of abnormal engine operation (fluctuation, abnormal loss of power, sudden ITT split, etc.).
The EDS will record 4 minutes before plus one minute after the EDS record switch has been triggered.
By moving the cursor to the appropriate time stamp and then selecting it, the operator will see the 4 pages of the Standard Parameter List (See Ref. - Propulsion Fault Data).
A list of the 10 most recent pilot request events shall be presented to the user. If no pilot event requests are avaiable, the EDS will display: "NO PILOT REQUEST DATA AVAILABLE".

procedure.title: On-Ground EEC Data (Real Time EEC Data) and Fault Codes
procedure.step: Return to the main selection menu using the TFC menu key and select the "ON-GROUND EEC DATA" menu by moving the cursor down or up.

This option will assist the operator in engine troubleshooting by displaying real time engine parameters, status words and fault codes. Live EEC data is displayed. The screen is continuously refreshed, to show real time data.

There are two options from this menu:
Fault Summary - provide fault codes for both channel
Real Time Display - Provide display of engine parameters
In maintenance mode, continuous data from the selected EEC will be shown. In flight mode, data from both engines will be displayed on EICAS.

The "Fault Summary" menu provides real time display of fault codes for better understanding of the warning indicators for quick fault isolation.. In this menu, both channels of one engine are displayed.
The "Real Time Display" menu of engine parameters can be used for maintenance activities requiring continous feedback such as TLA rigging. In this menu, both engines lane in control are displayed.

n-para.title: Engine Diagnostic Unit (EDU)
n-para.caution: MAKE SURE AIRFRAME ELECTRICAL POWER IS OFF WHEN HANDLING RECEPTACLES AND PLUGS.
MAKE SURE PLUGS AND RECEPTACLES ARE FREE OF MOISTURE; IF NECESSARY, DRY USING HEAT GUN.
DO NOT FORCE OR STRETCH HARNESS WHEN INSTALLING CONNECTORS OR SECURING SELF-LOCKING LOOP CLAMPS.
USE ONLY APPROVED TOOLS TO TIGHTEN WIRING HARNESS CONNECTORS. CONNECTORS ARE PROPERLY TIGHTENED WHEN ONLY BLUE COLOR BAND IS VISIBLE; RED COLOR BAND MUST NOT BE VISIBLE.

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: Removal and Installation of EDU and Supporting Bracket

procedure.step: Download all data per Para.
Remove connector P36 (1) using soft jawed pliers (PWC90012 or Glenair TG69) or Mini strap wrench (PWC58104 or Glenair TG70).
Install protective caps on connectors J36 (2) and P36 (1).

Remove
nut (3) F13EN05-19 1 and
washer (4) F13EW03-10 2 .

25270: Remove four
bolts (5) F13EB20-08 4 and
ground terminal (6) F13ET07A02 1 .

25270: Remove four
bolts (5) F13EB20-08 4 ,
washer (13) F13EW03-10 2 and
ground terminal (6) F13ET07A02 1 .

Remove
EDU (7) F13BE10-01 1 .

Remove two
bolts (8) F13EB20-09 2 and
nuts (9) F13EN05-17 2 .

Remove two
bolts (10) F13EB20-10 2 and
washers (11) F13EW03-19 2 .

Remove
EDU bracket (12) F13EB40A34 1 .

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: If a 25158 engine incorporates 25104 at a later date, 25158 must be replaced with 25150.
If a 25207 engine incorporates 25104 at a later date, 25207 must be replaced with 25203.
Engines that have incorporated the intent of 25203R2, Part B (improved "user friendliness" of the engine diagnostic unit (EDU) software), have incorporated the intent of 25241.
procedure.step:
Install
EDU bracket (12) F13EB40A34 1 with two
washers (11) F13EW03-19 2 and
bolts (10) F13EB20-10 2 .

Install two
bolts (8) F13EB20-09 2 and
nuts (9) F13EN05-17 2 .
Torque bolts (10) 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0 to 4.5 Nm).
Torque nuts (9) 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0 to 3.3 Nm).

25270: Install
EDU (7) F13BE10-01 1 ,
ground terminal (6) F13ET07A02 1 and four
bolts (5) F13EB20-08 4 .

25270: Install
EDU (7) F13BE10-01 1 ,
ground terminal (6) F13ET07A02 1 with
washer (13) F13EW03-10 2 and four
bolts (5) F13EB20-08 4 .

Install
washer (4) F13EW03-10 2 and
nut (3) F13EN05-19 1 on opposite end of
EDU ground terminal (7) F13BE10-01 1 .

Torque four
bolts (5) F13EB20-08 4 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.0 to 4.5 Nm).

Torque
nut (3) F13EN05-19 1 32 to 36 lb.in. (3.6 to 4.0 Nm).
Remove protective plugs on connectors J36 (2) and P36 (1).
Install connector P36 (1) to connector J36 (2).

DO NOT LUBRICATE THREADS.Tighten the connector P36 using one of the following methods:
SOFT JAWED PLIERS HAVE A DESIGN SLIP TORQUE OF 100 lb.in (11.3 Nm). DO NOT USE STEEL JAWED PLIERS TO TIGHTEN CONNECTORSTighten the connector using soft jawed pliers (PWC90012) or Glenair TG69. Apply reasonable force to make sure connector coupling nut is firmly tightened and the red band is covered.
WRENCH ASSEMBLY CONNECTOR HAS A DESIGN SLIP TORQUE OF 100 lb.in. (11.3 Nm).Tighten the connector with a wrench assembly connector (PWC58104) or Glenair TG70. Apply reasonable force to make sure connector coupling nut is firmly tightened and the red band is covered.
Verify and update the aircraft information (Ref. AMM).

n-para.title: EDU Data Access with Portable Computer Programs PCTS422 or GBS

procedure.title: Accessing EDU Data with the PCTS422 Program
procedure.step: The EDU provides an RS-422 channel for communicating with a portable computer (laptop) that has the PCTS422 program (P/N 3053379). To connect the laptop computer to the aircraft’s maintenance panel for EDU data access, (Ref. AMM). Turn on the aircraft electrical power, if it is not already on. If possible, plug the laptop computer into an external power source instead of running off its battery. Turn the computer on and launch PCTS422 program. The “PWC Configuration” window will appear. Select the left or right engine as applicable. The left or right selection must match the engine that the download cable is connected to. Make sure the laptop computer is configured correctly for communication. Typically it uses COM1. The display will change when the connection is set. Use the keyboard function keys to navigate through the screens, as indicated near the bottom of the display screen.

step.step: The “Fault Display” option will assist the operator in engine troubleshooting by displaying real time engine faults and the last 7 flight legs fault history.

Access the “Selection Menu” and select “Fault Display” by using key F3. The line that starts with an asterix (∗) displays the current faults (not yet stored in the permanent memory). Lines 0-6 are the faults that are stored in permanent memory from the 7 previous flight legs (maximum of 6 faults per flight leg).

Scroll through the faults using the function keys, and a simple description of the highlighted fault will be displayed near the bottom of the screen on line 24. For complete details on installing and using PCTS422 software you may refer to the PCTS422 users guide and reference manual.
In the “Real Time Display” option, live EEC data is displayed from both channels.
Access the “Selection Menu” and select “Real Time Display” by using key F3. The display will change to show continuous data with a two second refresh rate.
Seven pages of engine data are available. Use the function keys to scroll between the pages.

The “Cumulative Operational Data” option is used to read the following data:
Number of flight legs
Total flight duration
Total operational duration
Number of engine starts
Cycles/hours ratio
Average flight hours per month
To display the above data, access the “Selection Menu” and select “Cumulative Operational Data” by using key F3.

A data snapshot and a data recording (approximately. 5 minutes) are automatically taken for the following events:
Starting T4.5 exceedance
Operating T4.5 exceedance
N1 exceedance
N2 exceedance
Oil temperature or pressure below min. exceedance
Oil temperature or pressure above max. exceedance
Time at take-off exceedance
Faults
Flameout
Commanded shutdown in flight
APR activation
To display a list of the above events, access the “Selection Menu” and select “Historical Event Data” by using key F3. To analyze the content of the snapshots and recordings you must use the GBS.
When the “Pilot Rec” button on the cockpit pedestal is pressed, a data snapshot and a data recording (approximately. 5 minutes) is taken.

To display a list of the pilot requested data, access the “Selection Menu” and select “Pilot Request Data” by using key F3. To analyze the content of the snapshots and recordings you must use the GBS.

The EDU stores the following data:
Aircraft Make, Model, S/N, Tail Number, Timestamp.
Engine Model, S/N, Left/Right Position, Timestamp, N1/T4.5 Trims.
EEC S/N, Timestamp, S/W Version.
EDU S/N, Timestamp, S/W Version, Trim Table S/W Version.
To display the above data, access the “Selection Menu” and select “Installation Configuration Data” by using key F3.

procedure.title: Accessing EDU Data with Ground Based Software (GBS)
procedure.step:
DPHM software is a suite of windows based application used for engine management. It has four main software components:
GBSLite Diagnostic Module (P/N 3070181) - provides fault/event display and sorting, transient plotting, snapshot display mission analysis, and histogram analysis.
PW30X Transfer Module (P/N 30B2977) - program to communication with EDU and download/upload EDU data.
PW30X Trim Editor (P/N 3059718) - a program to modify operational, configuration, and N1/T4.5 trim files.
PCTS422 (P/N 3053379) - a real time interface program (Ref. Para. ).

step.step:
Connect to EDU
MAKE SURE AIRFRAME ELECTRICAL POWER IS OFF BEFORE CONNECTING ELECTRICAL CONNECTORS.Connect the GBS cable (PWC61969) to the airframe connector. Connect the other end of the GBS cable (PWC61969) to the laptop computer. Power up the aircraft electrical system. Open the GBSlite by double clicking on the icon. Make sure COM port #1 is available before launching this application. If any palm pilot type software is located on your laptop, it must be temporarily turned off or deactivated. This type of software protects COM port # 1 and will inhibit your ability to download the EDU files. If your computer is not equipped with a physical COM port, it is possible to use the USB adapter (PWC90191) to communicate with USB port (USB drivers provided with USB adapter must be previously installed).
Open the GBSlite by double clicking on the icon.
From the GBSlite Express Panel, select “Download EDU” under the Download and convert EDU data tab, this will launch the “PW30X Transfer Module Windows Application”.
Verify if communication is established by using the “Transfer” pull-down menu and select “Check Data Line”.

Make sure a window appears, stating “Communication OK”. If not, recycle the program and check the cable connections and communication setup. If error screens appear, do a check of the connections. Repeat this step until the “Communication OK” message will appear. If error screen continue to appear, exit and enter the PW30X Transfer Module again. Contact P&WC if the problem persists.
From the PW30XTm program, select the “Change Dir” button and select the newly created folder. Once the folder is selected, click the OK button.

Download current EDU data: This procedure copies the stored data from the EDU memory into the laptop computer. When the data is stored in the laptop computer it can be modified as necessary and uploaded to the same EDU or a replacement EDU. Select the download button or use the “Transfer” pull down menu. For routine data downloading select “ECTM Data”, (this will produce files in “.bec” and will take approximately 3 minutes). For complete data downloading select “All recordings”, (this will produce files engine in “.brc” and will take approximately 20 minutes). When the computer has read the data, a conversion window will appear, select “Convert All’. This completes the downloading of the EDU data.
Connect the EDU per .
Do the EDU download per .
To view downloaded data in GBSlite, select “EDU Analysis” under the analyze previously downloaded EDU data, then select the appropriate data folder.
In the Fault/Event panel (top panel), the data is sorted by data and time, the latest recording can be found at the bottom.
Select Fault/Event Code; the name of the event code will appear at the top in red.
If the IETM, P/N 30B4134 is installed, clicking on the Fault/Event Code will link to the appropriate maintenance action in fault isolation charts.
Select the associated snapshot and trace for further analysis of the Fault/Event, which can be viewed in the lower panel.
The .brc. or .bec file can be sent to the Designated Analysis Center (DAC) for data analysis or can uploaded to the P&WC internet-based WebECTM Services.
If required, the trim editor (P/N 3059718) can be used to modify the stored EDU data files as applicable and then initialize them. The PW30X Transfer Module can be left open during this step.

The trim editor allows the modification of the following files:
Installation/Configuration:- Aircraft ID, Engine ID, EDU ID, and N1/T4.5 Trim values.
Operational:- # of Flight Legs and Flight Duration etc.
Double click on the “PW30X Trim Editor” icon. When the “Edittrim Windows Application” window appears, you can select the items you wish to modify.

Select the “Installation Configuration” button in the ‘‘Edittrim Windows Application”. Type in the password “toronto” and select “OK”. Select the “No” button in the change password request, unless you need to change the password. The “Select an Install Config file” window will appear, select the file (_____.bec or .brc) you created when you downloaded the EDU data and select “OK”. The file name ‘‘_____.bec’’ is derived from the engine S/N and the number of down loads. Example - the first download from engine S/N CF0062 would appear as ‘‘f0062001.bec’’. This is the convention used for all the downloads completed. The “Installation Configuration” window will appear, the two choices in it are:
Aircraft ID
Engine ID
Select “Aircraft ID” button, modify the aircraft’s S/N, registration and owner/operator as applicable. Select “Save and Exit”. Select “Engine ID” button, modify the engine S/N, model number, service plan number, N1 trim value and T4.5 trim value as applicable. Select “Save and Exit”. In the “Installation Configuration” window, select the “DONE” button to save all the changes.

Select the “Operational” button in the “Edittrim Windows Application”. The “Select a Binary Recording File” window will appear, select the file (______.bec or .brc) you created when you downloaded the EDU data and select “OK”. The “Operational Data” window will appear with a “Cumulative Data” button. Select “Cumulative Data” button and a window will appear with many fields of operational data. The only fields that should be modified if necessary, to agree with the logbook are the “# of Flight Legs” and “Flight Duration”. All other fields should not be changed. The time duration are in seconds. When you are finished, select “Save and Exit”. Select “Done” button in the “Operational Data” window. All files are now corrected, initialized and ready for uploading. Exit from the “Edittrim Windows Application” by clicking on the “File” pull-down menu and selecting “Exit”.
The PW30X Transfer Module is now used to upload the initialized files that you have modified in the previous steps.

To upload the installation configuration data to the EDU: Select “Transfer” pull-down menu and select “Write Installation Configuration to EDU”. The “Select an Install Config file” window will appear. Select the file (_______.bic) that was created in the previous steps and select “OK”. The “Progress” window will appear. After the EDU Installation Configuration is uploaded the “Progress” window will disappear.

To upload the operational data to the EDU: Select “Transfer” pull-down menu and select “Write Operational Data to EDU”. The “Select a Cumulative Operational Data file” window will appear. Select the file (_______.boc) that was created in the previous steps and select OK. The “Progress” window will appear. After the Cumulative Operational Data is uploaded the “Progress” window will disappear. The uploading of all files is now complete. Exit from the “PW30X Transfer Module” window by clicking on the “File” pull-down menu and selecting “Exit”. The EDU is now updated with the necessary files. Cycle the EEC power and check for fault codes. Fault codes with the prefix letter ‘‘Y” which indicate EDU faults should be given priority (Ref. 72-00-00, FAULT ISOLATION).

n-para.title: General (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The lubrication system is an unregulated oil system which provides the required oil flow rate to the engine mainshaft bearings, all accessory drive gears and all accessory bearings, throughout the complete engine speed range. The oil flow lubricates and cools the bearings. Calibrated oil nozzles in the main engine bearing compartments ensure that the required oil flow is maintained under all operating conditions. The four mainshaft bearings are lubricated by under-race lubrication. The system consists basically of a pressure system, a scavenge system and a breather system.

n-para.title: Pressure Oil System (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The oil tank is an integral annular cavity within the intermediate case, located between the bypass and core gas paths. It is a "hot-tank" type because the scavenge oil is not cooled before returning to the tank. Oil is drawn from the oil tank through a passage in the bottom strut of the intermediate case by a gear-type, fixed displacement pressure pump. The oil is delivered into the inlet of the oil filter assembly. An integrated oil pressure adjusting and cold start valve mounted on the pump cover monitor oil pressure downstream of the oil pump.

The PAV bleeds pressure oil in excess of the preset value back to the pressure pump inlet. The PAV position is set for each engine to give a pressure differential between the AGB oil feed pressure and the No. 3 bearing scavenge pressure at a specified engine speed and temperature. Provision is made for airframe connection to this pressure differential for cockpit indication. In addition, an engine mounted oil differential pressure switch provides an electrical indication if the pressure differential falls below 20 psid. A cold start valve mounted on the pressure pump cover diverts oil from the pressure pump outlet into the oil pump inlet if oil pressure over 200 psig occurs during cold weather operation.

From the pressure pump, oil passes through the oil filter, which incorporates a filter bypass valve as a safeguard against filter blockage. An impending bypass indicator in the oil filter housing provides an electrical cockpit warning, prior to bypass valve actuation.
A thermal lockout in the oil filter impending bypass switch prevents indication below 100°F oil temperature to avoid false indications at engine start-up with cold oil.
Oil from the filter outlet is routed through the dual matrix fuel/oil heat exchanger. The hot engine oil is cooled by bypass fuel from the hydro-mechanical metering unit (HMU).

External piping routes oil from the heat exchanger outlet to the anti-syphon device, which is integral with a boss on the side of the intermediate case. The anti-syphon device contains a small hole drilled through to the expansion space at the top of the oil tank. Following engine shut down, the anti-syphon hole serves to break the syphon action caused by the tank oil level being higher than the main bearing oil jets.

From the anti-syphon device, pressure oil is directed by internal passageways in the intermediate case, to the No. 1 and 2 ball bearings, as well as to the outside diameters of the No. 1 and 2 bearings to provide squeeze film rotor damping. A tee-fitting on the rear of the intermediate case directs oil via transfer tubes to the towershaft plain bearing and to the top of the gas generator case, where an integral passageway in the diffuser section routes oil to the No. 3 roller bearing oil jet.

Pressure oil is also routed from the anti-syphon device down the side of the engine via external piping to a tee-fitting. The tee-fitting further divides the oil flow rearward to the No. 4 roller bearing, for bearing lubrication and squeeze film rotor damping, and downward to the AGB for lubrication of gearshaft plain and roller bearing elements, and the oil pump journals.

n-para.title: Scavenge Oil System (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The scavenge oil system incorporates three double-element scavenge pumps. The pumps are gear-type, contained in cast housings within the AGB, and are driven by the fuel pump gearshaft. Oil from No. 1 and 2 bearing compartments is drained by gravity through the strut at the 6 o'clock position of the intermediate case, into the AGB sump. Scavenge oil from No. 3 and 4 bearings is pumped by separate elements of the oil pump assembly, through external transfer tubes along the bottom of the engine, into the AGB sump. The scavenge flow from all bearing compartments is aided by P2.8 pressurizing airflow through the labyrinth air seals. When the bearing scavenge is via a gear pump, bypass valves are incorporated around the pump elements to prevent pressure build-up in the scavenge lines at higher bearing cavity pressure conditions.

Scavenge oil, returned to AGB, collects in a sump at the bottom of the housing and is scavenged out by a separate scavenge pump element which returns it to the top of the oil tank via external piping up the side of the intermediate case.

A self closing magnetic chip detector is installed at the bottom of the AGB, in the scavenge oil passage, to provide indication of potential engine distress by monitoring the presence of contaminants or debris.

The oil pump drive train is arranged such that the main pressure pump elements will not be driven in the event of a failure of any of the scavenge pumps. This feature prevents oil flooding the engine core because of an inoperative oil scavenge pump.

n-para.title: Breather System
n-para.para: Breather air from engine bearing compartments and the AGB is vented overboard through an impeller type centrifugal air/oil separator installed on the alternator gearshaft in the AGB. The bearing compartments are connected to the AGB either by cored passages or by external scavenge oil return lines.

No. 1 and 2 bearing compartments vent via a hollow strut into the AGB. The No. 3 and 4 bearing compartments are vented to the AGB via No. 3 and 4 bearing scavenge oil tubes, and the oil tank is vented within the intermediate case.

The engine features a differential oil pressure indicator, fitted just over the oil filler cap, to indicate any over-pressure condition in the AGB. A popped-out red button indicates an over-pressure condition in the AGB.

n-para.title: Fuel/Oil Heat Exchanger (Ref. Fig. )
n-para.para: The fuel/oil heat exchanger is mounted on the oil pressure manifold, which is in turn mounted on the left side of the accessory gearbox.

Engine lubricating oil enters the heat exchanger from the oil pressure manifold and is directed by baffles to flow around the tubes through which fuel flows. Heat transfer through the tube walls raises fuel temperature before it enters the fuel filter assembly. The fuel/oil heat exchanger also serves to cool engine oil prior to distribution to the engine bearings and accessory gearbox.

The fuel/oil heat exchanger body and matrix are made of aluminum and the whole assembly is brazed and welded into an integral unit. All external surfaces are anodized, coated with primer and finished with epoxy enamel, except fuel and oil mounting flanges.
Fuel/Oil Heat Exchanger

module.pageblock-title: OIL FILTER AND HOUSING - MAINTENANCE PRACTICES

general.para: Lubricate preformed packings, threads and mating surfaces with engine oil unless otherwise stated.
Install protective caps and plugs on disconnected tubes, component openings and electrical connectors after sub-assembly.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.
Refer to INTRODUCTION for alternate products, suppliers and suppliers addresses.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Remove three
self-locking nuts (8) F41LN05-10 3 and
washers (7) F41LW03-07 3 holding
oil filter cover (6) F41LC28-03 1 to oil filter housing assembly (1). Whenever oil filter element (4) is being removed for a routine check or as a troubleshooting aid, the cover (6) should not be drained prior to removal in order to facilitate inspection of contents.

Withdraw oil filter cover (6) with
oil filter element (4) F41LF08-01 1 installed.

Remove
retaining ring (2) F41LR20-04 1 and withdraw filter element (4).

Discard preformed packings
(3) F41LP03-21 1 and
(5) F41LP03-23 1 .

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.caution: MAKE SURE OIL FILTER ELEMENT IS FULLY SEATED IN COVER AND ELEMENT END CAP IS NOT HUNG UP ON FILTER BOWL LOCATING LUGS.
MAKE SURE THAT THE RETAINING RING IS FULLY SEATED IN THE GROOVE.
procedure.step:
Insert new
oil filter element (4) F41LF08-01 1 into
oil filter cover (6) F41LC28-03 1 with the three tangs uppermost and install
retaining ring (2) F41LR20-04 1 .

Install new
preformed packing (3) F41LP03-21 1 in oil filter element (4) and new
preformed packing (5) F41LP03-23 1 in oil filter cover (6).

MAKE SURE THAT THE OIL FILTER COVER IS IN LINE WITH THE OIL FILTER HOUSING. DO NOT PINCH PACKINGS. TIGHTEN NUTS EVENLY IN A TRIANGULAR PATTERN. MAKE SURE FILTER COVER IS FULLY SEATED BEFORE TIGHTENING AND TORQUING NUTS (8).Install oil filter cover (6) with oil filter element (4). Secure with three
washers (7) F41LW03-07 3 and
self-locking nuts (8) F41LN05-10 3 . Torque nuts 32 to 36 lb.in. (3.6-4.0 Nm).
Do an Oil Level Check (Ref. 72-00-00, SERVICING).

n-para.title: Oil Filter Impending Bypass Indicator and Bypass Valve

procedure.title: Removal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Drain oil system (Ref. 72-00-00, SERVICING).
Disconnect airframe cable connector from bypass indicator.

Remove two
bolts (8) F41LB20-47 2 and withdraw
oil pressure differential switch (7) F41LS66-01 1 . Discard preformed packings
(5) F41LP03-18 1 and
(6) F41LP03-19 1 .

Withdraw
spring (4) F41LS44-01 1 and
oil filter bypass valve (3) F41LV01-01 1 .

procedure.title: Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Position
spring (4) F41LS44-01 1 in core of
bypass valve (3) F41LV01-01 1 and insert valve into filter housing (1) with spring end out.

Install new preformed packings
(5) F41LP03-18 1 and
(6) F41LP03-19 1 on
oil pressure differential switch (7) F41LS66-01 1 and install into oil filter housing. Secure with two
bolts (8) F41LB20-47 2 . Torque nuts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

procedure.title: Removal of Chip Detector (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Remove chip detector (10) from AGB.
Remove and discard preformed packings (8) and (9).
Remove valve housing (7). Remove and discard preformed packing (6).
Remove bolts (4) and washers (2).
Remove adapter (5) with puller (PWC37728).
Remove and discard preformed packing (3).
Remove oil strainer (1).

procedure.title: Installation of Chip Detector (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Install oil strainer (1) into the AGB chip detector boss.
Install packing (6) on the adapter (5). Lubricate the packing (6) with engine oil (PWC03-001).
Install the adapter (5) in the AGB with two washers (2) and bolts (4). Torque bolts 36 to 40 lbf.in. (4.1 - 4.5 Nm).
Install packings (8) on the valve housing (7). Lubricate the packing (8) with engine oil (PWC03-001).
Install the valve housing (7) in the adapter (5). Torque 200 to 225 lbf.in. (22.5 - 25.4 Nm).
Install packing (9) on the chip detector (10). Lubricate the packing (9) with engine oil (PWC03-001).
Install chip detector (10) in the valve housing (7). Torque 90 to 100 lbf.in. (10.1 - 11.2 Nm).

n-para.title: Inspection/Check
n-para.note: For periodic inspection refer to Chapter 05-20-00.

procedure.title: Oil Filter Element
procedure.step: Visually inspect filter as follows: If more than 5 percent of the visible passages are blocked, filter element must be discarded. If filter element is distorted, dented, or broken wires are found, discard filter element. If debris is evident, proceed as follows: Use a magnet and determine if any of the debris is magnetic. If magnetic debris is found, use a magnifying glass and inspect. Analyze debris and take appropriate action (Ref. Subpara. ). Carry out a patch making procedure (Ref. Subpara. ). When analysis results are received, inspect oil system (Ref. Subpara. ).

procedure.title: Debris in Oil System Inspection:
procedure.note: All debris collected by the chip detector or in the oil filter that is not non-allowable debris Category 1, must be sent to a qualified laboratory for analysis.

Debris analysis monitors wear of oil-wetted engine parts. This procedure improves aircraft serviceability and dispatch reliability and reduces engine repair cost. This is achieved by identifying potential engine problems at the earliest possible stage, thus minimizing the possibility of unscheduled engine maintenance.

Rapid wear or surface fatigue (e.g. on gear teeth contact surfaces, bearing raceways, rolling element, housing bearing bores etc.) or interference between rotating and fixed components (e.g. oil pump pinions, associated housings and labyrinth seals etc.) produce debris. Magnetic debris over 100 microns in diameter are usually captured by the chip detector. Magnetic and non-magnetic debris over 10 microns in diameter are usually captured by the oil system filter.

Laboratory analysis (form, appearance, dimension, quantity and material) of the debris captured by the filter and chip detector is necessary to provide the information needed to facilitate in locating the source of the debris and determining any preventive maintenance action required.

The operator must provide to the laboratory the following information with the filter, chip detector and debris: 1. Engine model, serial number and position2. Engine time since new or time since overhaul3. Time since last inspection4. Aircraft type, serial number and tail number5. Reason for filter removal, inspection and debris analysis

The laboratory must issue an inspection report to the operator which includes: 1. Information provided by the operator with the filter, chip detector and debris2. Total weight of debris3. Material and amount of non-magnetic debris when classified as major4. Material, appearance, shape and amount of non-magnetic metallic debris5. Material, appearance, shape and amount of metallic debris6. The amount of individual constituent in the debris should be classified as:
Major - When the weight of the constituent is more than 40% of the total debris weight.
Minor - When the weight of the constituent is between 10% and 40% of the total debris weight.
Trace - When the weight of the constituent is less than 10% of the total debris weight. 7. Minor metal contamination may occur and appear at the first inspection of new engines, or engines recently having completed extensive shop work. In such cases, normal precautions apply.8. Debris definitions:
Particle - A piece of metal less than 0.010 inch in size.
Chip - A particle larger than 0.010 inch.
Flake - An extremely thin metal chip.
Sliver - Thread-like piece of metal.
Fuzz or Powder - A mass of very fine and light particles.
procedure.step: Inspection and Classification - Visually inspect debris with magnifying glass and/or microscope, as follows: Allowable Debris - Small quantity of hair-like filaments, fuzz, or powder, providing there has been no prior history of debris, allowable or non-allowable, generation within the last 400 flight hours. Non-allowable Debris, Category 1: Keywasher fragments, gear tooth segments, etc. Non-allowable Debris, Category 2: Large quantities of hair-like filaments (fuzz) or powder. Large quantity is defined as sufficient fuzz and/or powder filaments to completely cover the end of the chip detector. Any quantity of hair-like filaments (fuzz) or powder if the engine has a history of generating debris (allowable or non-allowable) within the last 400 flight hours. Non-allowable Debris, Category 3: Dark irregular magnetic chips with a minimum dimension of 0.010 in. (0.254 mm). Small clusters of magnetic flakes (three or more). Thin, shiny rolled flakes with feathered edges and more than 0.020 in. (0.508 mm) in size are generated when bearing surfaces break down due to excessive load (spalling). The outer surface of the flakes are highly polished and may show parallel impressions. The inner surface has a rough wavy or granular texture. After the bearing surface breaks down, the underlying material disintegrates and chips with dark, coarse and irregular shapes are produced. All other debris not defined above.

Non-Magnetic Materials - Debris most frequently found in the oil filter include: Aluminum - Thin needle like fragments and powder Source - The most probable source of these types of contamination is the main/scavenge oil pump housings/covers. Fragments are produced when the pump inner wall is scratched or grooved. Powder is the result of cavitation or erosion. Action Required - If more than 10 fragments are found, remove oil pumps, inspect the housings and covers and replace as necessary. If powder and/or less than 10 fragments are found, continue in service while monitoring oil pressure. If oil pressure drops significantly, remove and inspect engine oil pumps. Silver Plating - Flakes Source - The most probable source of this debris is silver-plated nuts. Action Required - None. This type of debris is acceptable and the engine can continue in service. Magnesium Powder Source - The most probable source of this contamination is the accessory gearbox or intermediate case. Contamination could be caused by bearing outer races fretting in the housing bores. Action Required - If this type of debris is found, the engine can continue in service provided an oil filter patch check is done every 250 flight hours and the amount of magnesium powder is monitored. If the amount of debris increases, replace the accessory gearbox. Carbon Particles The most common non-metallic debris is carbon particles caused by thermal breakdown of the oil due to hotspots in the engine. This type of debris is acceptable and the engine can continue in service with no special inspection required. However, if an oil filter impending bypass indication occurred, and the amount of debris collected in the oil filter and housing does not indicate that a bypass has actually occurred, and the major contaminant is carbon, proceed as follows: Drain, flush and fill the oil system again. Return the engine to service. Remove and inspect the oil filter for debris after the engine has run for approximately 50 flight hours. If the engine continues to generate carbon and the debris quantity is the same or has increased, an engine removal is recommended. Silica Particles Source - Silica debris indicates that dirt or atmospheric pollutants may have entered the oil system via labyrinth seal pressurization air and/or while replenishing oil. Excessive amounts of silica can indicate blocked cooling air passages and worn labyrinth seals. Action Required - To restore the silica content to normal levels, an oil change is required. Engine can remain in service provided oil consumption and MOT are within limits. Copper Fragments Source - Usually found with fibre insulating material and paint chips in the accessory gearbox scavenge oil strainer. This type of debris may be caused by failure of electrical equipment. Action Required - Engine can remain in service. Inspect the oil filter after 50 flight hours. If the engine continues to generate copper and the quantity is increasing, inspect the engine permanent magnet alternator (PMA) and the aircraft permanent magnet alternator (PMA).
Debris analysis must be done by approved laboratories; refer to Service Information Letter No. GEN-123 for the list of approved oil laboratories.
